PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. What plans does the Government have to lower the income tax burden on lower and middle income families?

—These matters are matters for Government policy which are continually under review. Let us look at the income tax rates which we inherited in government and the enormous changes which have been made under this Government during its period in office. I am surprised that this question comes from Senator Short, who is described by one learned commentator as `bogus' in what he has had to say about these issues. I am surprised indeed that it has come from Senator Short.

PARA.TAB: Over a period of years this Government has made substantial changes to income tax levels in this country and, if it is appropriate, will do so in the future. Before the Opposition gets too excited, we should remember in the course of this debate that this country has one of the lowest tax to GDP ratios of any country in the OECD. So do not get too excited about that particular issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I take it, quite obviously, from the Minister's answer that the Government has no plans at all to lower the income tax burden on lower and middle income earners. I therefore ask the Minister whether the Government has any plans to compensate those income earners for the $22 billion of income tax paid to the Government through bracket creep since it came to office or for the threefold increase in the tax take from the Government's hidden consumption tax, namely, the wholesale sales tax, over the same period.

—Senator Short, who is in the package mentality which developed last week, has put a number of questions in his supplementary. He talks about lowering the tax burden on Australian taxpayers. Implicit in that is that the Opposition's so-called package does all of that. Professor John Head, who is an authority on this matter, says that the aggregate burden on workers, in relation to the Opposition's package, is not reduced by the tax mix switch.

—Mr President, on a point of order: I asked a very simple question of the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Both the original question, which he failed to answer, and the supplementary question were directed totally to the Government's policies. The Opposition's policies are out on the table and we will debate those with the Government any time it likes. But in Question Time today I am asking the Minister for answers about the Government's policies, not ours.

—That was a nice little speech, which explained to me that Senator Short was asking a simple question. I am not surprised, because that is the gist of this so-called package put forward by the Opposition. It was devised by simple minds to mislead simple minds. That is what it is about.

—Mr President, on a point of order: I ask for your guidance on this matter. The questions I have put to Senator Button relate entirely to seeking information on the Government's policies. The Minister has not addressed that question in one word yet. I ask you to ask him to address the question that has been put to him.
—Order! The Minister has replied to a question and a supplementary question. That is all that can be allowed.

—The principal question went to income tax, and I answered that. Senator Short then tried to ask a supplementary question about payroll tax, compensation for income tax, and so on. The honourable senator is very excited about this promise that one day—Sunday too far away—he might examine the question of payroll tax in this country. It is an enormously attractive promise—to examine the question of payroll tax at some distant time in the future.

—I raise a point of order, Mr President. A very clear question was put to the Minister about his Government's policies. You have ruled in the past that questions have to be directed to the portfolio of the Minister. This question was directly related to the portfolio responsibilities of the Minister. We are happy to debate the broadly based goods and services tax at any place, any time. But could the Minister give the Government's plans?
—What is the point of order?
—Just keep quiet and you will hear.
—No, you shut up.
—Order! I ask Senator Cook to withdraw.
—Mr President, I withdraw.

—Order! In relation to the point of order, I think that so far Senator Button's answer has been in order; but I would remind him to take note of the question he was asked and not to dwell on the Opposition's policies.
—The supplementary question, as I pointed out, related to payroll tax.
—No, it didn't—income tax bracket creep.
—It is bad news for this Opposition if Senator Short does not even know what he asked about. In his supplementary question he specifically asked about payroll tax and compensation.

—On a point of order, Mr President: my question did not relate to payroll tax; it related to income tax bracket creep and to the increase in wholesale sales tax. It had nothing at all to do with payroll tax.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—Senator Short asked me about payroll tax and then he went on to talk about compensation for bracket creep. Talking about compensation, over a period of time in the life of this Government we have introduced substantial income tax changes. There is always the possibility that we will do that again. We have been able to do that as a government because of the significant broadening of the tax base in this country, which those opposite never did. As a result, we have been able to deal with tax issues as they have come along.

PARA.TAB: The Opposition comes in here today full of excitement. I can understand that because, after all, these issues were all available to members of the Opposition in the past but they did not deal with them. They did not deal with them, as Mr Downer—smart Alex—said in the House last week, `because we lacked the guts'. Now the Opposition is full of guts and noise, but the questions its members have to answer really relate to their brains and their policy prescription. If Opposition senators want to deal with that issue, we will happily deal with it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. What is the Commonwealth's role in the problem of contamination of the Darling River by toxic blue-green algae?

—I am aware, as I am sure many honourable senators on this side are, that a massive outbreak of blue-green algae has appeared in the Darling River. The outbreak extends almost 1,000 kilometres from Wilcannia to Mungindi on the Queensland border—I am from Western Australia; it is not quite the same as being from Barcelona, but it is a long way from Mungindi.

PARA.TAB: This is one of the largest recorded blooms of such algae. I understand that algae blooms are not infrequent during periods of low river flow and are, therefore, in this case partly a side effect of the current drought. The bloom outbreak poses an immediate threat to the water supplies of Wilcannia, Louth, Bourke, Brewarrina, Walgett and Mungindi.

The New South Wales water and health authorities are devising strategies to minimise the growth and impact of the bloom, with particular regard to downstream water users and domestic water supplies. The New South Wales Department of Water Resources, in consultation with the Murray-Darling Basin Commission, is implementing a plan utilising the Menindee lakes system to reduce the risk of algae spreading to the waters of the lower Darling and the River Murray below the Darling junction. This should isolate the bloom to New South Wales.

There are health risks to humans and to stock in using this contaminated water. As yet, the New South Wales Government has not asked the Commonwealth for any assistance in dealing with the problem, although various Commonwealth authorities are in regular contact with their State counterparts. I can also say that there are newspaper reports suggesting that the Army could be brought in to cart water to affected areas. I am advised by my colleague the Minister for Defence that the assistance of the National Disaster Organisation has, up until now, not been sought.

The Commonwealth has long recognised the significance of the freshwater algae problem and, in conjunction with the States, has engaged in important long term work through: the Murray-Darling Basin Commission, which is preparing a nutrients survey of the whole of the Murray-Darling basin; the Australian Water Resources Council, which is developing a national water quality strategy; and its funding of the Land and Water Resources Research and Development Corporation, which is currently sponsoring some 15 research projects related to algae blooms.

But at the moment the Commonwealth's role is essentially strategic. I am advised by the Minister that any requests for assistance from the New South Wales Government would receive prompt and efficient attention.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Is the Government concerned about the high rates of marginal tax which mean that a worker on average earnings now faces a marginal tax rate of over 39 per cent?

—I do not really have much to add to what I said before. Of course governments are concerned about high marginal rates. Every government would like to lower marginal rates; every government would like to lower taxes generally across a whole spectrum of activities. Every government would like to do that. It is only an opposition that can come in and do that by way of a con trick like this package which was announced last week—a curate's egg, if ever there was one.
—Have you been reading the press lately?

—Yes, I have been; probably more carefully than the honourable senator. The fact of the matter is that if the implication of Senator Watson's question is that a lot of people will be greatly better off under the proposed Opposition package, it is quite clearly wrong.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Given the Government's concern, to which the Minister has just referred, why has it allowed marginal tax rates on average earnings to increase from 30 per cent to 39 per cent since 1983, when it came into office? Why did the Government believe in 1985 that it was important to reduce marginal tax rates?

—In answer to a question here I am not going to go back to see what the Government was concerned about in 1985. I am most concerned about the situation in the 1990s and what will happen in the remainder of this decade. That is the concern I have about the future of this country.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Does the Government intend to impose annual medical reviews of disability support pensioners who have an impairment level of under 70 per cent, as suggested by the Opposition?

—The answer is absolutely not. I think it is important for all honourable senators to understand what this measure really means. It is important to understand what impairment levels are about, because it is pretty clear that those who have made the suggestion do not understand. The best way to explain the cruel nature of this suggested change—the absolute disgrace in regarding those with impairment levels of 70 per cent and under as being in some way malingerers—is to give some examples of what impairment levels are.

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. As you are well aware, under the Standing Orders questions can be asked regarding matters concerning public affairs. In the last sitting week you limited that—
—You don't like us talking about Opposition policy.

—Senator Collins should just listen. In the last sitting week, Mr President, in your interpretation you limited that to matters relating to the administration of the Department of the Minister concerned; in other words, strictly relating to his administration. In such terms, you ruled out of order a question we asked Senator Richardson regarding Cabinet solidarity in his operations as campaign manager for Mr Keating. Mr President, I put to you that you should apply the same rule to the Government as you apply to us. Matters that go beyond the administration of Senator Richardson's Department are out of order. If he wishes to debate any part of the Opposition's Fightback package, we are more than happy to accommodate that at the end of Question Time.

—Mr President, I wish to speak to the point of order. First, we are not surprised; we expected this unique application of double standards when the Opposition sought to apply a standard at Question Time last time we sat and does not like it when it is being applied on this occasion. Senator Alston's eloquent plea last time about Standing Orders was one we knew would rebound. We all enjoyed it then. We looked forward to this day, and it has arrived.
—Where is your point of order?

—I am speaking to Senator Hill's so-called point of order. Senator Beahan's question as to whether the Government was going to undertake a certain action within the portfolio of the Minister was quite clearly within Standing Orders, and the Opposition knows it.
—Mr President, on the point of order: Senator Hill has outlined the position with regard to your rulings—
—We saw you at the Parramatta shopping centre. You were standing in front of Hewson all the time.
—Order! There are too many interjections on both sides today.

—Thank you, Mr President; there was a gaggle over there. Senator Hill has correctly outlined a synopsis of the way you have interpreted the Standing Orders. I ask you to state whether you intend to uphold your previous ruling or whether you intend to bury it, irrespective of what Senator McMullan has had to say.

—Order! In reply to the points of order, I have not interpreted the standing order in any special way. It has been consistently ruled by past Presidents and by me in recent times that questions to Ministers must relate to subjects within their ministerial responsibilities. It has also been ruled consistently by me and by former Presidents that a question that invites a Minister to comment on Opposition policies is out of order, unless the question is linked to the Government's intentions or some other matter of ministerial responsibility. It has been the practice that, if a question contains an element linking it to the Minister's ministerial responsibility, it is allowed. I believe that Senator Beahan's question is perfectly in order.
—Mr President—
—Order! I have ruled on that.

—Mr President, I have a point of order. Senator Richardson has said that the Government has no proposals to introduce the test. As the Government has no plans to introduce the test, the question is therefore answered.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—As I was saying before I was rudely interrupted, I think it is important to note why the Government would not take this action. I think the best way to explain it is to look at some examples of what these impairment levels entail. I will give just a few examples, but I would be very happy, if I were requested to do so, to give a whole lot more. A 70 per cent impairment level will very often involve paraplegia. One wonders how we are going to wheel paraplegics in to have annual medical reviews. I find it extraordinary that anyone would even suggest that a saving would be involved, that suddenly the condition would get better and the lame would walk. I only wish they would.
—You don't believe that.

—No, I certainly do not believe that. Let us take another example, that of someone with a 60 per cent impairment level who has a psychiatric condition. The individual would require the kind of supervision that would prevent him from injuring himself or causing injury to others. He would need supervision even to maintain minimum standards of personal hygiene. One wonders what is to be gained by forcing those people back to medical reviews.

PARA.TAB: Let us look at someone with a 50 per cent impairment of neurological function. There one is looking at someone with an impairment of comprehension, at an individual who would be unable to understand simple instructions, even to answer yes-no questions, no matter how many gestures accompanied them.

TALK.START.PARA: —What rubbish!
—That is a fact. The trouble is that Senator Alston does not understand it. It is about time he listened.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. The Minister is debating the issue, which is specifically outlawed by the Standing Orders. He was asked whether he had any intention of introducing these changes. He has said no. Now he is developing an argument; in other words, he is seeking to debate the question. As that is out of order, I ask you, Mr President, that you rule so.

—I wish to speak to the point of order, Mr President. What I am doing, Mr President, is giving the reasons that the Government will not consider medical reviews. One cannot do that without explaining what people with the impairment levels under question actually suffer from. That is what I am endeavouring to do.
—Order! There is no point of order. I remind Senator Alston that if he continually interjects he should naturally expect a reply from the Minister.

—If we then look at a 40 per cent level—we are starting to get way down under the 70 per cent level now—and take as an example those with gynaecological conditions, we are talking about individuals who would have severe symptoms, despite continuous treatment, and who would need considerable assistance with ordinary daily activities. Even if we look at people with a 30 per cent impairment level—we are getting really low here—and take as an example those with gastrointestinal disorders, we are talking about people with bowel disorders with no response to medication and very considerable interference to their daily routine.

PARA.TAB: Even if we take the absolute base level for a disability support pension, a 20 per cent impairment level, and look at people who have an alcohol and drug abuse problem, we are talking about individuals who have an addiction established over time, an addiction that prevents work and that causes prolonged absences.

One wonders what kind of response we would get to forcing the lame and the sick to have medical reviews. We have been told that we could get huge savings. I say to Senator Beahan that the Government often looks at questions of medical reviews. We have done it time and time again. The trouble is that if we were to do this we would be talking about 300,000 medical reviews per year at a minimum cost of $100 a throw. We are talking about $30m. We are also talking about being able to get only a one or two per cent recovery rate out of forcing 300,000 of the lame and the sick to go back to medical reviews. This is not just politics; this is miserable politics of the worst kind. This is a disgrace, and no-one should own up to it.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Military Aid and Exports to Indonesia

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. In the light of the Dili massacre and other gross violations of human rights of East Timorese by Indonesia since 1975, will the Government immediately cease all military aid and exports to Indonesia and the training of Indonesian military personnel?

PARA.TAB: An incident having occurred in the gallery—

TALK.START.PARA: —The question appeals to me a little less than it does to the grandstand up there, for the reason that the events in Dili, appalling and abhorrent as they unquestionably were, were in our judgment, on all the available evidence so far, not a matter of deliberate or calculated government policy but rather represented some aberrant behaviour by a section of the military. I say `on all available evidence`; should there emerge contrary evidence, of course that judgment would need to be revised. But, as such, the situation is quite distinct from that, for example, which occurred in Tiananmen Square in China in 1989 which did reflect very deliberately a calculated act of government policy. As such, our concern has been to ensure that the event in question, in all its horror, is fully and properly investigated and that appropriate follow-up action is taken. Again, there is no basis for any assumption at this stage that investigation will not be conducted on a proper basis and that appropriate follow-up action will not be taken. There is no basis for any such assumption.

PARA.TAB: For that reason, the Government has resisted taking action of any kind which would represent a significant downgrading in the bilateral relationship, whether it takes the form of minimising or deleting the very small amount of defence cooperation activity which occurs at a sum of just over $2m, or any form of trade sanction whether it relates to defence exports or anything else, or any form of cancellation of visits, or any form of reduction of aid, which is quite substantial. All those forms of bilateral response designed to express a formal protest are in our judgment quite inappropriate in the particular context that I have described. What is appropriate is some more constructive form of Government action of the kind that we will be debating later today. I do not want to spend time spelling that out. But it will involve diplomatic action, through a visit in the next few weeks to Indonesia by me, and other related activity. That is the appropriate response. There is simply no basis for proceeding down the particular path that Senator Coulter has described, however much—I repeat—we all regard the awful incident which occurred in Timor on 12 November as thoroughly abhorrent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. Does the Minister's answer to my question mean that he agrees with Mr Brian Loton that the events in East Timor are `peripheral' to the more important considerations of Australia's relationships with Indonesia?

—No, it does not mean for a moment that I regard the events in East Timor as peripheral. However, it does mean that I think that those events should be looked at in the perspective that I have described. In the absence of any evidence at this stage either that they were directed as a matter of specific government policy or that they will be covered up and not followed through in an appropriate fashion, it is quite inappropriate for action of the kind that Senator Coulter seems to have in mind to take place. Of course, human rights issues are not peripheral to our relationship with Indonesia or anybody else.

PARA.TAB: Of course, in particular, the human rights situation in East Timor is not peripheral. It has been a central focus of our involvement with Indonesia for very many years. We have made the judgment, over many years, that the realities of international life and the nature of the international willingness to go down the path of recognising rights to self-determination and so on are so limited and the realities are such that the human rights of the Timorese people are better pursued through active encouragement and general international pressure upon Indonesia to do that. That is the course that we have followed so far. It has been a productive course over the last few years. Tragically, however, that particular course came to a very unhappy and unsavoury halt with the events on 12 November. It is going to be a matter of judgment as to whether that course is capable of being re-created or whether some other course may need to be followed in the future. However, it is premature to make any such judgment at this stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Will the Government require sickness allowance applicants to provide two medical certificates in support of their claim and continuing entitlement?
—You obviously did not get the message across too well on the Jana Wendt show if you have to have another run.
—Will this result in substantial savings, as the Opposition suggests?
—One day they might ask Senator Alston to go on the show, but I doubt it very much.
—There wasn't anything to answer.
—Given that I had three minutes, I thought that I was doing all right.
—Order! Can the private debate across the chamber stop.

—I would be very happy to, Mr President. The only reason that I have seen for this suggestion was given by Senator Alston in an interview on 3LO when he said, `We won't just take someone's word for it or one local GP's certificate. We will analyse these people carefully and, if necessary, we will have two independent medical assessments'. In looking at the way that sickness allowance is granted and the kind of regime that applies, obviously a medical certificate has always been and will remain part of that regime.
—It is only part of it.

—Yes, it is only part of it but a very important part. If one wanted to make savings out of those on sickness allowances, if one regards them as simply people from whom savings should be sought, the first thing one has to remember is that any savings have to be offset by the very considerable additional costs under health insurance arrangements to cover another 120,000 medical consultations a year. Even based on 85 per cent of the schedule fee, we are talking of more than $2m.

PARA.TAB: In looking at these arrangements, it has to be understood that the client currently meets the cost of the consultation fee for the initial medical certificate and subsequent medical certificate. That is already the client's responsibility. I am not sure whether Senator Faulkner is suggesting, as I think the Opposition has, that those two certificates have to be provided every 13 weeks, given that the length of time of the doctor's certificate is generally 13 weeks. But if that is the suggestion, with the kind of pressure that would be placed on sickness allowees, who by definition are not in the best of shape to start with, then it is the kind of suggestion that the Government would reject and reject out of hand. Medical certificates specifically for use in determining social security eligibility have recently been redesigned to provide some more comprehensive information to assist any assessment that the Department has to make.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because it has been too easy.

—No, it is simply to make assessment easier. I do not think Senator Alston has ever understood any of this. It has also to be noted that in many areas of Australia, especially in many remote areas—I am sure that Senator Boswell and his colleagues would be aware of this—there simply are not doctors to do this. Finding two doctors to do this sort of thing is just impossible. We are talking about a regime that simply cannot be implemented, so the Government would not do it. In any event, we are returning to the politics of misery, of trying to squeeze every last dollar out of the lame and the sick. That is the kind of politics that this Government will not ever cop.
—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Does the Minister still support the removal of payroll tax?
—How simple is that?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was a good interjection from Senator Macdonald—`How simple is that?'. It is a very simple question. The removal of a wholesale sales tax—I am sorry, a payroll tax—
—You are getting mixed up. We are dealing with the payroll tax.
—The removal of payroll tax is not on the agenda for any political party in Australia. It is a matter which would be considered by this Opposition if it were ever elected to Government.

—That is all it says. The honourable senator ought to know his text—`We will go to the States and talk to them about it'. A great hallucinating jawbone session will be had with the States; that is what it means.
—It says it will be withdrawn.
—No, Senator, it does not. It depends upon which version one reads.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. We have had three minutes of what Senator Button thinks our policy means. The very straightforward question was: where does he stand on payroll tax? It has nothing to do with anyone else but Senator Button and his attitude to payroll tax. I ask you, Mr President, on the grounds of relevance, to direct him to answer only that question. You definitely have the power to do that.
—Order! I believe that the Minister is developing an argument. It is not my role to judge the accuracy or truthfulness of answers to questions.

—I raise a point of order, Mr President. Presidents have ruled on many occasions that answers have to be relevant to questions. The question, as Senator Button agreed, was very straightforward. It was, `Do you still strongly support the removal of payroll tax?'.
—Senator Kemp, I would be very happy if every answer was yes or no, but the Minister is entitled to develop an argument.

—Of course, the question is asked in a political context. Senator Kemp has never asked me this question before but he has suddenly come in here and asked it today. Why has he asked it today? He has done so in order to offer some vague blandishments about the removal of a payroll tax.
—I raise a point of order. Mr President, you have just said in answer to—
—Are you still going to the Parramatta shopping centre?
—Mr President, there is such a noise in that corner. Could we have a little quiet?
—There is too much noise throughout the whole chamber.

—Thank you, Mr President. You have just ruled in answer to that point of order that the Minister is entitled to develop an argument. I wonder whether you could define for the purposes of the Standing Orders the distinction between developing an argument and debate, which is forbidden by the Standing Orders.
—Order! The Minister is entitled to give reasons why he supports or opposes something. That is what I believe the Minister is doing.
—Mr President, do I understand, then, that you have ruled that he may not develop an argument but he may give cogent reasons which are relevant to the question asked and that only?
—Order! Continue, Senator Button.

—Mr President, the point I am making is that one cannot answer this sort of question in abstract from the total political and economic consequence. I could be a very popular politician, as John Hewson is trying to be—

PARA.TAB: Government senators—You are.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you. But the fact of the matter is that one cannot divorce these questions from that context. Mr President, if the question is, `Would I like to have no payroll tax in this country in a hypothetical society?', the answer is yes. If it is, `Would I like to have no payroll tax and have it replaced by a goods and services tax?', the answer is no.
—Why not?

—Why not? I think this is very well explained by two of the leading tax experts in this country, Professor Freebairn and Professor Head. Neither of them are locked into huge fees as consultants to the Opposition or this Government at any time and they are very impartial observers of the tax system. Both of them say this:

ANSWER.PARA: The payroll tax is simply a tax on the value added by labour.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President—
—I thought you mob wanted to talk about your GST.
—We do. We are quite happy to debate it.
—Well, sit down.

—That is the point of order and that is what Senator Collins does not seem to understand. Standing order 73(4) states, `In answering a question, a Senator shall not debate it'. We are happy to have the debate at the appropriate time. This is not the appropriate time. Senator Button is not answering the question; he is seeking to debate it and he should be ruled out of order.
—Order! The answer is in order. I remind Senator Button that it is becoming a long answer.

—I have been a bit interrupted, Mr President. Senator Kemp is asking me whether I want to throw a bait to industry by saying, `Yes, payroll tax should be got rid of'. There is a superficial attraction in that. But, if payroll tax were replaced with a GST, that would have exactly the same effect on employment cost.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I notice that Senator Button has said that he is in favour of abolishing the payroll tax. If honourable senators look very closely at his answer, I think they will see that that came out.
—What is the question?

—I say to Senator Cook that my question to Senator Button is: as he is in favour of abolishing the payroll tax, and as he has now been in government for eight years, does he have any plans to abolish this tax?

—Senator Kemp is really leading with his chin with this one. I said that in a hypothetical society in which economic and political considerations are taken into account, the answer to that question is yes. But I ask Senator Kemp not to misrepresent me in pursuit of his arguments in favour of a GST. His credibility on the proposed GST is pretty bad. He has had a fair time in the Senate, misrepresenting the GST, misrepresenting the effects of the GST on exports and misrepresenting the effects of the payroll tax on exports. He has done all that in the past and he is doing it again with me today. He did not ask a supplementary question and he is totally misrepresenting the issue.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. I refer to reports of the disturbance at the National Exhibition Centre yesterday. Can the Minister provide details in relation to the large number of arrests made by the AFP at the AIDEX 91 arms exhibition?

—I am advised that there was a meeting between the AFP operations commander and the leaders of the protest groups to try to ensure that there would be a minimum level of disturbance of the peace in relation to the protests outside the AIDEX 91 exhibition at NATEX. In fact, as we know, there was severe disruption. On 25 November, yesterday, demonstrators barricaded with scaffolding the entrance to NATEX and they positioned themselves behind the barricade.

PARA.TAB: The protesters were given a direction to disperse by a senior police officer who feared that an imminent breach of the peace might occur. The protesters failed to comply with the direction and were individually arrested. Senator Josephine Vallentine was directed to disperse and was warned that, if she failed to obey the direction, she would be arrested. She failed to comply and was given a further direction. Senator Vallentine failed to comply and was subsequently arrested. I understand, Mr President, that you have been informed of the arrest of Senator Vallentine.
An incident having occurred in the gallery—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There is too much noise emanating from the gallery.

—Despite the applause coming from the public gallery, it shows great patience on the part of the police officers concerned that they twice asked Senator Vallentine to disperse and she refused twice before they arrested her. It was quite clear that she was intending to be arrested.

PARA.TAB: A total of 172 persons were detained or arrested and 163 persons were detained and put before the court. They were asked to agree to be bound over to keep the peace. They refused to be bound over. I understand that Senator Vallentine also refused to be bound over to keep the peace.One would think that a leading peace activist would agree at least to keep the peace in accordance with our ordinary common law traditions.

I have made inquiries as to the actual circumstances because I was concerned, naturally. As I understand, there have been no complaints made to the Australian Federal Police about the conduct of the arrests. So far as I am able to ascertain, there have been no complaints made to the Federal Ombudsman either about the means by which the Federal Police carried out their duties. There has been a complaint to the Ombudsman on one issue, but it had nothing to do with the actual circumstances at NATEX.

The demonstrations have continued today. I understand that eight further injuries have occurred so far today; one to a demonstrator and seven to police officers, including the breaking of an arm of a police officer. Mr President, there are guffaws from the gallery. I repeat that seven of the injuries today have been sustained by police officers, including the breaking of an arm of a police officer. I believe that the police have performed the duty that they are required to in the Australian Capital Territory to attempt to keep the peace. I wish that demonstrators who wish to make their views known, as they are entitled to in our society, would themselves keep the peace in accordance with their claimed deep-seated convictions.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Has the Government any plans to restore full employment in Australia? Will the Government table any such plans if it has them?
—Senator Baume has asked this question on numerous occasions before. I take it that it has a different gloss on it today because—
—The one million unemployed would like to know.

—The one million unemployed would like to know whether there is any efficacy in the Opposition's promises which have been described by experts as illusory, falsely based and bogus. These are some of the words which have been used to describe the Opposition's promises about full employment. The answer to that question that I have given to Senator Baume on numerous occasions in the Senate—
—Nothing.
—Not `nothing', Senator; not at all.
—It was a nothing statement last week.

—That is Senator Hill's view but it is Senator Baume's question I am answering, not his. We look for and expect a recovery in the Australian economy, as I have said. That will go a long way towards improving the employment situation in this country.

—I ask a supplementary question. I asked the Minister: did the Government have any plans to restore full employment? He has in fact, by giving no answer, clearly indicated he has no plans and has refused the offer to table any such plans. I asked the question in the context that we have detailed here our plan to create two million jobs after the Government has just destroyed a quarter of a million of them. We had a statement only last sitting week from the Prime Minister—
—Ask the supplementary question, Senator Baume.

—In view of the Prime Minister's statement last sitting week on employment which created no jobs either, I ask the Minister again: does the Government have any plans or does it intend to develop any plans to create full employment or even any jobs in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I pointed out, in answer to his first question, Senator Baume has raised this issue on numerous occasions at Question Time, and he knows the answer. But today he has raised it again. The Liberal Party is a bit excited at the moment because for the first time it has developed some sort of alternative view to the Government—after nine years. It is a bit of an alternative view which lacks coherency but, more than that, lacks credibility. I quote:

PARA.TAB: But the general impression left by the document—

ANSWER.PARA: that the overall majority of ordinary Australians will be gainers in the short term is at best highly misleading.

PARA.TAB: On the more important economic issues—

ANSWER.PARA: which I must say includes employment—
the Hewson document offers an absurdly optimistic assessment.

That is what the Opposition is about. Last week the Opposition put a curate's egg in the nest and it is going bad already; it will continue to go bad. That is what I said last week, and it is right. It is a curate's egg which will go bad. So do not get too excited about it.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Removal of Excise on Aviation Gasoline

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Zakharov Sen A.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask whether the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support has seen the Opposition's statement:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . that the coalition commitment to remove all excises, including on aviation gasoline, will provide a substantial boost to the aviation and tourism industries, over and above benefits flowing from our open skies policy and flexible employment contracts.
Will the Government remove such an excise to produce a `substantial boost' to tourism?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is not proposing to remove the excise from avtur aviation fuel.
—You are a party of big taxes.
—What did you do with avgas?

—I am very thankful to Opposition senators for their interjections. If they had waited just a second I would have explained that the reason the Government is not proposing to remove this excise from avtur fuel is that we did it five years ago.

PARA.TAB: There is an excise charged on avgas, which is exclusively used by piston-engined aircraft, and the number of tourists that are actually carried on piston-engined aircraft in this country is too small to measure. To refer to the Opposition—

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr President: if my memory serves me correctly, this matter the honourable senator is dealing with is subject to material that is on the Notice Paper and, as such, should not be debated.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—The Opposition has already discovered this hole in its package. Bryan Grey of Compass Airlines, who actually knows a little bit about the aviation industry, recently pointed out to the Opposition that, as far as his own fleet was concerned, Airbus A300s do not run on petrol. Along with all other jet aircraft and turboprop aircraft, which service most of the regional routes in Australia carrying tourists, they run on avtur, not avgas. At the time the Government established the Civil Aviation Authority we abolished the excise on this fuel.

PARA.TAB: The coalition says that the abolition of this excise, which has been gone now for something like five years, will result in a `substantial boost' to the tourism industry. Bryan Grey pointed this out to the Opposition, and it was forced to put out a statement defending the integrity of its package and attacking Bryan Grey's knowledge of the aviation industry. That is deserving of note because it is a classic of its kind and redolent of the snake oil that will have to be used in the next 12 months to defend this impossible to defend policy. It is a beauty: the headline of the press statement put out by the shadow Treasurer, Peter Reith, states:

ANSWER.PARA: Bryan Grey (Compass) and Wayne Goss Wrong on GST and Airlines

This is a classic. The statement says, in chapter 16, page 291, that these benefits will be `over and above' other benefits flowing from the aviation package. The abolition of the excise will result in `a substantial boost' to tourism. Bryan Grey pointed out to the Opposition that it is nonsense, which it is, and Peter Reith replied with this press statement on 24 November, which states:
There is no mistake in our package and it will be overwhelmingly beneficial for the airline industry.
Why is there no mistake in the package? Listen:
While Avtur is not presently subject to fuel excise, it equally won't be subject to the GST either. . .
So, because the Opposition is not proposing to tax a fuel which is currently not being taxed by the Government, this will result in a `substantial boost' to the tourism industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said this?

—The person who said this is the alternative Treasurer of this country. I am not a Rhodes scholar in economics, but I have read Animal Farm. Clearly, I will have to re-read Animal Farm over the next 12 months to point out the fatuous nonsense that is contained in this document. The Opposition does itself no credit at all by compounding that nonsense with absurd press statements such as the one to which I have just alluded. The press release goes on to say that the other benefits flowing to the aviation industry from the Opposition's package will include such things as the privatisation of airports. I intend to deal with that particular subject on another day.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Does the Minister support the view of his colleague the Minister for Finance, Mr Willis, that the former Treasurer, Mr Keating, should return to Cabinet to provide the Government with an effective defence against the Opposition's tax reform package?
—It is not a matter relating to my ministerial portfolio to respond to remarks by Mr Willis which I have not heard. I doubt very much the accuracy of the attribution.

—Mr President, in view of the Minister's response, I ask a supplementary question. Are the reports in today's media accurate that several Ministers from all factions plan to persuade Senator Button to resign from the Cabinet to make way for the former Treasurer? If so, will the Minister advise the Senate as to when he will be standing down?
—I have not seen any of those reports and nobody has said anything to me about them.

—I refer the Minister for Defence to the defence export guidelines which state that exports may not be approved where a risk exists that they will be used against the citizens of the importing country. Firstly, given repeated Indonesian atrocities in East Timor, West Irian, Aceh and elsewhere, can the Minister explain why approvals were granted in 1989-90 to Australian Defence Industries to sell ammunition to the Indonesian armed forces? Secondly, what further approvals to export military equipment to Indonesia have been given since 1989-90 and what is the exact purpose of the military training of Indonesian personnel conducted under the defence cooperation program? Thirdly, given that the purpose of AIDEX is to promote and facilitate military exports, including exports to Indonesia, and given the profound community opposition to AIDEX evidenced yesterday and today, will the Minister rule out his support for future arms exhibitions?

PARA.TAB: An incident having occurred in the gallery—

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank my fan club for the reception. In relation to defence exports to Indonesia, the export guidelines have been scrupulously and properly met. The ammunition to which Senator Spindler refers, as he knows full well, is 4.5-inch naval ammunition used for practice purposes. He knows that, but everyone else has been saying, `Probably our ammunition was used in Dili'. That is absolute nonsense. None of our defence exports have ever been used for internal security purposes.

PARA.TAB: Senator Spindler goes on to ask what other defence exports have been sent to Indonesia in the period 1989-90 and onwards. There are three: first, material used for seismic testing, which because of its explosive nature comes under defence guidelines; secondly, cryptographic equipment, which comes under defence guidelines but in fact is for commercial use and not military use in Indonesia; and, thirdly, some engine and spare parts for DC3s.

That is the totality of our defence exports to Indonesia. It is remarkably low. Indonesia does not seek to source its defence equipment within Australia—I assume for reasons of price rather than anything else. While Senator Spindler may not have been trying to imply that the ammunition was used in Dili, others who have been associated with him have. I think it is a good opportunity to at least put that to rest.

Senator Spindler went on to ask about Indonesians being trained under the defence cooperation program. This is a remarkable question. The defence cooperation program with Indonesia was cancelled in 1986. It has not been revived and will never be revived. It simply does not exist. In fact, as the honourable senator would well know, the defence relationship was somewhat strained from 1986 through to 1990. The tentative re-establishment of a reasonable defence relationship has occurred from 1990 onwards. That has occurred mostly at a senior level and is mostly aimed at trying to create a degree of transparency in our region so that there will be no military misunderstanding.

The honourable senator, although he did not ask for the number, asked whether Indonesians were involved in training in Australia. There are some, but far less than all of our other neighbours because this is a very tentative relationship which is being built up. I very much defend the type of military training that we provide because it broadens the horizons of officers coming from overseas and broadens their experiences of other cultures and other values. The one thing Australia is excellent at is training: having a disciplined and polished officer coming out the other end who will exemplify the best, not the worst, of military values. None of that training is to do with internal security matters; nor would the Indonesians ever expect it to be so.

We then come to the third point. Senator Spindler said first of all that AIDEX is primarily to promote the export of defence goods. The primary reason for any exhibitors being there is in fact to show their defence goods to the Australian defence forces and the Australian Department of Defence, because they are their big customers. I have had to repeat on many occasions for the honourable senator's benefit that the key to defence exports is not whether they are moral or amoral as such, but rather where one sends them and the nature of what one sends.

The honourable senator has tried time and time again to come up with examples that have eventually fallen on their face. He made reference to the overwhelming community support against AIDEX. I suspect that most of the community do not know about it. But I will tell the honourable senator something: rent-a-crowd and mob rule do not equate to policy.
Opposition senators—Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —Those opposite might `Hear, hear!' on this point, but with our behaviour here today we have not set a very good example—and I am included in that—to the people in the gallery. So we have to take a bit of pain ourselves. But it does not show overwhelming support when 400 or 600 people demonstrate in that way. I have had to warn my Defence Force that there is nothing more dangerous than a pacifist, because pacifists can belt the living daylights out of a person. If anything has proved that, it has been the events at AIDEX in the last few days. Whether AIDEX is good or bad is a point open for public debate. It is a relevant point for demonstrators to act upon, if they so desire, within the law; but what it comes down to eventually is export controls.

PARA.TAB: I have been a little disturbed by the assumptions in, and nature of, Senator Spindler's question, but I want to finish on this note. The one thing that really irritated me is the Canberra Times: it fulminates against AIDEX, yet manages to run a full page advertisement from British Aerospace, a prime exhibitor there. If that is not the height of press hypocrisy, I will give it away.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister said that there is nothing more dangerous than a pacifist; I suggest to him that the military establishment is more dangerous. Will the Minister continue to promote it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have always noted that, when in doubt on issues, the Australian Democrats usually refer to the United Nations. I refer to those clauses in the United Nations charter which make it the

ANSWER.PARA: responsibility of every country to defend itself and to have the capability of defending itself. The tragedy of areas such as Kuwait and others was that they did not have that capacity. There were others at fault in that situation, and we have noted that before in this chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that why we sold arms to Iraq?

—Defence exports were a major factor in that; I put that on the public record. The irresponsible export of arms to a warfare state is totally unacceptable behaviour. The honourable senator has checked our record and he knows that most of our defence exports go to our closest allies: New Zealand, United States, Great Britain and Papua New Guinea. We have had a fairly impeccable record of not taking up export opportunities to those countries with gross human rights violations or to areas of massive instability. The sooner the honourable senator comes to terms with that and stops trying to jump on a populist band wagon the better.
—Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

—Mr President, what is your current practice in relation to cheer squads in the gallery? Are we all going to be permitted to bring a cheer squad along to support our particular political point of view? If not, why has no action been taken in this matter?

—Order! I suppose I have to make a judgment as to whether the work of the chamber is being disrupted. My judgment today was that if people were to be removed forcibly—and the removal of the first person caused quite some disturbance—we would play into the hands of those who were seeking further publicity.

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. From my observations of the last 30 seconds, it seems to me that tolerance, decency, patience, good manners and indulgence do not incite a civil response. One can speculate as to whether Senator Collins and Senator Tate are defending that sort of conduct; I do not know whether they are. The Standing Orders are clear. Senator Hill asked a persuasive question. In the event that there are the same number of people representing a different point of view, can they presume, from the precedent set today—and I am very mindful of the response that you have made to Senator Hill—that they are allowed to come into the gallery and conduct themselves in the same way on the basis that a response to them would only cause a retaliation of the kind that we saw? Is this chamber going to be subject to blackmail because of the threat or prospect of worse conduct than that being offered or can we assume that in the future these people will not be encouraged by the notion that they can conduct themselves as they wish and that the Senate will be suspended for them to be cleaned out or whatever?

—Order! In reply to Senator Crichton-Browne, they will certainly not be encouraged. In reply to the question asked of me by Senator Hill, I said that I had made a value judgment. As Senator Crichton-Browne would well be aware, I have had occasion to clear the gallery before and I will do it again if I think the circumstances warrant it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of answers given by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) in response to two questions without notice asked this day by Senators Behan and Faulkner relating to disability payments.

SPEECH.PARA: In particular, I note that Senator Richardson was at pains to suggest that there was nothing that could be done in the welfare area to tighten up the system. Those of us who have had to put up with Senator Richardson over the last 18 months know full well that time and again he claims that not one extra cent can be wrung out of welfare administration. Yet hardly a week goes by when we do not find either the Auditor-General saying that the work test is not being enforced or mobile review teams detecting that hundreds of millions of dollars are going astray in the welfare system. As a result, of course, we have social security costing something in the order of $28 billion and the number of recipients going up by about a million per decade.

PARA.TAB: In these areas, which we all acknowledge are potentially very sensitive, it is incumbent upon any government to make sure that income support goes to those in need. That is clearly not what has been happening in this area. Indeed, that is the reason that the Government itself went through a whole series of essentially cosmetic changes to turn invalid pensions into disability support pensions and sickness benefits into sickness allowances. The Government was not even predicting savings; indeed, it was predicting costs.

One wonders why the Government went through all of that. The answer is manifest, I suggest. It did so because it was acutely aware of the fact that the numbers had blown out beyond any justification. The Government simply cannot explain why over the last decade there has been an increase of 66 per cent in the number of people receiving disability support pensions—or there will be by the end of this financial year. The Government cannot explain why, when it first introduced these changes, the number receiving such pensions had already risen by 43 per cent over a 10-year period when the population growth rate was much less than 10 per cent.

The answer lies clearly in the number of phone calls that I get from doctors around Australia who complain to me that people going into the Department of Social Security asking for the unemployment benefit are being told that they would be much better off to go to the local doctor to get a certificate to be put on a sickness allowance. In due course, they would be transferred from the sickness allowance to an invalid pension. I would be pardoned for using the old terminology. That is precisely what is being put to me time and again from doctors in a number of States around Australia.

I do not suggest that this Government has actually circulated a memorandum encouraging the Department to do this, but it has done the next best thing to it; it has turned a blind eye. It wants to get people off the unemployment list—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is dishonourable, mischievous and wicked.
—I do not think Senator Crowley understands a word of this.
—I understand it very well.

—Senator Crowley does not get the same phone calls I do. The fact of the matter is that we are concerned, as Senator Richardson ought to know if he has looked at the documents, to assist those people in genuine need. We will not be insisting on everyone having an automatic review, in person, every year. Where the disability is manifest, we will not require people to be put through a personal assessment.
—That is not what your document says.

—The document does not say anything about personal assessments. It says that there will be an annual review. It is quite a simple matter to see whether someone is manifestly disabled, in which case a personal assessment would not be required. Anyone listening to the answer we got from Senator Richardson today would not think that there was a functional disability in the system, let alone a low-backed soft-tissue injury in the place.
—He has got one.

—He has a lot of things wrong with him, but I do not think we can cure them with the invalid pension. The fact remains that there are very many people at the low end of the system—and again we know this because this is why the system was changed. The Social Security Appeals Tribunal said that people with impairment levels of less than 15 per cent were getting invalid pensions. There are administrative memoranda going around to that effect. That was clearly because the Department was prepared to turn a blind eye to people who had very low level disabilities—mild to moderate at best. They are the people that we are talking about tightening up on. Senator Richardson well knows that ACROD, the peak council in the area, also takes a very dim view of the lax administration in this area. That is where the savings are to be made, not just for the sake of savings but so that the Government can do some of the decent things that it ought to have done years ago.

PARA.TAB: The Government knows that the Cass report recommended a disability allowance. It has been dithering about it for more than three years. We have done it. In this package we have said that we will give $45 per fortnight to those people at the severe end of the spectrum who are in need of additional assistance. It will cost $57m, but we are prepared to spend it, just as we are prepared to give money to the voluntary agencies, which the Government has not been prepared to do. The Government has not given one cracker. It has made a couple of derisory gestures and that is it. We are prepared to give $50m to those agencies to assist with emergency relief. We are also prepared to give $35m for labour market programs for the disabled. Again, our whole approach is to target those people most in need. Yet this outfit is prepared to say that all those who have managed to get themselves onto the list over the last 10 years can stay there.

We will look at people on disability support pensions on a very restricted basis. We estimate that only about 2 per cent will ever come up for a medical review. It is a nonsense, it is a disgrace, and Senator Richardson knows it. He knows how easy it is to get a medical certificate. In fact, all the incentives are in that direction: for people to go to their local doctor and ask for a certificate, particularly after they have been urged on by the Department of Social Security. That is simply not good enough. There ought to be independent assessments, as the Minister well knows. Quite often, a CMO might not be sufficient. There ought to be a second opinion. There are very many ways and means by which this system can be tightened up. But the answer we received was, `It is all too hard; it is all too expensive; there is no need to do any of this. Even people on 25 per cent are very seriously disabled'. I am surprised that he did not pretend that somehow someone on 15 per cent disability is very severely disabled.

Senator Richardson well knows the number of people who are not declaring income when they have mild to moderate disabilities. He well knows that it is very easy to get these sorts of payments with psychological conditions—conditions which are very difficult to rebut in many instances. The benefit of the doubt ought not to be given except on the basis of at least two medical reports. Functional overlays are notorious, yet there is no recognition from this Minister of that fact at all. Those people who genuinely believe, supposedly, that they have a physical disability that precludes them from working to a level at which, objectively, they are capable of working are not malingering, to use the jargon, but it is getting fairly close.

I would have thought that the very least the Minister ought to be doing is reviewing those people. But, no, we never have any surprise visits; we do not even have mobile review teams out checking in this area. This has been an area of enormous blow-out under this Government. The totality of Senator Richardson's cosmetic changes means that we will not save money, we cannot save money; we are simply prepared to tolerate the status quo. We think that that is condemning these people to second-class citizenship status. Very many of these people would much prefer to be in the work force. They would be able to take advantage of programs such as Austrain, which we are prepared to offer to them. If people have been out of the work force for six or 12 months or longer, as perhaps 300,000 are likely to be under the Minister's status quo arrangements, those people will be able to be offered jobs for less than the award wage for a limited period. Ask the people involved. Do not just ask the mates of those opposite at the Trades Hall Council. Ask the people themselves whether they would be interested in taking jobs at 90 per cent of the award wage for 12 months. They would jump at the opportunity. Ask them if they would be prepared to work for 80 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —If they are in a wheelchair they would find jumping difficult.

—It is pathetic, is it not? Here we have someone pretending that every person on a disability support pension is either in a coma or a wheelchair. Nothing could be further from the truth. As the Minister well knows, if one is over 70 per cent disabled, one is not necessarily a quadriplegic; one is not necessarily in a wheelchair. It is all a matter of judgment. You ought to know, if you apply yourself, that the bulk of people on these pensions are around the 30 to 40 per cent mark. There are many people who are at much lower levels than that. Why, indeed, have you made the impairment cut-off point 20 per cent simply on the basis that a person is unlikely to earn income for two years?
—Order! I ask Senator Alston to direct his remarks to the Chair.

—I apologise, Mr Deputy President. It is a preposterous notion because invalidity is meant to connote long term permanent disablement. Indeed, before the Act was changed, one had to have 85 per cent permanent incapacity. Now we have a system where all that is needed is 20 per cent impairment for a couple of years. Who is doing whom a favour? The Minister can stand up there and pretend that all these people are comatose, do not understand what day it is and do not know which medical door to go through. The Minister can try that line. He can go on spending $2.5 billion a year, throwing money away when it is not necessary, and the end result will be that he cannot afford to give a disability allowance; he cannot afford to give money for special labour market programs for the disadvantaged. Go on doing that, depriving the seriously disabled and benefiting the mild to moderately disabled, and tell us whether that is a fair system. It is the opposite of a fair system.

PARA.TAB: The people who are in need of help are at both ends of the spectrum. Those people who are severely disabled and cannot help themselves ought to be entitled to help from the Government by way of an additional allowance. Those people at the bottom end are not being done a favour by being put on pensions. Those people want jobs. They want to be able to exercise any work force capacity they have instead of it somehow being pretended that they are beyond redemption and that they ought to consign themselves to the scrap heap and pick up a pension or an allowance.

That is what this is all about. It is about the fact that we had the guts to address the people who are in genuine need. You are not prepared to tackle welfare fraud. You never have been. You have never shown the slightest interest—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Alston, you are directing your remarks to the Minister. You should be directing your remarks to the Chair.
—He is being very long-winded, too.

—If ever I have heard the pot calling the kettle black, it is Senator Gareth Evans. I make no apology for what I have said because in this area very high stakes are being played for. I do not want to let pass that Senator Richardson is pretending that somehow we will be requiring people in wheelchairs to come in for medical examinations. If people have a manifest condition of disablement, they will not be required to attend for examination; otherwise we will be requiring a searching examination of all those people who have got on to this system through far too easy administrative procedures about which nothing has been done, despite all the upheaval in the past couple of years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I note Senator Alston's remark in the course of his contribution when he said, `Who is doing whom a favour?'. I think that is what is wrong with this whole debate and what is wrong with the package that Senator Alston

SPEECH.PARA: is pushing. The award of a disability support pension is not about doing anybody a favour; it is about giving those with a severe medical impairment an opportunity for a decent standard of living. That is all it is. It is not about a favour; it is about a civilised society providing for some of its more unfortunate citizens a decent level of income support—nothing more and nothing less.

PARA.TAB: When the disability support changes were put through this Parliament in very recent times, we moved away from 85 per cent incapacity as a means of determining who should be eligible or not eligible for these disability support pensions. We moved to a medical test, a 20 per cent impairment level. That was the test that we set and that is the level a person now has to pass. If a person cannot pass it, he or she will not get such a pension.

We estimated that between a quarter and a third of all new entrants to the system after 12 November would be eligible for some form of rehabilitation, some form of training. The kind of initiative Senator Alston is talking about we already announced in this Parliament months ago; it is already under way. But the real hoax here is the claim that these reviews will get $127m worth of savings. The opportunity for that is nil. This reform will cost money, save nothing, and create misery for hundreds of thousands of people who, by the very nature of their medical impairment, are obviously in pretty severe difficulty to start with.

I do not think Senator Alston has any idea at all of the kinds of disabilities people have when they are on 20 per cent or 30 per cent impairment levels. Most of them tend to be in the 30 per cent to 40 per cent range, and they are people with very severe problems indeed. At 70 per cent, the level quoted in the Opposition document, such people are in very desperate trouble. The idea of those cases getting regularly reviewed is nonsense.

What happens now is a much more sensible and workable proposal. Anyone who has any kind of medical doubt at all about them is scheduled for a review. The information for that will come from their treating doctor, from a Commonwealth medical officer or from a disability review officer in the Department. Where there is any evidence whatever that a person is receiving a payment to which he may not be entitled, he is reviewed now. The idea that one would put in mobile review teams to chase people with these levels of impairment is absolute nonsense.

TALK.START.PARA: —With what levels of impairment?

—You have set the 70 per cent level, you clown. The real problem with mobile review teams is that they only make money if they are targeted on those places where the level of fraud is greatest. The great problem is that that is not here. Senator Alston has just missed the boat. Our medical reviews show a one per cent to 2 per cent rate of being able to get a cancellation of a pension: that is the rate that the Opposition will find when it applies this test. What will happen is that the test will be applied at massive cost and there will be no saving whatever. For no saving all there will be is great misery in the disabled community.

PARA.TAB: I am glad that Senator Alston quoted ACROD and some of the organisations for the disabled because I am going to quote them a hell of a lot in the next few weeks. I am going to quote everything they have to say about this package and about those who have designed it. I am going to quote everything they say about the outrage this is causing in the disabled community, about the misery this will cause the hundreds of thousands of people in this country who deserve, and get at the moment, a whole lot better. This Government will remain committed not just to doing them a favour but also to giving them what every civilised society knows is a right. The real argument I have with this proposal is that the misery does not even produce a dollar; it is just part of a fraudulent package.

As for the $2.5 billion funding for social security, I can assure the Opposition that I will be getting up every single day and taking apart that $2.5 billion. The figure is a joke; it is all wrong. It will be undone before Christmas, and the Opposition will not know where it stands. That is part of the job. The first thing I want to do is refer to those who are being treated the most miserably as a result of this proposal. It is not just the unemployed who might find themselves on no benefit after nine months. If they are able bodied, at least they might have a show, miserable though it might be. We are talking about the weak and the sick, and picking on them is pathetic. That is the only way the Opposition has to go, and it does not even get money out of it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I waited until the Minister sat down, but during his exchange with Senator Alston, he called him a clown. I think that is unparliamentary and you should ask him to withdraw it.
—I thought he said something about `on the town'.
—If I said it, I would certainly withdraw it.
—That was my honest interpretation of what was said. But if that is the case, the Minister should withdraw it.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: AIDEX Exhibition
PETITION.PARA: To the Hon. the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled, the Petition of the undersigned showeth:

PARA.TAB: That the Australian Government is making Australia an active participant in the international arms trade by its official support for the Australian International Defence Exhibition (Aidex 91) to be held in November 1991.
Your Petitioners ask that the Senate should—
request the Government to withdraw all official support and participation from Aidex to regain our international standing as an advocate of disarmament and arms control.

PETITION.TITLE: AIDEX Exhibition
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

We the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully call on the Government to withdraw its endorsement from the arms bazaar, AIDEX 91, scheduled to be held in Canberra, 26 to 28 November 1991, and to ensure that no government department or company takes part in the aforementionede event.

PARA.TAB: And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Road Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

PARA.TAB: Australians living in rural and non-urban areas rely to a great degree on the local road network for all facets of their lives.
Funding for roads is an essential part of the Commonwealth's responsibilities for the maintenance of the transport infrastructure.
Road funding under the Hawke Government has decreased significantly in real terms and local government is particularly disadvantage by this decline.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Immediately address the serious problem of a rapidly deteriorating road network which is confronting local government by allocating more resources to local road funding.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Constitutional Monarchy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that Australia, under its constitutional system based on the Monarchy, is one of the world's most successful democracies. The petitioners note particularly that:
Australia is one of the world's oldest democracies
Australia has led the world in many democratic reforms

PETITION.PARA: Our constitution, based on the Monarchy, has:

PARA.TAB: ensured national independence
maintained national unity in a federation
provided constitutional stability
protected our liberties and freedoms
Your petitioners therefore request that:
Australia should remain a constitutional Monarchy with Her Majesty The Queen of Australia as our head of State.

PETITION.TITLE: AIDEX Exhibition
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: A humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
Attention is drawn to Australia's increasing role in the militarisation of the Pacific region and in particular to the current Government-led arms export drive.

The arms trade is not only detrimental to Australians affected by the diversion of public money away from socially beneficial areas—for example, health, education and social welfare—but is an integral factor in the oppression and poverty of the people of the Third World.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will:
Cease all military aid and training to governments engaged in repression of their own people.
Direct all Federal and State Government Departments and instrumentalities to withdraw from participation in and support for AIDEX and similar arms fairs in Australia and overseas.
Close down AIDEX 1991.
Establish a register of all applications for arms transfers and offset agreements which would be subject to public scrutiny.
Redirect all monies currently being used to promote the arms industry to socially useful research, development and production.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Smokefree International Flights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: We, the undersigned,
(i)are alarmed at the health and safety hazards that arise from the smoking of cigarettes and other tobacco products on international airlines, a dangerous practice banned within Australia;

(ii)call for the International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) of which Australia is a member to set a standard for smokefree international flights; standards set by ICAO must be agreed to by its 162 member nations.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: AIDEX Exhibition
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows the very deep concern of people in the community against the proposed AIDEX exhibition of weapons of war in our country. We firmly believe that it is not in Australia's interest to become dealers in death and destruction. Particularly at this time when our planet's environment is in a parlous condition and demands statesman-like leadership to the world on its rehabilitation. We therefore ask that:

The Exhibition to take place be one which shows instead the ways in which we aim to overcome the dangers to our world from poisoned soil, air and water by high-lighting the need for tree-planting, solar-powered homes, electric cars, etc. as a means of attacking the global warming and other hazards to our fragile environment.
And we, your humble petitioners will as in duty bound, ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I present to the Senate the following petition, from 78 citizens, which is not in conformity with the Standing Orders as it is not in the correct form:

PARA.TAB: We would like to remind you of the promises made at the World Summit for Children in 1990 and those by Prime Minister Hawke for the children of this country.

Also we would like to remind you that children cannot survive or thrive on promises. We ask you as one of our elected leaders to see that you make every possible effort to give the needs of the worlds children top priority and help to translate these hopes and promises into reality.
We have listed below these promises which we learnt about at an Activity and Workshop day called "PUTTING CHILDREN FIRST" held at Sacred Heart College on October 25th, 1991.
At the World Summit you promised
To cut down the child deaths by 1/3 before the year 2000
To cut down maternal death rates by half by the year 2000
To reduce severe and moderate malnutrition of children by 1/2 of the 1990 level
Politicians set a goal to provide access to clean water and sanitation for all families
To give basic education available to all and at least 80% completion of primary school
To provide education for at least half of uneducated (illiterate) adults, especially women
Children will have protection in situations of armed conflict.
