DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the time for the presentation of the report of the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on relations between Australia and the republics of Latin America be extended to 30 April 1992. (Notice given 26 November 1991)

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to make a brief statement relating to the notice of motion I have just given.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 9 April 1991 the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade was instructed by the Senate to inquire into Australia's relations with the republics of Latin America. As the Committee embarked on the inquiry it quickly became evident that Latin America had been seriously neglected as an area of opportunity. The Committee has cast its net wide in order to bring together a comprehensive range of facts, views and attitudes on the relationship.

PARA.TAB: Information on various aspects of the relationship is scattered and not always easy to access. Both in parts of the bureaucracy and in the private sector, thinking about Latin America has, with a few notable exceptions, been relegated either to the low priority area or to the too hard basket. Therefore, it is not surprising that the Committee feels that it has some way to go before it will be in a position to form useful conclusions about Australia's relations with Latin America.

So far the Committee has received 114 submissions. A number of substantive submissions have been received only recently or are expected to be received in the coming weeks. Public hearings have been held on at least two occasions in Canberra, twice in Sydney, and in Melbourne and Brisbane. Further hearings are planned for Canberra and Adelaide.
The original terms of reference require the Committee to report by 30 November 1991. It is the view of the Committee that it needs more time to do justice to the task set by the Senate.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that the President has received the following letter, dated 26 November, from Senator Bourne and Senator Vallentine:

PARA.TAB: Dear Mr President,
Pursuant to Standing Order 75, we give notice that today we propose to move:
'That in the opinion of the Senate the following is a matter of urgency:

INTERJECT.PARA: The need for the Australian Government:
(a)to immediately send a fact finding delegation to East Timor to investigate the Dili massacre;
(b)to reassess Australian military aid and defence equipment exports to Indonesia;
(c)to move that the United Nations facilitate talks between all parties on the future of East Timor;
(d)to request, in the strongest possible terms, that Indonesia agree to and facilitate all of the above.'

PARA.TAB: New South WalesWestern Australia

INTERJECT.PARA: I understand that informal arrangements have been made to limit the debate to 1 1/2 hours. Is the proposal supported?

TAB.EMPHASIS: More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Vallentine and on my own behalf, I move:

PARA.TAB: That in the opinion of the Senate the following is a matter of urgency:
The need for the Australian Government:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)to immediately send a fact finding delegation to East Timor to investigate the Dili massacre;
(b)to reassess Australian military aid and defence equipment exports to Indonesia;
(c)to move that the United Nations facilitate talks between all parties on the future of East Timor;
(d)to request, in the strongest possible terms, that Indonesia agree to and facilitate all of the above.

According to Amnesty International, between 50 and 100 people were killed and scores were wounded when Indonesian security forces opened fire on a group of mourners at Santa Cruz cemetery in Dili, East Timor, at about 8 a.m. on 12 November 1991. Dozens of others, including two foreign journalists, were beaten during the incident. At least 42 people, and possibly many more, have been detained. The victims were among hundreds of people who had gone to the grave of Sebastiao Gomes Rangel, a young man killed on 28 October when Indonesian troops entered the parish church of Motael, Dili, where he and about 20 other political activists had been hiding.

PARA.TAB: Eyewitnesses said that the procession was peaceful, although some members of the group had shouted pro-independence slogans and a flag of the nationalist movement Fretilin had been seen. Security forces, many of them carrying long sticks or truncheons, were in evidence along the route to the cemetery. However, with the exception of a brief scuffle between soldiers and young men at the tail end of the procession, no clashes and no physical confrontations were reported by non-governmental sources. According to one eyewitness account, a scuffle began near the Hotel Resende when a small number of soldiers ran after members of the procession and beat them with truncheons. The marchers retaliated by throwing stones and shouting, but no injuries were reported.

The shooting took place five to 10 minutes after the crowd had reached the cemetery. Some banners had been hung, people talked among themselves, and a number shouted pro-independence slogans. At this point, a large contingent of armed soldiers arrived from two different directions. Eyewitnesses said that hundreds of soldiers carrying M16 automatic weapons approached the cemetery on foot from one direction, while a smaller group—possibly of the paramilitary police mobile brigade—arrived in trucks from another direction.

According to eyewitnesses, the foot soldiers marched to the entrance of the cemetery, formed a line about 12 men abreast, then opened fire on the crowd. No warning was given. Some soldiers reportedly fired into the air first, but others levelled their weapons straight at the crowd. The walls of the cemetery and the large number of people made it difficult to escape, but the shooting continued even as people tried to flee. Some were believed to have been shot in the back while running away. The shooting stopped and resumed several times, suggesting that it was planned and deliberate, rather than a spontaneous reaction to provocation. One eyewitness said:
Looking down the road I saw body after body, and the soldiers kept firing at those who were still standing.

SPEECH.PARA: Amnesty International reports that other estimates of the number killed varied between 50 and 180. An Indonesian military spokesman said initially that fewer than 100 had died, but on 14 November the Government announced that `only 19' had been killed. Among those reported to have died of gunshot wounds was a student from New Zealand, Kamal Bamadhaj. Dozens of people were said to have been beaten badly during the incident, among them two US journalists, Alan Nairn and Amy Goodman. Anyone who heard Amy Goodman describe the massacre on the AM radio program would not soon forget the broadcast.

PARA.TAB: The written word is a powerful tool, but the spoken words of an eyewitness are far stronger. The strongest and most shocking evidence of the massacre was the television footage taken by Max Stahl of Yorkshire Television. It is very distressing to read of people being killed; it is devastating actually to watch someone dying of appalling abdominal wounds.

There is considerable evidence that the Indonesian military is quite unrepentant about the incident. They have expressed official regret at the deaths and promised to investigate. On the one hand they have attempted to justify the massacre by claiming that security forces had used force when attacked by rioters, while on the other hand the commander in chief of the Indonesian armed forces, General Try Sutrisno, has been quoted in the Jayakarta newspaper as saying, `These ill-bred people have to be shot'. I will quote a little from the translated article:

SPEECH.PARA: `Our armed forces are not like armies in other countries. Our people's army is very tactful.'

PARA.TAB: It turns out, the four-star general continued, that the patience shown by our officers was not appreciated; on the contrary, the disruptors became even more brutal. Then, some shots were fired into the air. `But they persisted with their misdeeds,' he said.
General Try Soetrisno then said that ABRI—

SPEECH.PARA: the armed forces—
would never allow itself to be ignored. `In the end, they had to be shot,' he said, reiterating his words that such disruptors had to be shot. `And we shall shoot them,' . . .

PARA.TAB: The commander-in-chief called on the public not to panic, not to be influenced and to remain confident in ABRI's ability to resolve everything. `ABRI is determined to crush anyone who disrupts stability.'

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats, since the inception of the Party, have been consistently and loudly opposed to the Indonesian invasion and incorporation of East Timor in 1975. My predecessor in this place and my good friend, Colin Mason, constantly raised the matter in the Senate but received little support at the time. I am very encouraged by the outrage being expressed by so many groups and individuals, not only in Australia but throughout the world, over this massacre. There is a growing surge of activity in the European Parliament, the Netherlands, the USA, the UK, Portugal, Sweden, Canada and New Zealand. Australia must actively support cooperative international action.

PARA.TAB: The Dili massacre has been a turning point in that it is simply no longer possible for the international community or our own Government to act as if the human rights situation in East Timor has been or is being resolved. While the events of 12 November represent the single most appalling tragedy in recent years, they are consistent with the pattern of abuse that has been inflicted on East Timor by the Indonesian authorities since 1975. The policy of successive Australian governments with respect to Indonesia may have produced dividends in some respects but it has clearly failed to offer any adequate or enduring protection for the rights of the Timorese people. Australian foreign policy in this respect must be reappraised as a matter of urgency. One key aspect of this must be a recognition that UN involvement is essential if genuine and lasting recognition of the rights of the Timorese people is to be achieved.

I believe that the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) will be moving an amendment to this urgency motion. In many respects it is a good, strong motion, although I do not believe it goes far enough in relation to military transfers or to Australia's role in the United Nations in bringing about a final resolution to the problems of East Timor. Indonesia has no historic, cultural or ethnic claim on East Timor. Indonesia is a close neighbour and, we are told, a friend of Australia's. One does not let one's friends murder their neighbours or their children. One does not let one's friends do things that are against their best interests. It is in everyone's best interests—Indonesians and East Timorese alike—for East Timor to be allowed self-determination.

We are encouraged by the support for East Timor shown by so many in the Australian community, including members of all political parties. The Australian Catholic Bishops Committee for Justice, Development and Peace has called on the Australian Government:

to move in the United Nations General Assembly, currently in session, that Indonesia's action against people assembled at the Santa Cruz cemetery be investigated without delay by representatives of the UN Commission on Human Rights;
to move that Indonesia's membership of the Commission be suspended until the UN investigation into the Santa Cruz incident is completed; and

to move that a United Nations-sponsored plebiscite be conducted to determine the wishes of the East Timorese people, with the option of independence being available to East Timor should the people vote for it.

SPEECH.PARA: Community Aid Abroad has urged the Government to adopt the following four point action plan: first, to support the sending of a United Nations force to protect East Timorese civilians; second, to dispatch immediately Foreign Minister Evans to Jakarta and Dili to facilitate talks between all concerned parties, including the Indonesian Government, Fretilin and the church; third, to suspend all military aid and defence equipment exports to Indonesia until the satisfactory commencement of such talks; and, fourth, to postpone the impending visit of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to Indonesia until the satisfactory commencement of such talks.

PARA.TAB: Amnesty International is calling for an immediate and impartial investigation into the circumstances of the massacre at Santa Cruz, and for guarantees that those responsible for extrajudicial executions or for the ill treatment of prisoners will be brought promptly to justice. It believes that investigations must be carried out by an independent body with no link to the security forces allegedly responsible for the massacre. It urges the Indonesian authorities to permit an investigation to be carried out under the auspices of a recognised international body, such as the United Nations Special Rapporteur on Summary or Arbitrary Executions. Amnesty International is also seriously concerned for the safety of those arrested and is urging that those detained solely for their non-violent political activities or beliefs be immediately released and that, following their release, their safety be guaranteed.

What we are seeking in this urgency motion is achievable. It represents the minimum of what we believe should reasonably be done by any civilised country in response not only to this quite appalling massacre but also to 16 years of consistent, brutal human rights abuses in East Timor. I commend the motion to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —What happened on 12 November in Dili was brutal and unconscionable. There may have been some provocation for a violent military response—in particular, the apparent stabbing of a battalion deputy commander and a private soldier early in the course of the demonstration—but on no version of the events which took place, not even the most extreme military version, could the degree of force that was clearly used on this occasion possibly be justified.

PARA.TAB: The course of events and the scale of the deaths and injuries associated with them is still not clear. The deaths are best estimated on the available evidence we have at around 75, plus or minus—certainly more than the 19 that have been acknowledged to date by the military authorities. As to the wounded, we now know that there are 89 people in hospital, but there are a number of others wounded who are still in hiding, and the death toll may rise as a result. At least the International Committee of the Red Cross has, in the last 24 hours, had access to those wounded in hospital and to those 47 people who are still in military detention as a result of the demonstration. That is to be welcomed.

It has to be said that there is no evidence that there was any deliberate or calculated decision or action of government involved in the conduct of this particular massacre, unlike the Tiananmen Square incident in China, where manifestly what happened was the result of a deliberate and calculated act of state policy. It does rather seem to have been aberrant behaviour by a particular group within the military. Whether that is the case will, of course, hopefully become clearer in the course of the investigation which is now under way. But our assessment of the situation, as being properly described in these terms, obviously does affect the nature of the response that the Australian Government has made to this situation as it has unfolded.

The Indonesian Government's reaction was initially very defensive. It also extended to an extraordinary and indefensible statement from the military commander-in-chief, to which Senator Bourne has already made reference. But it also has to be acknowledged that more recent statements issued after the first day have been more sensitive and more willing to acknowledge the enormity of the situation. In particular, we now have the presidential decree establishing the national commission of investigation—a really quite unprecedented thing to occur in Indonesian experience and a precedent that we of course welcome very much.

At this stage there is no reason to assume that that national commission of investigation will not produce an inquiry which is, in the language of the presidential decree itself, `free, accurate, just and thorough'. We certainly hope it is, but we will have to wait and see.

The international reaction to the events in Dili has been strong—probably in no other country stronger than in Australia, which is understandable given the long history of concern with this issue at all levels of the Australian community and on both sides of the Parliament. But clear and unequivocal statements have been emerging from the European Community, the United States Congress and a number of other countries. A number of countries have communicated their concerns more privately than publicly, but the reality of that concern has been no less for that. Clearly, this weighed upon the Indonesian Government in coming to its welcome decision to establish a full and proper inquiry.

The Australian Government's reaction was clearly articulated by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) during my absence overseas. It involved us seeking clear expressions of regret from the Indonesian Government, which have now, of course, been forthcoming. It involved seeking that a full and fair inquiry be conducted into all the circumstances of the massacre and, as I have said, that is now under way. We have also made it clear that we regard it as absolutely necessary that there be an appropriate follow-up involving appropriate treatment or punishment of those found guilty of unlawful or excessive conduct.

The Prime Minister, on behalf of the Australian Government, has also made it clear that, beyond that response to the 12 November events themselves, we believe there needs to be a new approach to reconciliation with the East Timor people involving, as the Prime Minister put it, sitting down with the East Timor people—including the resistance forces—and trying to work out a program for achieving peaceable relations.

The options that confront the Government in terms of the current situation are, essentially, either negative or positive in character. We did have available to us a number of negative options and they have been vigorously pressed upon us by a number of lobby groups and individual parliamentarians. They basically involve action being taken to demonstrate concern, abhorrence and hostility at what has happened on the part of the Australian Government or people—measures such as the cancellation of ministerial visits, the cancellation of aid programs and the cancellation of the kind of cooperative military activity which does presently take place; matters of that kind.

However, the Government's position—as I have already indicated at Question Time—is that we believe such measures as this are quite premature to contemplate at this stage, given the embarking by the Indonesian Government on the course of investigation that we have urged upon it. It would be utterly at odds with that course of action for us to cut across the bilateral relationship and to make assumptions of guilt on the part of the Government, as it were, by putting in place negative measures of that kind.

There is always a question as to whether measures of that kind will be, or are, productive or counterproductive for the people we are trying most to assist—in this case, the East Timorese. There is always a question as to whether such measures are in Australia's larger national interest. Given the course of the relationship and the significance of that relationship, not only to us but also in terms of multilateral cooperation on issues such as Cambodia and the establishment of APEC, there is always a question as to whether it makes any sense to deliberately embark upon a course of breaking down bilateral relations as an expression of protest.

We do not need to address those questions at this stage. It is not appropriate to be thinking about any such measures. Nonetheless, in the Government's judgment it is appropriate to be thinking about some more positive measures which can be taken at this stage: measures designed to encourage the effectiveness of the investigation process now under way and to achieve a longer term resolution and reconciliation of the Timorese conflict in a way which meets the needs and aspirations of the Timorese people.

Some people will say the only thing that could possibly meet the needs and aspirations of the East Timorese people would be the independence of East Timor following a UN-supervised act of self-determination and, presumably, a vote to that effect. That is probably too narrow a view of the situation. There is evidence, and quite a deal of evidence had been accumulating over the years before this incident, that a great many East Timorese people, perhaps a majority, would be content to have a society which involved them living in peace without an omnipresent military authority; which involved them being able to exercise rights of free speech and association; and which involved them being able to freely practise their religion—they are predominantly Catholic—and to exercise cultural freedom and independence, and gave them a measure of economic opportunity and support.

This was the course of action on which we believed the Indonesian Government was genuinely embarked in order to produce, over time, that kind of society in East Timor. The tragedy of the events of 12 November is that it so comprehensively put at risk the achievement—peacefully and within a reasonable timeframe—of the confident support of the East Timorese people for that kind of situation. We believe—and Australian policy has been firmly embedded in this particular course since 1979—that the only realistic future for the East Timorese people does lie with their acceptance of Indonesian sovereignty. In the mid-1970s we made very clear our opposition to the circumstances of the Indonesian takeover. In innumerable statements since I have made it perfectly clear that I have not changed my own personal view that what happened in 1975 was indefensible.

The world inevitably, and sometimes unfortunately, moves on. Things which appear to be realistically achievable at one time become less so over time. The truth of the matter has been that the international community, from the late 1970s onward, lost interest in East Timor, and the prospect of achieving the process of self-determination, which was so widely called for in the mid-1970s, is probably no longer realistic.

It may be that the events of 12 November will change all that in terms of the international reaction but, on the evidence so far, I honestly do not think that is the case. I believe it makes more sense to operate within the framework of an acknowledgment of that reality which we have accepted on both sides of politics since 1979 and to try to improve the conditions of the East Timorese people within that framework.

There are some constructive things we can do, both in respect of improving the conditions of the people in the aftermath of the 12 November incident and also, as I have said, encouraging the investigation to be conducted effectively. Those things include, perhaps, a visit to Indonesia by me as Foreign Minister within the next few weeks, in recognition that diplomatic dialogue is likely to be a more productive way of achieving results than any available alternative course of action at this stage, particularly given the nature of the relationship and the degree of diplomatic capital, if you like, which has accumulated as a consequence of the good state of those relations in recent years.

The second course that might be possible for us to take constructively is the exploration of a possible role for the United Nations, or more particularly its Secretary-General, in encouraging these developments. At the present time, there are problems—procedural and otherwise—in seeking any action in the General Assembly or in the Third or Fourth Committee or the UN Human Rights Commission. A more realistic approach in this respect would seem to be the utilisation of the good offices role of the Secretary-General, which is something we have publicly supported in the past and which the Indonesian Government has been prepared to accept.

Another constructive thing we can do is to support actively the role of the Red Cross as a permanent monitoring presence, possibly by way of targeted financial assistance. The Red Cross has been playing a very important role in recent days in putting pressure on the Indonesian authorities to make information available, with some results which I indicated earlier suggesting that that cooperation is now more forthcoming.

Finally, it is proposed that, as a constructive measure, we seek the establishment of an Australian consulate in Dili. It will, of course, depend on the Indonesian authorities as to whether that can go ahead, but it will be an important permanent presence in the province if it is able to be secured, with advantages flowing fairly obviously from that.

Our attitude to the motion moved by Senator Bourne is reflected in what I have just said. In some ways we think the motion goes a little far in talking in terms of immediately sending fact-finding delegations to East Timor to investigate the Dili massacre. I think that is both unrealistic and unwarranted in terms of the action that is taking place now under the auspices of the Indonesian Government. I add, however, that the Australian Embassy has had people on the ground there for most of the period since the massacre, and the Australian Ambassador proposes to make early and regular visits to East Timor with this sort of thing in mind. Similarly with the reference to the UN facilitating talks, that may be a little more ambitious than is achievable or necessarily desirable at this immediate stage.

The basic point I make about the motion is that we believe it is possible to say rather more than has been said by Senator Bourne and Senator Vallentine in their motion and to say it in a way that generates some of the balance I have been trying to put into the remarks I have just put on the record—the balance as between recognising the steps that have been taken, using language that makes unequivocally clear our condemnation of what has occurred, language that suggests that a rethinking of some aspects of Australian policy may well be justified if that investigation does not proceed satisfactorily, and language that identifies some of the constructive steps I have just spelt out. A weakness of the Opposition's foreshadowed amendment is that it goes only very selectively to the subject matter I have just described. In particular, it falls short of addressing both the constructive measures and what might appropriately happen in the event that the investigation is not satisfactorily conducted.

I urge that the Senate adopt the amendment I shall seek to move using the procedures of this place. I make it clear for the record that this amendment has been adopted by the Labor Party room this morning and will be moved as a separate motion in the House of Representatives in another debate today. In terms of stating a clear consensus position, hopefully, across the parliamentary chambers, it would be useful to have this amendment adopted.
I conclude by seeking leave to move an amendment to the urgency motion, the effect of which would be to substitute a substantive motion for the urgency motion in the terms that have been circulated.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: Omit all words after "That" substitute:

SPEECH.PARA: "the Senate
(a)expresses its deepest sympathy to the people of East Timor for the appalling tragedy they experienced with the Dili massacre of 12 November 1991;
(b)condemns in the strongest terms the resort by the Indonesian military to force which on every account was wholly excessive;
(c)regards as deeply repugnant the reported comments of the Indonesian Commander-in-Chief on the day following the massacre that the "disruptors . . . had to be shot";

(d)notes the Indonesian Government's decision to establish a National Commission of Investigation to investigate all aspects of the massacre, and calls upon it to take every necessary step to ensure to the satisfaction of both the East Timorese and international communities:

TAB.TAB: (i)that the inquiry is "free, accurate, just and thorough", as promised;
(ii)that it is conducted fairly and impartially, with all witnesses guaranteed protection against intimidation or retaliation; and
(iii)that appropriate action is taken against those found to be responsible for unlawful or excessive acts;

SPEECH.PARA: (e)further calls upon the Indonesian Government:

TAB.TAB: (i)to provide immediate access by humanitarian and aid groups, especially the International Committee of the Red Cross, to those wounded or detained as a result of the events of 12 November and other recent incidents in East Timor, without any prejudice to those so visited;
(ii)to respond promptly to requests for information in relation to detained or missing persons about whom concern has been expressed following the events of 12 November and other recent incidents;
(iii)to release all political prisoners detained because of their opposition to the integration of East Timor with Indonesia; and
(iv)to guarantee that individuals who express peaceful opposition to the integration of East Timor with Indonesia are free from intimidation, harassment or detention;

SPEECH.PARA: (f)requests the Government to instruct the Australian Ambassador to Indonesia to make an early visit, and subsequently regular visits, to East Timor to report fully on all aspects of the present situation and the progress of the National Commission of Investigation;

(g)requests the Australian Government, having regard to the full range of its policies toward and bilateral contacts with Indonesia, to give consideration to the steps which it might take to review these policies and contacts in the event that the Indonesian investigation and follow-up action is unsatisfactory, for example the suspension of military training programs;

(h)notes the importance of any Australian Government response to the 12 November massacre not only reflecting the deep concern of the wider Australian community but also being consistent with Australia's own national interests and above all with the interests and welfare of the East Timorese people;
(j)calls, accordingly, upon the Government to explore all possible constructive avenues for

TAB.TAB: (i)guaranteeing the effectiveness of the investigation process and its follow-up;

(ii)achieving a peaceful resolution of the on-going conflict, including by requesting the Indonesian Government, in the Prime Minister's words, to "sit down with the people of East Timor including the resistance forces and try and work out a program of achieving peaceable relations"; and
(iii)meeting the longer-term needs and aspirations of the East Timorese people; and

SPEECH.PARA: (k)in particular in these respects, the Senate requests that:

TAB.TAB: (i)the Foreign Minister make an early visit to Indonesia to discuss all aspects of the East Timor situation, including the events of 12 November and options for effective longer-term reconciliation;
(ii)active steps be taken to explore the role which might now be played, with wide international support, by the United Nations and its Secretary General;

(iii)strong support be given to the role of the International Commission of the Red Cross in protecting and promoting human rights in East Timor, through continued representations to the Indonesian authorities and if possible targeted financial assistance; and
(iv) approval be sought for the establishment of a resident Australian Consulate in Dili.".

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a great deal of common sentiment in the chamber this afternoon in relation to this issue. We join with the Australian Democrats and the Government in expressing our deepest distress over the incident in East Timor on 12 November 1991, which is the subject of this motion. Not only do we express our deepest sympathy for those who died, we think also of those who were injured and are presently hospitalised and of the families who have lost relatives in this tragic event.

PARA.TAB: I do not wish to debate the facts because they are only partly known at this time. They will become more apparent as time proceeds. They were put, in a form, by the Democrats' spokesman this afternoon. From my observation of the film to which she referred, which was taken by Yorkshire Television, there was obviously a lot that was valid in her description. In that film I saw a large number of rather excited young people waving banners for self-determination and independence. I saw no signs of an angry crowd and no signs of violence on the part of the protesters, who were at that time marching from the church where they had had a ceremony in memory of one of their colleagues who had died about a fortnight before in circumstances which are still not totally known. They were marching to his grave.

As the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) said, there are suggestions that an Indonesian major may have been stabbed during that march, but the incident in which it seems that the Indonesian armed forces opened fire on the crowd occurred some considerable time later. There does not seem to be, as the Minister said, any evidence on the table that would in any way amount to provocation to justify the incredibly heavy-handed reaction of the Indonesian armed forces. This is a tragic event that should never have occurred, and a lot of innocent young people have lost their lives as a result of it.

How should a country such as ours, which I think I can fairly say has a very different value base, react to such distressing circumstances? There is an issue of self-determination involved in this matter, of course, but we have not seen this violent act in such terms. We have seen this violent act primarily as an incident of what seems to be gross human rights abuse. The cause of the demonstration or the cause for this group of students joining together does not seem to us to be particularly relevant. What is important is that students reacting or protesting or taking other non-violent action should be entitled to do so without having to suffer the reaction of armed forces opening fire upon them.

Our attitude would have been the same, whether this incident had occurred in Indonesia or anywhere else in the world. We have hopefully moved into what some are describing as a new world order in which justice prevails and in which we have an international community more willing to comply with the international standards of human rights that have been now agreed. On the facts that we have before us so far relating to this incident, it would seem to be a gross abuse of the minimum standards that the international community has set.

Because it is an international issue, it gives us as Australians the right and the responsibility to protest way beyond anything that concerns bilateral matters. Regrettably, Indonesia—as we saw with China and as we see with some other countries—still seeks to regard such matters as internal matters. We press the same point upon Indonesia as we pressed upon China: these incidents can no longer be regarded as internal matters, domestic matters; they are matters of international concern in which the international community has a right and a responsibility to act.

What, therefore, should Australia do? What form of protest might most effectively reduce the chance of such a terrible event recurring? We are pleased about one aspect and that is that the Indonesian Government seems to have responded in this instance somewhat differently from its response to not dissimilar tragedies in the past. In this instance it has said that it deeply regrets the incident and the loss of life and that it will conduct a comprehensive investigation of all aspects of the incident. It has said that anyone `proven to have violated the prevailing laws' will be charged and tried in accordance with Indonesian law.

The Indonesian Government has set up a national committee of investigation to carry out this inquiry, which is, as the Minister said and I agree, of an entirely unprecedented stature, to be headed by a Supreme Court judge with members drawn from the Ministries of Foreign Affairs, Home Affairs and Justice, the Parliament and the armed forces.

It demonstrates, I think, that the Indonesian Government sees that it does have a responsibility in this instance to properly investigate what occurred and to take appropriate action. We, of course, have pressed upon the Indonesian Government that such an inquiry should be open and free and that its deliberations should be in public; that its results should be made public; and that the Indonesian Government should bring criminal action against those who have demonstrated to have been in breach of the law. Only by such action will the Indonesian Government demonstrate to the international community that it is prepared to comply with what I described as the minimum standards of human rights which we are all now prepared to accept. The Governor of East Timor has been outspoken on the incident and has said that he will resign if the results of the investigations are not objective. I commend him for his courage in that regard.

The fact that it should be an open and free inquiry is something which I took to the Indonesian Ambassador in Canberra last week. As I put to him, the Australian-Indonesian relationship is an important one. It will be severely soured by events such as this. It is in the interests of Indonesia that it demonstrate to the world that it will conduct an open, free and fair inquiry to get to the bottom of this tragedy.

I understand from the Minister, Senator Evans, that he is of a mind to travel to Indonesia to put a similar point of view. If that is the case, we acknowledge that the sentiment is similar to that which we put to Indonesia's representative in Canberra last week. I am reminded of the fact that in 1975, after the Indonesian invasion, Andrew Peacock, the then Foreign Minister, on two occasions visited Jakarta to protest about the events that had occurred.

I must say that other visits are much more tricky, because it is very important that we do not send the wrong message to Indonesia. I have uttered words of caution regarding the visit of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) which, of course, was designed to be a goodwill visit. I think that the visit should very much depend on the conduct and the action taken by the Indonesian Government through its committee of inquiry.

That brings me to the motion before the Senate today. I am concerned about aspects of the motion moved by the Australian Democrats and Senator Vallentine, because it seems to take the issue a step further. I do not think that sending a delegation from Australia will help the issue at the moment. I do not think reassessing our relationship in terms of aid or defence cooperation at this time will help in the issue. I do not believe that bringing the United Nations into it will assist either. I think the important thing is to maintain the pressure upon the Indonesian Government, which has the first responsibility to act in these circumstances to ensure that it carries out the open inquiry that I have referred to and takes the proper disciplinary action that might become apparent according to the findings of that inquiry.

I now move to the amendment that has been put by the Government which, as the Minister said, adopts the terms of a Caucus resolution which was passed this morning. Again, I am concerned by aspects of that resolution, because it also seems to me to go beyond that which is helpful at the moment. With regard to the first half of the resolution, which is put to us as the Government's amendment, I do not have a great deal of difficulty. I make just a few amended changes that I will mention in a moment. But the second half seems to raise the issue of self-determination, which I believe is unhelpful at this time. I notice that the proponents of that motion in this morning's Caucus have in fact gone to the press and said that it intended to be interpreted in those terms. They have put to the press that the language means a major change in the Australian Government's position in relation to East Timor. They said particularly that it should be interpreted as demonstrating support for self-determination. Senator Evans put it to us this afternoon that that is not the way in which it is to be interpreted, so we have a confused situation with the sponsors of the motion interpreting it one way and Senator Evans interpreting it another.

At the very least, it seems to me that parts (g) through to (j) in the Minister's motion are premature. They raise matters that really prejudge the issues that are before the committee of inquiry. In some ways they are also repetitious in picking up earlier parts of the motion. They are also, in their language, somewhat confusing, which I suspect comes out of the debate that took place in Caucus. I therefore think, on balance, that it would be unhelpful to include them within the motion that the Senate will adopt.

I would not wish it to be interpreted that by taking that attitude I am opposed to everything in the second half of the motion. In fact, I see that there is a suggestion for an Australian consulate in Dili, which I think might be quite helpful, bearing in mind particularly the close relationship with the East Timorese community in Darwin, which my colleague Senator Tambling will refer to.

I have incorporated the first half of the motion in the terms of our amendment. The change I seek to make is really in relation to the third part—to delete clause (c)—because I think the issue of what General Try Sutrisno said is something that needs further clarification. I have seen several interpretations of what he said and I would not wish to be part of a motion condemning him without being certain of what he said and that it was, therefore, something that should be condemned. I think that is therefore premature. The issue of political prisoners is one that is always debatable and I preferred to use the language of a call to release all prisoners detained without trial. I have made that change also in our amendment.

We see some merit in the Australian Ambassador visiting East Timor in order to better inform the Australian Government. I think what is important is that the Australian Government keep the Parliament properly informed of the progress of the national commission of investigation; in other words, that the material the Government gets as a result of his visits is properly brought to our attention in order that we, as the people's representatives in this country, might take the appropriate action.

I will, therefore, move the amendment that I have circulated to the Government's amendment to the Australian Democrats' motion. I urge the Senate to adopt our wording because it keeps pressure on the Indonesian Government, where it is most appropriate at this time, without introducing other matters that will only confuse the debate and without prejudging the determination of the Indonesian Government's committee of inquiry. I move:
Omit paragraphs (c), and (g) to (k) inclusive; and omit (b), (e)(iii), and (f), substitute the following paragraphs:
"(b)condemns in the strongest terms the resort by the Indonesian military to excessive force;
(e)(iii)to release all prisoners detained without trial;

(f)requests the Government to instruct the Australian Ambassador to Indonesia to make an early visit, and subsequently regular visits, to East Timor and to report fully to Parliament on all aspects of the present situation and the progress of the National Commission of Investigation.".

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to express my heartfelt and deepest sympathy to the relatives of the victims of the Dili massacre and to those who have been wounded as a result of the actions of ABRI elements in Dili. I also rise as a member of the Australian-Indonesian Parliamentary Friendship Group to express my great disappointment at what has occurred in Dili. For many years I have been a strong and long-standing friend of Indonesia—since my first visit to that country in, I think, 1965. I am fully well aware of the struggles of that country and its people for independence. On the very day that the massacre was reported in Australia, I gave notice of the following motion in the Senate:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)expresses outrage at the reported massacre by Indonesian security forces of dozens of East Timorese people in or adjacent to the Santa Cruz Cemetery in Dili on 12 November 1991; and
(b)calls upon the Australian Government to:

TAB.TAB: (i)continue to insist that the Indonesian authorities give a full account and explanation of this massacre in an area of intense interest and concern to the people of Australia, and
(ii)register Australia's protest in the strongest possible terms.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Acting Deputy President, as you know, that motion was carried unanimously by the Senate.

PARA.TAB: I am concerned also that this event took place at a time when there was developing an improvement in the relationships in that area. I believe that there was a deliberate attempt by key Indonesians in East Timor to quieten things down, to ensure that people were able to go about their business with greater freedom.

Only time will tell what exactly happened on that fateful day. But we do need to get at the truth. We need to ensure that this is done openly and fully. We need to ensure that there are no scapegoats—whether they be individuals high up in the military establishment who may not have been directly involved or whether they be what the Indonesian security forces call gerakan pengacau keamanan; that is to say, security disturbing movements.

We do not want to have a repeat of the excuses given by the Indonesian authorities about the killing of two youths in Dili on 28 October. The Indonesian news magazine Tempo reported the week after that the Government took the view that the deaths of the two students were the result of actions by rival gangs of youths. Reports outside Indonesia indicated that the victims were shot by security forces. I am concerned that the Australian Government was not able to answer why those two youths were shot. I commend the Government for its proposal to make sure that greater attention is paid by our embassy in Jakarta to the situation in East Timor.

Again, what has happened to the truth in regard to the Dili disaster? The immediate response by Indonesia to the massacre was to claim that only 19 people were killed. It was claimed that the killings occurred because soldiers misheard an order not to fire, and that it was a misunderstanding. We now know that eyewitness reports, video footage and even the reported remarks of the ABRI chief of staff, Try Sutrisno, bear out the fallacy of that initial pathetic claim.

We also know that quite a number of people in Jakarta have been arrested since the massacre. It has been suggested that those people have been released. However, information that is available indicates that is not so, that they have been carted away and that many of them have not been released.

We really do need to find out the truth. As friends, Indonesia and Australia need to be able to trust each other and share the truth with each other. The first element of trust is openness and truthfulness between two friends. I believe that is what is needed more than anything else right here and now.

The question is whether the national commission of investigation is able to arrive at the truth. I note that the chairman of the national commission, Judge Jaelani, served in several military units in West Java, including as commander of the army's paracommando regiment in Batujajar in Bandung in the 1950s. That does not disqualify him from being chairman of this commission obviously, nor does it disqualify him from being a supreme court judge. But, it might—as with some of the other members on the committee—prevent many of the East Timorese from presenting themselves before the commission with full confidence. However, it is absolutely essential that this should happen if we are to arrive at the truth.

That is why I am interested in the Government's proposal which indicates a role for the United Nations and its Secretary-General, and the International Commission of the Red Cross in regard to matters relating to human rights violations. I believe that it would be in Indonesia's interests and, indeed, in our own interests for this inquiry to be undertaken by, say, an international organisation such as the United Nations Commission on Human Rights or by the International Commission of Jurists. Clearly, that would serve our joint interest in arriving at the truth.

We need to look at the idea of cooperative conflict resolutions in this field because we have common security interests as well as many other interests. My view is that this inquiry would be better undertaken by an internationally respected body. Not that I reflect on the members of the commission. All I am saying is that I do not believe many of the East Timorese would feel confident in going before that body. If they are not confident in doing that, the Indonesians, ourselves and the world will not ultimately arrive at the truth of this tragic affair.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to indicate my support for the viewpoints expressed in particular in the amendment moved by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Gareth Evans. I take some responsibility for a significant part of that amendment as I, Mr Gibson and Senator Sherry were involved in the negotiations which resulted in this document going to the Labor Party Caucus this morning where it was unanimously accepted. Basically I think it is fair to say that it looks at the short term and the long term. It expresses the repugnance and horror about the massacre felt by all members in this chamber, and it makes that repugnance and horror absolutely obvious to the Indonesian Government, and particularly to those responsible.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, it sets out a step by step approach to the way in which we should be dealing with the Jakarta Government, particularly over matters relating to human rights and to East Timor. The step by step procedure that we have outlined in the amendment by Senator Gareth Evans that we drafted last night is an attempt to ensure that cooler heads prevail and that the long term relationships that we have with our near neighbours, especially Indonesia, are improved. But more importantly, it is an attempt to ensure that they are improved on the basis that our neighbours have a full understanding as to where we stand on matters relating to human rights, on prisoners detained without trial, prisoners who are tortured in Indonesian gaols and on summary execution; and in particular to the way that we view the rights of the citizens of East Timor. That concern is expressed very adequately indeed in the amendment moved by Senator Gareth Evans, which was contained in a series of motions and steps passed by the Labor Party Caucus this morning.

I think that nobody is under any illusions about the special role that the military plays in Indonesian society, and I might say in some other societies in South East Asia. That role is much greater than the role played by the military in countries such as Australia. There are many people in Indonesia who hold simultaneous posts in the armed forces and in the civilian bureaucracy. There are some who have been trained in the armed forces and who have then gravitated to the civilian bureaucracy.

We also understand the particular problems that apply to the holding together of a massive country in an archipelago of thousands of islands, many people of different religions and different backgrounds, and that in itself is not an easy task. The total falling asunder of the Soviet Union, for example, should teach us that there are some people of a conservative political nature who will do anything to keep a country together. What we as Australians should be doing—and what Senator Gareth Evans has proposed is the best way to go about it—is to indicate even to those in the military in Indonesia that there are better and more effective ways of keeping a country such as that together than simply singling out certain regions and punishing dissent in those regions. I do not think it is an accident that sooner or later this happened in East Timor rather than in some other more troublesome areas of the Indonesian archipelago.

I do not want to go on about that, but it serves to indicate that this is a very delicate area, but in no way should it prevent Australia making its views plainly known about the abuse of civil rights in East Timor that has occurred and is occurring. In no way does it allow Australia to draw back from saying, `We want a fair, open, frank and honest inquiry about the incident and the murders that occurred on 12 November in Dili'.

To inject a note that is not bipartisan, I am disappointed at the way in which the Liberal and National parties have attempted to amend Senator Gareth Evans's amendment. There seems to be a drawing back from this willingness to be honest and from saying, `We do not accept your view of human rights in Indonesia'. There is a drawing back from a number of very important moves or steps that the Australian Government is about to take. In our amendment we said that a consulate should be set up in East Timor immediately so that we have official eyes and ears on the ground. The Liberal and National parties have pulled back from that request.

We have also said that the United Nations, basically through the Secretary-General, should be involved. Those in the National and Liberal parties have pulled back from that and said that we do not need that process. For example, we have indicated our repugnance at the reported remarks of the Indonesian military, particularly the Indonesian commander-in-chief on the day following the massacre, in which he said, `The disrupters had to be shot'. To pull that out of our amendment is to let the Indonesians off the hook, and particularly those Indonesians who have a view that there is only one solution, as they call it, to the East Timorese problem, and that is repression.

TALK.START.PARA: —You did not listen to what Senator Hill said.

—I listened very carefully to what Senator Hill said. I say that the taking out of that very important expression of disgust at the comment by the Indonesian commander-in-chief is cowardly; it is inappropriate. It should be in there because under no circumstances should Indonesia and the Indonesian military be of the view that Australia is weak about this matter. Our repugnance should be shown clearly and that quote should be in any motion which goes from this Senate.
—Have you seen the transcript?
—Let him finish.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Teague)—Order! There are too many interjections on both sides of the chamber. Senator Aulich has the attention of the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been justified criticism directed at successive Australian governments of both political persuasions, beginning with the Whitlam Government and continuing with the Fraser Government era, of their inadequate role as strong mediators in that region on the East Timorese question. We all have to look at our consciences.

PARA.TAB: Maybe the constitutional difficulties we had in 1975 are not sufficient justification for us to have sat back and done nothing. The problem is very much of this Parliament's making. I may not have been here at the time but, I suppose like everyone else, I have to share some blame for accepting my Party's weakness in the issue and the weakness of the succeeding Liberal Government. I believe that today we have the opportunity to make amends for that by using cool heads and a certain degree of courage to ensure, for the benefit of the Indonesian people themselves let alone the people of East Timor, that people know exactly where we stand and that the mixed messages we have been sending to Jakarta are clarified. We have that opportunity today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —We all condemn the tragedy of 12 November in Indonesia. The horror and shock of death on our doorstep, one hour's flight from Darwin, certainly comes home quickly to us all. There can be no justification for the use of force against a civilian population. Many territorians have families in Indonesia with whom they have close contact. We now have many Australian citizens of Indonesian descent. I am certainly familiar with many people in the Northern Territory who have very close family ties with this tragedy and the events of 12 November.

PARA.TAB: The questions that are raised about the local military administration certainly have to be brought out and the seriousness brought home time and again. The comments attributed in yesterday's Australian to Governor Mario Carrascalao of East Timor after he returned from a visit to Jakarta are very important:
"They are not very well informed", he told the Lisbon daily, Publico. "They have only been told half-truths.

The massacre was not something that happened on the spur of the moment. There were antecedents", said Mr Carrascalao, who had threatened to resign after the shooting unless Jakarta held a full inquiry and brought to book those responsible.

SPEECH.PARA: We have now seen the international media attention and focus, and often confusion, on this issue. There is a need for information and investigation. The initial confusion by the Indonesian authorities is borne out in many ways. Senator Aulich has referred to our proposed deletion of one particular quote—it is evident—but I took offence to another, a statement by Admiral Sudomo on 15 November:

In anticipating the incident the security apparatus had taken persuasive measures to calm the crowd but a few radical elements had attacked and tried to seize the arms of the security apparatus which had led to cause casualties on both sides.

If we wanted, I am sure we could find many more appropriate quotes to include in this debate. We must join the international community in calling for a full and open investigation to ensure that all who are responsible for the events are properly brought to account in accordance with, firstly, Indonesian laws and, secondly, internationally accepted standards of human rights. The inquiry must be open.

PARA.TAB: We also have to be mindful of the historical context of this problem: the very nature of past Indonesian authority; the way in which it has exercised itself; the peculiar size of the country that we are talking about with its 180 million people; and the fact that East Timor had 400 years essentially of failed colonial administration by Portugal. We need to recognise that the ethnic people of both East and West Timor have the same cultural background, even though before 1975 they had different administrations.

August to December 1975 saw a bloody civil war after Portugal abandoned its colony. The interests that we need to recognise are that the marxist Fretilin on the one side pitted against the UDT, APODETI and Kotis interests on the other resulted in the deaths of tens of thousands of people. It was genocide on a grand scale.

Many of these hidden agendas are behind the debate today: the many vested interests of the Portuguese and their recent activities, particularly youth activities, in their former colony; the Portuguese interests with regard to their financial claims on the Timor Gap developments; the roles and involvement of the churches; the activities of Fretilin that have continued since 1975; and the roles of the international Left with regard to wider political objectives in Indonesia. The self-determination arguments of many people should not be on the agenda of this debate. We need to come back to talking about the issues of human rights and not guising a self-determination agenda under peculiar motions in peculiar ways.

My constituency, which encompasses the Northern Territory and most of northern Australia, has very special links with all sectors of the Indonesian community. We have access to aid groups that are constantly working. A lot of activity needs to be targeted and specially taken into account. I noticed with particular interest the debate last week in the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly which resulted in a unanimous resolution by the CLP Government and the Labor Party. I commend the debates there of Thursday, 14 November.

Many interests affect the Northern Territory, particularly in the areas of education, health and welfare. They are all being tackled and, very importantly, need to continue to be tackled and linked. I have had representations from youth groups in the Northern Territory with family links in these communities where people have died. We need to recognise their sorrow and grief.

The motion put forward by the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, Mr Perron, last week was very important. It is very important to note that sitting today in the gallery is the Parliamentary Secretary of the Northern Territory Cabinet, Rick Setter, who has taken a particular interest in this matter. The speech of the Northern Territory Leader of the Opposition, Mr Ede, was particularly relevant and important. I would love to take the time, but I do not have it, to quote from the speeches of many of the members of the Legislative Assembly, including the Minister for Industries and Development, Mr Hatton, and Mr Ede. However, I will quote the former Labor leader of the Legislative Assembly, Mr Terry Smith, who has just retired:

SPEECH.PARA: We cannot get away from the fact that a massacre has taken place; that it has taken place on our doorstep, an hour's flight away; and that it has taken place involving the families of fellow Territorians. We have the responsibility in that situation to speak up loud and to speak up strong.
Further on he said:

It is often said by the government that we, because of our closeness to Asia, have a special responsibility to develop that closeness and to develop ties with our Asian neighbours, and I agree. However, equally, if we accept that our closeness gives us a special responsibility to develop closer ties, our closeness also gives us a special responsibility to stand up and be counted when something drastic and dramatic and as terrible as this thing has happened.
I concur with the comments today of my other Senate colleagues in that regard.

PARA.TAB: Returning to the subject of special interests, the technical and vocational education into the eastern provinces of Indonesia that is now being managed by the Northern Territory Government is crucial to the future development and interests of Indonesian people. We need to moderate very carefully the trade union rules and roles to ensure that there is not undue extremism, maybe involving other agendas or other interests, but rather a return to the straight statement of the human rights that are at stake.

Senator Robert Hill and I met last week with Ambassador Siagian. I believe to this day that we are the only politicians to have sought and obtained an interview with him. We certainly made very strong points about human relations and whether this situation compared with what happened in China and Tiananmen Square and whether it compared with other situations. I certainly have good working relationships with the Indonesian consulate in Darwin and I intend to keep them up. As the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, Mr Perron, said last week in a letter to the trade unions in the Northern Territory on this issue:

SPEECH.PARA: I believe no purpose whatsoever will be achieved by breaking off educational, trade and diplomatic links with the Jakarta Government. Because of 10 years of solid work by the NT Government, I am able to put the view of our Timorese community, and express the horror of the community in general over recent events in Dili to senior Indonesian Ministers.
Further in that letter he said:
I suggest to you that more can be achieved by maintaining all forms of communication, both trade and diplomatic, by asking directly what happened in East Timor—

There are so many situations that we need to address in this particular debate. However, it is the future that we must look to and develop. The eyes of the world are on Indonesia today and it needs to recognise that it cannot walk away from the influence of television and radio and its responsibility to respond publicly. We do have important trade links. Indonesia has a responsibility to adopt a good neighbour policy and that policy involves us in many areas of vital and reciprocal interest.

PARA.TAB: I conclude my remarks today by quoting from an editorial in the Northern Territory News on Thursday, 14 November that I believe is extremely relevant. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Trade and commerce, cultural and sporting exchanges are ultimately the things which change societies and make them better. That has been the case in the past with European nations and will be the case with other developing nations around the world. Sure the Indonesian government should be left under no misapprehension that the actions of its soldiers in East Timor can in any way be condoned. It should be condemned in the strongest possible terms. Nor should the Indonesians believe Australia will be less shocked by the events next door than it was, for example, with Tiananmen Square. It simply means neither the Indonesians nor ourselves can afford to withdraw into a shell. Now perhaps less than ever. Geography has thrown us together and, whether anyone likes it or not, that will remain the case after Dili. That is why it is particularly important that our slowly developing ties also remain.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I place on record, as the motion does, my abhorrence of the massacre that occurred in Dili two weeks ago. Secondly, I place on record my deepest sympathy to the relatives and friends of those persons who have died or been injured. I was one member of a delegation of seven persons who visited East Timor. Some six weeks ago I outlined what I perceived to be the situation in East Timor when I tabled the report of our delegation's visit to Indonesia, Singapore and Hong Kong. I wish to relate a couple of my impressions for the record.

PARA.TAB: As I said six weeks ago, I found my visit to East Timor a terribly depressing experience from the point of view that, in contrast to other parts of Indonesia, East Timor struck me as being basically a military camp. There is no doubt that there are tens of thousands of combat troops in East Timor. Although the military presence has been scaled down over the past four or five years, it is still outwardly a very strong military presence. At least 100,000 people have died in East Timor over the past 15 years, as a result not only of internal civil war but also of direct, quite brutal Indonesian military occupation and repression that continues today.

Certainly there has been a considerable improvement in the situation over the past three or four years. There has been some improvement in roads and education, but one has to ask what the value of paved roads is for people in a subsistence economy, who have to walk everywhere. One has to ask the value of education when there is no employment or industry at all in East Timor except a basic subsistence agriculture. I have no doubt that there is an overwhelming desire for the East Timorese people to have a say in their future and for it not to be determined solely by a central government in Java. The East Timorese have nothing to lose in their current situation.

The Government amendment to the motion before the Senate addresses eight basic issues. It deals with the massacre and our sympathy for the families of the persons who have died; it deals with the very important issue of human rights; and it deals with the issue of the Australian Ambassador being asked to visit East Timor at the earliest opportunity.

There is a range of issues outlined in the amendment which, regrettably, those opposite cannot support. It includes such things as a call on the Australian Government to be a lot more active in terms of United Nations involvement in East Timor and the call for Senator Evans to visit East Timor in the very near future to place very clearly on the record our position on East Timor. The amendment also refers to negotiations that should take place between the central Indonesian Government and the legitimate representatives of the people of East Timor. It refers to the role of the Red Cross and also the establishment of a consulate in Dili, which I think is a very good idea. I regret to say that those opposite do not support those last points in the amendment. I have to pose the question: why? What positive approach do those opposite propose to take to resolve the conflict in East Timor?

I congratulate the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) as he has made very clear—and his comments are included in the amendment—his attitude to the situation in East Timor. In fact, the Prime Minister has expressed the clearest and strongest views of any political leader in the past 15 years. I congratulate Senator Harradine for the contribution he has made to this issue. As a fellow Tasmanian senator, I have known of Senator Harradine's strong interest in East Timor over a long period of time. Like Senator Harradine, I share a desire to have a close friendship with Indonesia because Indonesia will be one of the most important countries in terms of the economic development of Australia. However, a good relationship, a sound relationship and being good friends means that on occasions we will disagree.

Our relationship with Indonesia and our overall interests are important, but what is also important is that 100,000 to 200,000 people died in East Timor during a brutal and illegal military occupation. It is very clear that around the world there is almost no comparable example of a country illegally occupying a colony. It has not been tolerated or accepted in any other part of the world. Because of its failure in 1975 and 1976 and the years following, Australia carries a heavy moral responsibility for what has occurred in East Timor.

If this country is to participate in what I hope will be a new world order; if this country is to participate in the way we did earlier in the year—which I supported on principle and I still firmly support—we have to be consistent in the application of our principles. Certainly, the facts are different in East Timor, but there is no doubt that the illegal military occupation should end forthwith and that the East Timorese people should be allowed to have some say in their future.

From a personal point of view, if the inquiry into this situation is not satisfactory, I will be pushing my Government to end this de jure recognition of Indonesian occupation of East Timor and to end any military exchange programs. This is an ongoing issue. Simply passing a motion today in the Senate does not mean that the campaign to ensure some justice for the East Timorese should cease. This is an ongoing issue that has received some impetus, regrettably, by the massacre in East Timor. Of course, the international situation has changed quite dramatically in the past two years. We should not stop here. We should continue the campaign to ensure that the people of East Timor obtain justice and some sort of self-determination and freedom.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join with all other senators in expressing my abhorrence of the killings that occurred in Dili recently, particularly as they were unprovoked killings of unarmed civilians. That situation appals all honourable senators. It is right that this chamber should express its very deep concern and its very deep sympathy to the people of East Timor for the appalling tragedy that they experienced.

PARA.TAB: I support the amendment moved by Senator Hill, which basically contains the same thoughts and sentiments as that moved by Senator Evans. I am particularly pleased to see bipartisan support calling for a free and open investigation. I am pleased to hear of the unprecedented nature of the investigation being set up by the Indonesian Government in that the people appointed to it, as Senator Hill pointed out, are quite exceptional people. It is indeed pleasing to be able to join with all other senators in calling for that inquiry to be free, accurate, thorough and fair and also for appropriate action to be taken against those who might be found to have been guilty of excesses and unlawful acts.

I was pleased to hear from Senator Evans that the International Committee of the Red Cross has in fact today or yesterday been given access to the wounded in hospital and to people detained. I think that is, again, an indication that the Indonesian Government is prepared to allow the investigation to proceed fairly and to allow the ICRC to proceed with its investigations as it would wish to do. I also support the proposal in Senator Hill's amendment which mirrors other proposals for the Australian Ambassador to play a role in obtaining information and reporting to the Parliament on what has happened in Timor.

The tragedy that occurred in Dili very recently has, of course, its groundings in the long, rather unfortunate history of that particular part of the world. The Portuguese, who controlled East Timor for most of its recent history, had a terrible record. I think that some of the pronouncements that the Portuguese are now making are somewhat hypocritical. When the Portuguese walked out of East Timor in the midst of a very bloody civil war, their record had been nothing but appalling. When they walked out, only eight per cent of the local population could read or write. There were no sealed roads, very few schools, very few bridges and very few hospitals there. I would suggest that the words `human rights' were simply not part of the Portuguese dictionary at the time they governed Timor. I quote from an article written in 1974 which the Research Service has obtained for me about the Portuguese rule in that territory:

As recently as 1947, forced labour was being used for the construction of roads and other public works. An Australian officer of the War Graves Commission saw the system in operation at the time in the Viqueque area. The system appears to have been commuted to an annual poll tax but more recent descriptions of cowed and frightened behaviour of Timorese in the presence of Portuguese and the tenacious custom of saluting all Europeans offer some indication of the nature of the colonial relationship.

SPEECH.PARA: It was an appalling relationship. To compound it, the Portuguese walked out on that community amidst a very bloody civil war in which tens of thousands of people were slaughtered.

PARA.TAB: One of the groups involved was the communist marxist group of Fretilin, which caused some 40,000 to 50,000 refugees to migrate to West Timor at the time. The population of the capital city, Dili, decreased from 25,000 to 5,000. It was a terrible situation. It was into this situation that the Indonesian Government came and took over. There will be a lot of argument always regarding the takeover by the Indonesian Government, but it came into that situation at a time when tens of thousands of people were being massacred.

The Indonesians have tried very hard to rule properly in that community, as they have tried in the rest of their community. Indonesia is a country of some 13,670 islands, 6,000 of which are inhabited. There are 191 million Indonesians from 300 separate ethnic groups speaking 250 separate languages. Indonesia is our closest neighbour and is a major and increasing trading partner. Of the community in Indonesia, some 87 per cent are Muslims, and the balance are Christians and other minor religions. To us, Indonesia is our gateway to Asia. It is a neighbour with whom we have worked in very many constructive ways in recent times, and Senator Evans mentioned the Indonesian Government's contribution to the good work that has been done in Cambodia in which Australia played a very large part.

The East Timor province, with a population of about 737,000, 120,000 of whom are in Dili, has been for the last couple of years run in the same way as any other Indonesian province. It has received an enormous amount of money from the Indonesian Government—far more than any other region of Indonesia and, certainly in one year, far more than the Portuguese ever put into that community in the whole of their time there. It is run in the same way as any other province.

I think it is instructive to mention the principles of Pancasila, which govern all Indonesians. Firstly, they believe in one God. This principle affirms the Indonesian people's belief in God. Secondly, they believe in a just and civilised humanity. This principle indicates the respect which should be shown to all human beings regardless of sex, religion or political beliefs. Thirdly, it speaks of unity. This principle embodies the unity of the Indonesian nation. Fourthly, it talks of democracy and decision-making by a process of deliberation designed to reach a consensus rather than one group imposing its will on others. The fifth principle of Pancasila, social justice, is the principle that demands the equitable spread of resources to the whole population. It indicates the protection of the weak in the society so that a just and equal society can be created.

Those are the principles by which the Indonesian nation is run. Those principles apply right throughout. It is, therefore, somewhat distressing to see what happened in Dili recently. It has happened, I suggest, not through the urgings or the directions of the Indonesian Government or its senior officials but through the horrendous actions of people holding very minor positions of authority.

My visit to Indonesia with Senator Sherry brought me into contact with the Governor, Mario Carrascalao, and the military commander, Brigadier-General Warouw. I join Senator Sherry in his opinions of these people. I quote from Senator Sherry's speech:

I would like to give considerable credit to the Governor of East Timor, Mario Carrascalao, and to the military commander, Brigadier-General Warouw, with whom we spent quite some time. There is no doubt that these two individuals have made a very determined and conscientious effort to improve the situation in East Timor under their jurisdiction.
