I give them considerable credit for their openness and frankness in discussing with us the problems in East Timor.

SPEECH.PARA: I would go even further and say that I found them both to be particularly sensitive to the issues in East Timor and to be trying their best to do the right thing. There are provocateurs at home and abroad who would be unhappy with a peaceful solution to the East Timorese situation in which all parties could get together and live happily together. But it should not stop the rest of the world from trying to achieve that solution.

PARA.TAB: I also noticed the army presence in East Timor. But I do say that a lot of the army presence I noticed was from the territorial army: the engineers, the doctors and the civilian troops who were spending time there on civilian projects.

We can always be very quick to blame others for human rights abuses. Our own record with Aborigines, as the inquiry into Aboriginal deaths in custody shows, is not quite as good as we would like it to be. We have also given many confused signals around the world about our attitudes to Tiananmen Square, Fiji, African human rights and the Balkans. Whilst in no way diminishing our horror at and the abhorrence of the unprovoked killings, I look towards the future of Indonesia and its relationships with Australia and the world, about which both Senator Hill and Senator Tambling spoke.

We have to try to encourage trade and tourism. We have to do anything that will get a greater Australian presence into East Timor, and I support the proposal for a consulate in East Timor. I come from that part of the world—Townsville, Cairns and northern Australia—where we have very close relationships with the Indonesians, very close trading relationships, where a lot of people are involved with the Indonesians on a daily basis, and that relationship should continue. Our involvement with Indonesia has increased; as recently as last Friday Garuda International opened a new air link into Cairns.

I understand the amendment moved by Senator Evans. I understand the difficulties he has with some sections of his own Party, but I support what he says, not necessarily what is written in his document. I think the amendment moved by Senator Hill far more appropriately puts the sentiments this Senate should express.

I look forward to the day when the Timorese problem is solved, when a full investigation into the killings has been held and properly concluded and those responsible brought to justice. I look forward to the day when there is a peaceful Timor, where all inhabitants are able to live together in peace and harmony. I look forward to the day when Australia can live closely and with mutual trust and respect with our nearest neighbour. I look forward to the day when all the world—not just Indonesia, not just Australia, not just the rulers of Tiananmen Square, not just Africa or the Balkans—is a place where bloodshed is abolished and human rights are universally and unambiguously a matter of course. I support Senator Hill's amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I share the concern and expressions of sympathy that have been offered today by honourable senators around the chamber to the East Timorese community in Australia and, of course, to their families and friends back home who have suffered this enormous tragedy. I express sympathy not only for the Dili massacre and for the other massacres that have followed since then—we should keep that in mind—but also for all that has gone before that, for everything that has happened since 1975. Along with some other senators who have spoken here today, I apologise for Australia's stand in 1975 and since.

PARA.TAB: I want to refer back to the original motion moved by Senator Bourne and me earlier today. We deliberately worded this motion very cautiously in order to seek cross-party support; we know that there is genuine cross-party concern for what has happened in East Timor. Our intention was to put forward a motion that could be supported by the Senate of Australia, that would send a very strong message to the Indonesian Government via our own Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans).

However, we have had two significant sets of amendments to our motion. I would really have preferred our motion to be much stronger, because obviously it is not going to get through. So I will put on record what I would have preferred to say in the beginning. That was—and I am sure Senator Bourne shares this particular aspect with me—that we would like to see Australian military aid and defence equipment exports to Indonesia not just reassessed but discontinued. We feel strongly that Australia does have a responsibility for aiding the Indonesian military. No matter how good our intentions might sound or how good our intentions might be, obviously we are aiding and abetting the Indonesian military and we can see the result, particularly in East Timor.

A second matter I would like to have added to the original motion is that Australia should rescind its de jure recognition of Indonesia's takeover of East Timor in 1975. Other senators have referred to this. We deliberately did not put that into the motion because we knew that it would be difficult for the Government and that the Opposition probably would not support it either. But a lot of the problems stem from the fact that during that tragic time Australia really sat on its hands and did nothing.

It is tragic that, in the year when self-determination is back on the international agenda, it has taken this massacre in Dili to bring back concern about East Timor after the international community has looked the other way for 16 years. That is apart from a few motions that have come intermittently before the United Nations during that time. I remind the Senate of the words of our Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to the crew of HMAS Darwin on 13 August 1990 as he sent them off to the Gulf:

SPEECH.PARA: It's important for Australia that the world understands big countries cannot invade small countries and get away with it.

When the journalists asked him about East Timor as an analogy, he simply brushed it off and refused to answer the question. That is what has happened here repeatedly, because I have raised that question with the Minister as well: it has been dismissed.

PARA.TAB: In December last year, I asked Senator Evans what was the difference between Iraq's invasion of Kuwait and Indonesia's invasion of East Timor. He offered some totally inadequate excuses about East Timor being a colony and not a sovereign state, that it had all happened a long time ago and we could not do much about it. In fact, he said that there was no need to contemplate any change of policy, and he denied that there was the growing international body of opinion that I had referred to concerning the rights of self-determination for the East Timorese. I find it strange that, at a time when the Baltic states have achieved their independence after 50 years of occupation, a period when the Australian Government refused to acknowledge Soviet authority over those three countries, Senator Evans can say that it is too late to change our position on East Timor.

The wrong that was committed in 1975 can be corrected. It should not be compounded by continuing with that recognition. Australia is one of the very few countries in the world that has recognised Indonesia's takeover of East Timor. We should not refuse to admit that we were wrong in the past; we are compounding the problem by so doing. I commend the Liberal member of parliament from South Australia, Chris Gallus, who said at a rally outside Parliament House on 12 November that both the Labor Government of Gough Whitlam as well as the current one and the Liberal Government of Malcolm Fraser bore some of the responsibility for the situation in East Timor today. That was borne out by Senator Aulich and Senator Sherry in their speeches this afternoon, and I am glad they had the courage to say that; I think it is very important.

What we really need to see is this Government working for talks between the East Timorese and Indonesia to resolve the conflict along the lines suggested last year by East Timorese resistance leader Xanana Gusmao. Senator Evans worked long and hard to bring an end to the conflict in Cambodia, and I have commended him for his dedication. I find it sad that he is not prepared to bring his skills to bear on following up these proposals with regard to East Timor and Indonesia. We should be pushing hard in the United Nations for this issue to be put on the agenda, as Senator Evans went in to bat on the Cambodia issue.

It is worth noting that the leader of the Catholic Church in East Timor, Bishop Belo, has repeatedly stressed self-determination. In February 1989 he wrote to the United Nations pointing out that the East Timorese had not been consulted and were calling for a United Nations referendum. Despite this, in the same year the Australian Government was prepared to sign the Timor Gap treaty, dividing up the oil in the Timor Gap with Indonesia rather than with the people of East Timor, for which Australia has been taken to the International Court by Portugal. The outcome of that will be quite interesting to see. I think the Timor Gap treaty is another reason why the Australian Government is so reluctant to take the Indonesian Government to task. The East Timorese consider that it is stolen oil; it is their oil, not Indonesia's.

It is important to note that Indonesia is a state created from what was once the Dutch East Indies. The colonialism bogy comes back to haunt us many times. At the time of its creation, Indonesia did not lay claim to the territory of East Timor, not even under President Sukarno. The United Nations has declared the 1990s the decade for the eradication of colonialism. There is to be a special effort over the next 10 years to clear up the 15 or so remaining decolonisation issues. East Timor, of course, is one of these.

I still find it very difficult to understand the inconsistency on East Timor that the Australian Government perpetrates. I am glad that much of what Senator Evans has put in his proposal is acceptable in getting the United Nations in on the act, but I think we should be going further than he has suggested. I am in favour of improving relations with Indonesia, but I am not prepared to be selective about human rights. It is important to note that the SBS Dateline program indicated last Friday that this Government has known all about Indonesia's operations in East Timor since 1975 through the activities of the Defence Signals Directorate in the far north of this country. As a member of the Cabinet since 1983, Senator Evans cannot claim ignorance of Indonesian military operations.

As has been very obvious from the debate this afternoon, this is an issue that crosses party boundaries. We all want the situation to improve for the East Timorese people and we all want the killings to stop. There were many old soldiers in 1975 who remembered the thousands of East Timorese who gave their lives fighting with Australians against the Japanese between 1942 and 1945. It is the case that many of their families believe that they have been betrayed by Australia. This is a very sad situation.

I will not be supporting Senator Hill's amendment for the reasons outlined very clearly by Senator Aulich who, I think, demolished some of the problems that were raised. I would like to make one comment about part (g) of Senator Evans's amendment which talks about the suspension of military training programs in the event that the Indonesian investigation and follow-up action are unsatisfactory. I find that far too weak. However, I very reluctantly have to agree with the Government's amendment, although I do not agree with that part.

As I said earlier, Senator Bourne and I deliberately worded our motion to be inclusive enough and cautious enough to get full party support. I am disappointed that that has not happened. Given that that has not happened, I am prepared to support Senator Evans's amendment because certainly it is a step in the right direction and I commend the Government for that.
Senator Hill's amendment to Senator Gareth Evans's amendment negatived.
Senator Gareth Evans's amendment agreed to.
Motion, as amended, agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: First of all, I would like to make a general criticism that the public and the Parliament hear too little about what is happening at Australian Agricultural Council meetings. The Council consists of agricultural Ministers from all around Australia and the Federal Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Although the Council seems to work slowly, it puts forward some really good resolutions that I believe are not publicised nearly well enough.

PARA.TAB: I draw the Senate's attention to a couple of resolutions made at the 136th meeting of the Agricultural Council which will be very pertinent to inquiries that the Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs will be conducting in the new year. The resolution on drought policy states:

SPEECH.PARA: Noted that Standing Committee had not agreed on a national drought policy.

The Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs will be having a look at the drought task force recommendations. Hopefully, the Committee—which, as we all know, is an all-party committee—will come back to the Senate with a resolution which will give the Federal Minister some assistance when he meets with State agriculture Ministers at the end of February. First of all, I hope that the drought will have broken. Secondly, whether or not the drought has broken, I hope that the Committee will come up with some suggestions and ideas that will help people in those areas.

PARA.TAB: Another Agricultural Council resolution related to national guidelines for feedlots. The Queensland Minister for Primary Industries led a discussion on feedlots and their market potential. He made the point that there was now $740m worth of feedlot beef in a total export beef industry of $2 billion. This is an expanding industry. This point was made at the Council meeting:

SPEECH.PARA: Nationally agreed guidelines were seen as necessary to ensure a coordinated approach to feedlots in general as well as specific issues such as animal welfare and the environment.

The Rural and Regional Affairs Committee will be looking at feedlots from an environmental, economic and animal welfare point of view. I hope and trust that our Committee will give some help and assistance to the agricultural Ministers when they meet next year.

PARA.TAB: A resolution on the national registration scheme for agricultural and veterinary chemicals was also brought up at the Council meeting. The record of the meeting states:

SPEECH.PARA: Standing Committee advised Council that it endorsed the proposal of the AAVCC that the development of a national approach to control of use could be a responsibility of the future national registration body, and desirably this should be embodied in the new legislation.

A year or so ago, a Senate select committee, chaired by the Deputy President, looked at agricultural and veterinary chemicals in Australia and came down with a strong recommendation that this be done.

PARA.TAB: The Council also considered the question of a domestic meat inspection review and the need to keep our meat inspection costs down. There is a possibility that these costs could be reduced by between 25 and 30 per cent if some of the task force recommendations are implemented. I recommend such a course to the Senate. If this happens we will have reduced inspection costs as well as a completely clean product. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is considering the report of the Australian Agricultural Council meeting which was held in Sydney in August this year. This meeting occurred at a time when the Australian rural sector had been facing a very pessimistic future. In fact, the outlook continues to be bleak with this week's news that one of the last sources of water for many rural communities in western New South Wales, the Darling River, has been badly polluted with the highly toxic blue-green algae. This is on top of a devastating drought, which is proving to be the death knell for many farmers in my own State of Queensland.

PARA.TAB: The Council dealt with a number of specific issues at the meeting, including the brucellosis and tuberculosis eradication campaign, the development of long term screw-worm fly preparedness for Australia and the introduction of consistent national standards for egg grading and packaging. However, a number of highly contentious and urgent issues were considered at the Ministers policy session. These issues included: an overview of development and related policies, including an update of the GATT-Uruguay Round; market development in Asia; coordination between Commonwealth and the States on agricultural trade opportunities; national guidelines for feedlots, about which my colleague Senator Brownhill spoke; drought policy; and the relative role of agriculture in economic and public policy implementation. It would have been interesting to have been an observer at the meeting.

With regard to the Uruguay Round and the trade issues, the report notes on page 2 that the Chairman assured Council of the Government's continuing efforts to attain meaningful reform of agriculture and agricultural trade policies. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The prospects for a successful outcome to the Uruguay Round negotiations by the end of 1991 or early 1992 hinged on a successful outcome in the agriculture negotiations.
The report goes on to say:
Considerable progress had been achieved but difficult political decisions remained to be taken in a number of areas.

I wonder what the Ministers actually thought was the considerable progress that had been achieved. It is ironic to note that these same Ministers, in the report of their previous meeting in Nelson, New Zealand at the beginning of the year, said:
While Ministers recognised that the concept of a level playing field was never likely to be fully achieved, most thought that there would be some significant benefits for Australia.

I have heard many speakers in this place and in the media argue about the merits of free trade and the abolition of tariffs, but I have yet to see any significant benefits flow to our rural sector; only hardship seems to be the end result.

PARA.TAB: Australia has been building its tariff policy around its commitment to the Uruguay Round of GATT. We are told that it is necessary for Australia to reduce its tariff barriers to demonstrate our good faith at GATT and to encourage the larger, more powerful nations to demonstrate that they will follow our lead. However, it is quite clear that this philosophy is not working. The EC and other countries have failed to respond to any of the initiatives taken by Australia and other trading nations.

This came under considerable spotlight in the Senate in June when we addressed the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill. In that debate, the Government outlined how it intended to set what it calls a `level playing field' for the motor vehicle industry, the textiles, clothing and footwear industry, the vegetable industry and the sugar industry. What concerns me greatly is that it did this without regard to the impact of its policies on the competitive conditions within which producers in each of those industries work. As I said in the debate on the sugar industry:

SPEECH.PARA: We are saying . . . that because we are on the altar of free trade, because we want to be able to hold our hands on our hearts and say to the Europeans, to the Americans and to the Japanese that we are acting as we believe they should act, we will be in a better position to ensure that they do so.

Unfortunately, in doing so, we place a number of our major industries in a position where there will be even more unemployed; where there will be an even larger number of those engaged in the TCF industry shutting up plant and moving offshore; and where in the sugar industry and the vegetable industry we will find that imports will take over their market share. Reduction of tariffs in these areas as some sort of grand gesture, while they are not being matched by our trading competitors, is a warm inner glow nonsense.

TALK.START.PARA: —I endorse the remarks made by Senator Bjelke-Petersen and I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The record and resolutions of the seventh meeting of the Australian Soil Conservation Council on 2 August 1991 deal with a subject that is very close to my heart. I have spoken about soil conservation quite a lot in this place. It is one of those issues which I believe should be basically apolitical. It is something we should all strive for because, basically, soil is where it all starts: the growing of our crops provides a livelihood to the people who grow them; and the food that is produced sustains people through life. It also gives us a great export income. It all stems from the soil, as I think Fallowfield, that memorable English gentleman, said.

PARA.TAB: I notice that the Chairman of the Soil Conservation Council, the Hon. Simon Crean, said in his opening remarks:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . perhaps for the first time, the Commonwealth and States were close to adopting a national strategic approach to soil conservation.
I think that is fantastic. He went on to say that this was a positive development, particularly in the context of the outcomes of the Special Premiers Conference. He continued:
There was now a clear vision to guide future efforts—"sustainable land use by the year 2000". The Decade of Landcare Plan would provide the road map.
He then went on to say:

Community landcare continued to be the main focus of attention for governments in facilitating more sustainable land uses. Community interest and involvement in landcare groups and activities continued to be high. There were now over 900 landcare and related groups.

I think that is commendable and wonderful. It is something about which we should all be very happy and proud. But, unless guidance comes from the Commonwealth powers and the Australian Conservation Council, and incentives are given to the people at the coalface to actually do something about it, it will be only rhetoric. We do not want that; we want things to actually happen at the coalface.

PARA.TAB: One of my concerns is that the money that is put into land care is used correctly and is used where it is meant to be used: by the end-users. If it falters now and if the money is not forthcoming as part of a budget to look after our soil to keep this decade of land care operating in a proper manner, we will find that we will be the losers in the long run.

I notice also that the Australian Soil Conservation Council made mention of drought. It made the point that the differences in the approach between the Commonwealth and State governments precluded the development of a national drought policy. I have already mentioned that, hopefully, the rural and regional affairs committee might be able to help them to get it all together somewhere along the line. The Commonwealth does not differentiate between degrees of severity of drought, whereas the States have agreed that a national drought policy should make provision for extreme drought, with clearly defined special assistance measures.

However, the Commonwealth and the States agreed that there was a need to improve farmers' risk management skills. Here, again, guidance has to be given and a lead has to be taken so that people can put money away in good times in order to look after themselves later. I suggest that a decent IED scheme, whereby people can put money away in good times in order to look after themselves in bad times, is a step in the right direction.

In conclusion, I notice that the Council approved the awarding of the 1991 McKell Medal to Professor John Burton. Professor Burton from New England University, whom I have had a lot to do with, is an absolute genius at spreading the word about the conservation of our most precious resource. He is a person with practical ideas who did a great deal of good in the Murray-Darling Basin, as well as in the area of soil conservation generally. I commend this report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to have the opportunity of following my colleague Senator Brownhill in speaking to the report of the Australian Soil Conservation Council on its meeting held in Sydney in August. In doing so, I first want to congratulate all of those throughout the Australian community who are making strenuous efforts to promote soil conservation activities across Australia. I note from the agenda that item No. 1 was, `The Decade of Landcare Plans and Commonwealth/State/Territory Cooperation'.

PARA.TAB: In recent years, we have often heard of several pressing environmental matters, including energy, pollution and the greenhouse effect, which have been competing for the public's attention. But soil degradation is our most basic issue. It is often forgotten in the media and there do not seem to be many votes in this issue when politicians parade their concerns about the environment before the public. Yet, as I have said, soil degradation is Australia's No. 1 environmental issue.

Over thousands of years, floods, dry spells and the prevailing wind patterns have combined to strip numerous layers of the fine fertile soil from Australia's surface. Regrettably, most of it has ended up in the Pacific and Indian oceans, stretching out from the coastline in two plumes to the north-west and the south-east, mirroring the prevailing wind systems.

We all would have read numerous stories about wind-blown soil from the Australian mainland which is regularly dumped on the New Zealand alps. Nothing is more important to a nation's environment than its soil and the preservation of the quality of its land. The loss of our thin and fragile soil, the progressive degradation of our land and the expansion of the desert and arid areas of the Australian continent are our No. 1 environmental challenge. Left unmet, the result will be a disaster on a massive scale for Australia.

By 1983, about 66 per cent of all of our land was in need of some conservation measures. Significant long term problems have also arisen as a result of the progressive breaking down of the structure of Australian soils. Soil conservation is not only of particular importance to the greenies to whom the Government and the media are often pandering but also of vital importance to those Australians who often have much more to do with the environment—that is, the man and woman on the land.

Only in the past few years has soil degradation come a little into focus. This is partly because during the past few years Australia has experienced a series of storms, droughts and floods which were directly or indirectly related to the problem. Indeed, the disastrous drought currently being experienced in my State of Queensland has resulted in unheard of dust storms blanketing cities, such as Brisbane, with a constant haze of fine soil swept off the once beautiful top soil of the Darling Downs.

The nation's stocktaking during the Bicentenary also brought a reawakening of concern for what has been happening to Australia's land. It is estimated that about half of Australia's rural land requires treatment for land degradation. Human activity has been responsible for about half of that degradation. Indeed, Australian farmers play the leading role in the environment, caring for over 200 million animals and millions of square kilometres of land. The care of this nation's environment, to a remarkable degree, is already in their hands.

Agriculture is a sustainable and renewable industry, yet there is growing criticism, much of it from ignorance, of farming practices. Indeed, in previous reports on soil conservation it has been noted that although the rural recession has reduced the scale of soil conservation work it has not reduced landholders' commitment to land care. That is because farming is very much a family activity with a number of generations usually working the same farm. Consequently, there is a powerful incentive for each generation to leave the land in a better state than they found it.

The majority of farmers have, for decades, been environmentally conscious and have taken many initiatives to improve the environment. I have spoken in the Senate of the fine work done by many in the community on land care programs. I note in the report that the Chairman urged all Ministers to take a strong personal interest in the promotion and implementation of the decade of land care plans.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motion that the Senate take note of the Australian Soil Conservation Council's annual report, record and resolutions at its meeting held in Sydney in August. Although it is a strange coincidence, the aspects of the Chairman's opening statement which attracted Senator Brownhill's attention were the very ones that I had underlined as being particularly important. I noted also that the Chairman, in his opening statement, said that there was now a clear vision to guide our future efforts. The opening statement says that we will have `sustainable land use by the year 2000'. That has become the sort of statement that is very easily supportable by a number of commentators and people who are interested in this issue. The question becomes: what does it actually mean? Why is it important to make such a statement?

PARA.TAB: There will be considerable debate over the very meaning of the statement. In this context, I assume that it would be easy to gain agreement with the idea that sustainable land use would mean land use which could continue in that fashion infinitely. After all, there is no point in saying `sustainable' if we only mean sustainable up to a certain year—whether that be 3000 or 4000 AD. `Sustainable' must mean sustainable in an infinite sense.

I think Senator Bjelke-Petersen adequately described to us why it was important that such a concept be cemented in our policies, in our Government's policies and in our community's actions over the next few years. As Senator Bjelke-Petersen quite rightly said, we are all too familiar with the mental picture, the tangible picture, of much of our soil being blown offshore into the Pacific Ocean, the Indian Ocean or being deposited on New Zealand's alps. It is sad that we should be familiar with that picture. I think we have lost our complacency with that picture, but it is through actions of councils such as the Australia Soil Conservation Council that we have the means to stop that situation from recurring. Such a picture is not sustainable. It should be obvious to everybody that such a situation cannot continue indefinitely.

The other part of the opening statement which attracted my attention, and that of Senator Brownhill, was that community land care continued to be the main focus of a tangent for governments in facilitating more sustainable land uses. The word `community' attracted me. As Senator Brownhill said, guidance, leadership and finance from the Commonwealth are necessary in this area. One of the most useful ways to ensure that it occurs is to emphasise and make available successful models of farm practice to those who use the land and those who devise policies about land use. Successful usage models must be available for inspection, instruction and education. It is not simply a matter of throwing money in that direction; it is a matter of following good examples—best practices, if you like—and certainly examples that are working.

It is true that we have a great number of successful land users around Australia. Those people have been able to demonstrate that their land use practices are sustainable and in fact are improving the soil retention of the areas in which they are involved. Such people do not receive enough publicity. I have mentioned in this place before Mr Bert Farquhar who has taken over an area of land known as Rushy Lagoon in Tasmania, an area previously owned and exploited by the British Tobacco Co. which degraded the soil very successfully. Since Mr Bert Farquhar and his army of unpaid workers—the worms—inhabited this land, it has become a model for all to follow. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: In the brief time available to me, I want to make a few points about the Industry Commission's annual report for 1990-91. It is a very important report and deserves detailed consideration by the Senate and, indeed, by the wider community. First, I congratulate Mr Stephen Sedgwick on his appointment as Chairman of the Industry Commission, following the appointment of the outgoing Chairman, Mr Tony Cole, as the Secretary to the Treasury. Mr Cole did a very good job with the Industry Commission. I wish Mr Sedgwick well in his new role.

PARA.TAB: The 1990-91 report raises some very important issues. It is in many ways a very thinly disguised attack and certainly a very strong criticism of the Government's performance in terms of economic reform in this country. At a time when economic reform is the buzz word for everyone, when the Government has been claiming great success in economic reform, the Industry Commission has brought that down to earth with a very significant bang.

The report starts off by mentioning substantial progress in reforming Australia's economy in the past year. It mentions two reforms in particular: further tariff reductions and the States' acceptance in principle of mutual recognition of regulations. It also points out that governments have signalled a willingness to work together to effect further change in the context of the special Premiers conferences. So far as tariff reform is concerned, the coalition's policies for tariff reform would see a faster pace of reform than those of the Government.

Since this report was drafted, we have had the massive collapse of the special Premiers conference arrangements that showed so much hope of achieving substantial reform in Commonwealth-State relations, particularly so far as the financial relationship is concerned. The unwillingness of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), due to pressures from within his own Government, to encompass the scope for financial relationship change, despite previous commitments to the Premiers, is a very sad thing indeed and we will pay dearly for it. I hope very much that the Prime Minister will be able to change his view on that matter.
The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . some opportunities for micro-economic reform have not been taken up, even though the need to press ahead remains as urgent as ever. Not to respond to the challenge would be to condemn Australians to a lower standard of living than we are capable of achieving.

The report then talks about the missed opportunities that have occurred with this Government's policies. It mentions the fact that there is no room for complacency, that there is a great deal more still to be done. I note in particular page 5 of the report which is, as I said earlier, a thinly disguised but nevertheless strong criticism of the Government.

PARA.TAB: Indeed, the thrust of the report as a whole is that the changes that this country ought to be making in the areas of micro-economic reform and our taxation system and the like are lineball with the thrust of many, and indeed most, of the specific proposals contained in the coalition's Fightback! document which was released last week. The IC report is a very strong support for this document. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.
