TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with section 118 of the Commonwealth Banks Act 1959 I present the annual reports and financial statements of the Commonwealth Bank of Australia and subsidiary companies, the Commonwealth Savings Bank of Australia and the Commonwealth Development Bank of Australia, together with the Auditor-General's report thereon for the year ended 30 June 1991.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The annual report of the Commonwealth Bank for 1991 is indeed a very important report, as is said at the outset in the report itself. Indeed, the first sentence of the Chairman's report reads:
The year ended June 1991 was a landmark year for the Commonwealth Bank.

It certainly was a landmark year. The biggest landmark of it was the fact that 30 per cent of the shareholding of the Commonwealth Bank was floated on the public market and, as a result, we have a partial privatisation of the Commonwealth Bank for the first time. It is now owned 30 per cent by the public and 70 per cent by the Government. The Commonwealth Bank ought to have been fully privatised. It is a key plank of the coalition's policy that on coming to Government we will privatise the remaining 70 per cent of the shareholding of the Commonwealth Bank. As we pointed out in our coalition policy document last week, we propose to do that in the first year of returning to government.

PARA.TAB: It is regrettable, I think, that only 30 per cent of the bank has been privatised to date. That was due to a large degree of internal pressure within the Labor Party ranks themselves. A special national conference of the Labor Party was required even to get approval for that 30 per cent to be privatised. The legislation enshrines the fact that the shareholding shall not increase beyond 30 per cent. One of the very first acts of the incoming Liberal-National government after the next election will be to amend that legislation to allow the bank to be fully privatised, because that is the only way in which we are going to enable the bank to grow, to achieve its own efficiency and to be able to compete properly in the financial markets along with the other private sector institutions.

To have a bank 30 per cent privatised and 70 per cent still in the hands of government hogties that institution in a way that makes it inevitable that it will not be able to be as efficient and as competitive as it should be, as the Government would want it to be, as the shareholders would want it to be and, indeed, as its customers would want it to be. The Commonwealth Bank is a major institution in Australia and it needs the ability to be able to compete fully and fiercely with all the other institutions that go to make up our financial system.

The annual report—I have had the chance to glance only very briefly at it—contains some very interesting material. In terms of the financial results for 1990-91, it points out that there was a significant fall in group operating profit after tax and before abnormal items from $497.3m in 1989-90 to $272.1m in 1990-91. That is a 45.3 per cent fall in profit.

That fall was due to a variety of factors, but in particular it was due to a massive rise in the charge against profit for bad and doubtful debt. That charge against profit for bad and doubtful debt rose during the year to a staggering figure of more than $1 billion. It had risen to $1.026 billion by the end of 1990-91. That is compared with a figure of only $461.7m at the end of 1989-90. That figure of $461m, for heaven's sake, was large enough. The rise to over $1 billion is a staggering increase. The report continues:

SPEECH.PARA: Bad debt expense adversely affected most areas of the Bank's operations. Profits of the Commonwealth Development Bank and the Bank's finance company, CBFC Limited, both fell on this account.
The report also points out:
Profit was also affected by loss of interest income and other revenues from non-performing loans. . .

This really is another phrase for bad debt. The report states that—net of provisions and interest reservations—those non-performing loans stood at a figure of $2.2 billion at 30 June 1991, compared with only $504m a year earlier.

PARA.TAB: In other words, over the 12 months from July 1990 to the end of June 1991, the non-performing loans of the Commonwealth Bank rose fourfold. They rose to a level of 3.09 per cent of the total lending assets of the bank, compared with less than one per cent of the lending assets a year earlier.

Those figures for 1990-91 were, of course, affected to a major degree by the other great event that occurred in connection with the Commonwealth Bank in 1990-91. I refer to its acquisition of the State Bank of Victoria which, the Senate will recall, arose as a bail-out operation because of the incredibly incompetent policies and mismanagement of the State Bank of Victoria, essentially by the Victorian Government, which led to the State of Victoria having to sell perhaps its prized asset, the State Bank, to the Commonwealth Bank. That was a bail-out operation of enormous magnitude.

The collapse of the State Bank of Victoria and the collapse of the Pyramid Building Society and other companies—including those connected with the Victorian Government's financing body, the VEDC—have had an enormous impact on my own State of Victoria. I see that my colleague Senator Cooney is here, not necessarily nodding his head but I am sure agreeing that the state of affairs in Victoria is one of very real depression. It is not just financial or physical depression and a loss in output but it is a major loss of will and spirit in Victoria. That is having a significant effect on the whole population of Victoria. There is a massive job to be done by incoming Liberal-National Party governments, both in Victoria and here in Canberra, to change that mood around.

I believe that without those changes in government there will not be the change in psychology in the Victorian community, business or individual, that is necessary if we are to get Victoria out of the dreadful hole that it is now in. The State Bank sale, I think at bargain prices, to the Commonwealth Bank was perhaps the classic example and epitome of everything that is wrong in the State of Victoria.
The Victorians are still paying for the massive incompetence of their State Government. During 1990-91, according to the Commonwealth Bank annual report:

SPEECH.PARA: The Victorian Government paid over an amount of $510m against the risk on these loans—
its non-performing loans—
as part of the purchase agreement, to release an indemnity for loan losses it had provided to the State Bank.

At the end of the day, the chickens come home to roost fairly and squarely with the Victorian taxpayers; and, given the relationship between the present Commonwealth Government and the State Government, there is a very real risk that they will come home to roost with Australian taxpayers generally. Certainly, the Victorian taxpayers are being hit to leg as a result of this gross incompetence that has occurred.

PARA.TAB: We find in the case of the Pyramid Building Society debacle that Victorians are paying 3c a litre on petrol simply to meet the guarantees that the Victorian Government has given to the holders of funds in Pyramid. That will continue for many years throughout this decade. All Victorians, every time they go to the petrol pump to put petrol in their cars, are paying 3c on every litre for the privilege of meeting the massive guarantees that were incurred as a result of what I believe was, to say the very least, the unbelievable incompetence that was exhibited by the Victorian Government—in particular, the incompetence exhibited by the then Treasurer, Mr Jolly, and the other responsible Minister, Mr McCutcheon, who gave to the depositors in Pyramid in the earlier part of last year a letter of comfort which was, at the very least, highly misleading. That is the basic reason why every Victorian is now shouldering the burden of the calamities that occurred with those building societies collapses.

The report of the Commonwealth Bank, reflecting the impact on it of the finances of the State Bank of Victoria, is all part and parcel of a financial incompetence on the part of the Labor governments of Victoria and the Commonwealth. The policies compound; they work in a vicious cycle. They are a massive example of the reason why, at the next election, both in Victoria and federally, there will be, I am quite certain, a massive swing and a change of government in both the State and the Commonwealth.

There are many other things one could say about the report. The report requires and warrants much more careful examination than we have been able to give it in the very short time since its release. But I congratulate the bank on getting through the year in the way in which it has. It has a very long, hard road ahead of it. To give the bank credit, it does not pull any punches when it looks at that road ahead. In the section on the outlook for 1991-92, the chairman, Mr Besley, says:

SPEECH.PARA: Weak domestic economic activity and depressed world market prices for some key Australian exports are expected to limit opportunities during the coming year and intensify competition amongst the banks for quality lending. . .

PARA.TAB: The level of bad and doubtful debt expense and the related problems of non-accrual loans during 1991/92 cannot be reliably predicted at this stage. Weaknesses in the economy are still affecting borrowers and are expected to continue for some time.

SPEECH.PARA: That is precisely what the Opposition here in Canberra has been telling the Government. If it thinks that economic recovery is under way, it is not only kidding itself but it is cruelly deluding itself and the Australian people. There is no way that the Australian economy at the moment has any recovery under way. At the very best one could say that the level of economic activity has bottomed. Even that, I believe, is optimistic and we as Australians are set for a very long, hard year ahead. The great tragedy about the continuation of this Government is that it is refusing to acknowledge those basic facts—that the fundamentals underpinning the Australian economy are in their worst shape for at least 60 years. Never since the 1930s has the fundamental structure of the Australian economy been in as weak a shape as it is today. Therefore, it is an absolute necessity to make a major and urgent start on correcting those fundamental problems.

PARA.TAB: The tragedy that we face is that the Hawke Government seems to be unaware of what is happening and appears to be incapable of taking steps to start putting Australia back on the right road. The Government is so divided by leadership struggles, personality clashes, policy clashes and factional clashes that it has become a battle for survival of one job in Australia, and that is the job of the Prime Minister. At the same time as all this is happening, Australia has almost a million people who are unemployed and another 500,000-plus who are severely underemployed in this country. While that tragedy and human misery occur, we have a government—a so-called government—here in Canberra that can do nothing other than squabble and divide over the prime ministership. That is an indictment that will haunt this Hawke Labor Government for many years to come. Certainly it will haunt the Australian community because the Australian community is paying for it.

That is why Fightback! and the accompanying document that the coalition released last week are so fundamentally important. At last we have one side of politics that is prepared to say to the Australian people that they have a future, and a great future. We tell the people not to lose hope and to believe that they can overcome their problems. They need the support of government with proper programs, and there must be a vision for the future. Indeed, that is what this is all about. The present government, the Hawke Government, has no vision for the future. It appears to be absolutely incapable of developing that.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are not a vision; you are a nightmare.

—Senator Bolkus and his lot are the essential reasons why almost one million people are unemployed in this country, and why more than half a million people are underemployed. If Senator Bolkus and those on the front bench were able to be a team and to have some vision for this country, to give the people of this country some hope and opportunity, we would applaud them. They are obviously beyond any redemption in that sense.
—Shackled.

—Yes, those opposite are shackled, divided and bitter. Disunity, as Senator Bolkus knows, is death. It will mean the death of the Labor Government. But, sadly, it has meant the death of jobs and hope and opportunity in this country. The sooner Australia gets rid of this Government and gets on with proper policies and takes a united approach to the future, as soon as Australians are given hope and incentive and the prospect of a better life, the better it will be. The longer we leave doing that, the more difficult it will become because the more intractable will be the problems of which the present Government is guilty.

—I wish to make a few short remarks arising out of the contribution made by Senator Short. I know that both Senator Short and I serve the State of Victoria well, but I do not take Senator Short's pessimistic approach about our fellow citizens in Victoria. There is a myth going around Australia at the moment that we in Victoria have not got the gumption for the fight that many others have. I think that is quite wrong. There is a lot to be said for Victoria. We have great people in our State. I am thinking of, for example, Sir Gustav Nossal who is one of the foremost medical researchers in Australia.
—Dean Jones is about the best thing you can say about Victoria.

—Senator Baume is trying to be kind, but I think Dean Jones is one of many. I think that Victoria has a lot going for it. Senator Baume from north of the border may look with jaundiced eyes upon the great State of Victoria and make remarks that he does not feel are ungenerous. But they are in all the circumstances. Even Senator Bolkus, who is to the west of us, may not appreciate Victoria as much as he should, but I know that he comes to Victoria on a number of occasions.
— Steve Kernahan is the best you've got.

—Well, I will not comment on that. Certainly we must not get too depressed about what is happening in Victoria. For example, the Japanese have seen fit to put up a Daimaru store there, BHP is being run from there and Coles Myer and some of the largest firms in Australia are operating there.

PARA.TAB: Senator Short said that what happened to the State Savings Bank of Victoria and what happened to Trico was that Government's fault. That is Senator Short's opinion. It is not the opinion that has been expressed by the inquiry now being conducted by Sir Edward Woodward, who is an eminent judicial figure, a former member of the Federal Court of Australia, and before that the head of ASIO. Sir Edward, having looked at all the evidence, said that the blame was not to be placed at the feet of the Victorian Government, and specifically that neither John Cain nor Rob Jolly was responsible for what happened. I wish to put that on record. Furthermore, the issue of Pyramid is still under investigation.

Although it is to be expected that political points will be made in this chamber, it is proper to look at the outcomes of inquiries made by other than politicians and to rely on them. Certainly, in the circumstances of the State Bank and Trico, the inquiry headed, as I have said, by that eminent jurist, Sir Edward Woodward, has come to a conclusion different from that reached by Senator Short. In respect of Pyramid the evidence also seems to be that, if there was bad administration, it was the administration of Pyramid rather than that of the State Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join my colleague Senator Short in welcoming the annual report of the Commonwealth Bank. Very briefly, I want to make a few remarks about the state of the economy as outlined in the judgment of the Commonwealth Bank in its report. As Senator Short said, the bank noted that weaknesses in the economy are still affecting borrowers and are expected to continue for some time. I stress that point because it appears to be in some conflict with the Government's quaintly optimistic view that, to quote from the employment statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) of a couple of weeks ago, `everything is on track'. We are certainly not on track for any early recovery, according to the Commonwealth Bank, which goes on to say that the outlook continues to be very uncertain. The report further states:

SPEECH.PARA: Domestic production will need to outstrip domestic demand for some time if Australia is to overcome its balance of payments difficulties and enjoy sustainable economic growth.

What is the Government doing to create the requirement that domestic production will need to outstrip domestic demand which the bank says must happen? What is the Government doing to bring that about? We asked that question, in a way, at Question Time. We asked Senator Button what the Government was doing to restore full employment in Australia. The answer was nothing; in fact, there was no answer.

PARA.TAB: The fact is that this question has to be answered and the Commonwealth Bank's concerns must be met. One reason the Opposition has introduced a program of total reform of the financial and tax systems is to bring about this result that the bank says is necessary. We have a policy vacuum from those on the Government side, who are doing nothing except fighting amongst themselves about who should be the leader of the sinking ship. It is left to the Opposition to present the only policy options, the only policy alternatives, the only effective plan to meet the sorts of requirements that the Commonwealth Bank says must be met if we are to get out of our present economic crisis.

The Commonwealth Bank notes that we will have continuing unemployment, which will be a restraining factor in any signs of recovery that might emerge in such sectors as the housing sector. That is the Commonwealth Bank's judgment. What is the Government doing about that? It has no policies but, rather, a policy vacuum. That is one reason why the John Hewson-Tim Fischer policy of total reform in the coalition's Fightback program is to get rid of seven hidden Hawke taxes, which are inhibiting economic growth and development and having such a damaging impact on the prospects of economic recovery, and to replace them with one fair, honourable and evident tax. The Commonwealth Bank report continues:

SPEECH.PARA: The upturn in economic activity is likely to be more gradual than in previous recoveries.

That is a very pleasant way of saying that there will be no early recovery and that, when recovery does occur, it will be slow and hard and we will not have anything like the levels of recoveries in the past, largely because this Government has no way out and is offering no hope. That is one of the marvellous things that the Hewson-Fisher package—the coalition's Fightback package—does; it provides the only hope, because this Government is providing nothing. The report continues:
Business investment in plant and equipment is likely to be slower.

That is in terms of any kind of recovery. Yet it is business investment in plant and equipment that is the basis on which our hopes of increased job opportunities and increasing employment and economic recovery depend. As the bank says, this area is likely to be slower in its growth than other parts of economic recovery, which it underlines will be more gradual.

PARA.TAB: So we can see how, in the vacuum of policy this Government has created because of its internal divisions, the coalition has provided a whole set of coherent answers while the Government has none. In fact, the Government even has no answers to the coalition's policy, which was released last Thursday. Apart from the Prime Minister making a silly statement about fuel tax that has now been established to be totally wrong, the Government has no answers to that policy. It has no answers to the problems facing Australia and, on top of that, it has no coherent answers to the coalition's statement. At least the Opposition has provided the prospect of a coherent, positive answer, giving hope to the people of Australia and meeting the requirements for recovery that the Commonwealth Bank quite rightly points out are needed.

The Commonwealth Bank once again warns that weaknesses in the economy are expected to continue for some time. There is one reservation on that point. The economy will continue to be weak as long as this Government is in power. What is needed is a government that will give the Opposition's Fightback policies a go because they will give Australians a go.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Calvert)—In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the following report of the Auditor-General: Report No. 12 of 1991-92—Project Audit—Department of Employment, Education and Training—Management of Information Technology.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I will be very brief. The Auditor-General's Report No. 12 should give no-one any pleasure because it is highly critical of a department that has a very important role to play at a time of massive unemployment. The Department of Employment, Education and Training, following the employment statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) a couple of weeks ago, is now involved in a very important activity at a time when there are no jobs; that is, transforming undereducated dole queues into educated dole queues. That is an important task because, even though in the short run it may not do the young people of Australia much good, in the long run it may well increase their options in the job market, if and when this Government ever manages to have any policies that will create any real jobs. The employment statement of two weeks ago failed to do so. It is very depressing that when one reads this report one finds these conclusions:
The ANAO found that overall, management of IT in DEET had not been effective.

As these departments get more and more sophisticated in their requirements, there is a massive need for up to date information technology if they are to do their jobs properly. So the Auditor-General finds that management of this vital element of the Department's activities has not been effective. The report goes on:

PARA.TAB: during its initial two and a half years, DEET had no senior management committee to plan and set priorities for the use of information technology—the transfer of computer operations from Melbourne to Canberra jeopardised the effective operation of information technology services in DEET when 95% of the technical computing staff in Melbourne left the Department
an unsuccessful attempt to acquire a human resource management system resulted in a substantial waste of public money, and
parliamentary oversight of DEET's management of information technology had been hindered by excessive delay in responding to recommendations of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts.

SPEECH.PARA: The report continues:

DEET's experience suggests that agencies in planning and giving advice to Government on new policies or operational arrangements, must take account of the impact of proposals on existing Government information systems.
However, the report does say:

The ANAO acknowledges the very great difficulties that have confronted DEET as a new organisation in amalgamating several Government agencies and establishing an effective corporate IT management process.

All those separate matters are of some significance and indicate failures of management within that Department. Presumably those are failures that the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) should have known about and taken action on. If he did not know about them, he has clear failings as a Minister, because this has been going on for quite some time.

PARA.TAB: Back in September 1985, the Auditor-General levelled some major criticisms at the adequacy of planning, cost-benefit analysis and management of the development of the Job Bank system in this Department's predecessor. In particular, organisational and management infrastructure required to support the application of information technology in the Department was, according to the Auditor-General, undeveloped and inadequate. The Auditor-General's report of 1989-90 reported that early administration of the Austudy program involved a major imbalance acting against taxpayers' interests. So there was nothing unexpected about the fact that there were problems in this area. What did the Government do about it? The answer is: absolutely nothing.

The report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts on the Job Seeker project, which was published in June 1986, was followed by a delay of more than three years before the Finance minute containing responses from the Department, from the Department of Finance and from the Department of Administrative Services was published in the Joint Committee of Public Accounts report of November 1989. The Audit Office considers that the delay impeded parliamentary oversight of administrative performance. So back in 1989 we had more examples of bad management. Of course, this situation went on. We can see what has occurred when we look at the transfer of the computer systems for this Department from Melbourne to Canberra. The Auditor-General says of this great move:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the original objective of achieving efficiency through the consolidation of functions and accommodation in a single building in Canberra remains to be achieved. . .
He goes on:
. . . the relocation of the Systems Division and the Melbourne computer centre severely disrupted the planning and management of information technology in the Department.

PARA.TAB: The staffing of the Systems Division was fundamentally affected by the relocation; only 12 of the 213 Systems Division staff in Melbourne accepted a transfer to Canberra. One result of the loss of staff was the suspension of some elements of basic management functions including strategic and implementation planning.

SPEECH.PARA: The Auditor-General further says:
. . . despite the extensive use of contract staff, many functions essential—
not just important—
for the effective management and operation of DEET's IT systems have not, and could not, be pursued.
The Auditor-General concludes on this area that:

. . . the Department was without appropriate and sufficient resources for a considerable period and was unable to give adequate attention to planning, organisation development and other essential but long range management tasks.

The extraordinary thing about this is that this movement took place despite the recommendations of a committee, which was supposed to supervise this and make recommendations, that further consideration be given to the question of the location of the computer centre, taking into account any decisions made in relation to the Department's information technology strategic plan before the move took place. Nevertheless, as the Auditor-General notes, the transfer proceeded before the Department had sufficient opportunity to settle its strategic requirements. The key point, as the report states, is that:
It should be noted that there was no technical requirement for the immediate relocation of computer operations even if the remainder of the Department was relocated to Canberra.

This was just one of a great host of ludicrous decisions, because it was estimated overall that about one-third of the staff would transfer to Canberra, which was totally contrary to a survey conducted by the relevant staff association which indicated that 91 per cent would not transfer and 4 per cent were uncertain that they would transfer.

PARA.TAB: So we have this decimation of skill and an inability to implement the requirements of the move, leaving the Department in absolute chaos. As a result, the planning process of the Department had not ensured adequate coordination between the plans of program managers and the plans of the systems division. There were totally wrong estimates of costs of doing a whole range of things. The Audit Office concluded that there was reasonable evidence that the implementation of modes of devolved management in the Department had not proceeded with full regard to the requirements of the efficient overall planning and provision of information technology services.

After all these problems, we then find more evidence of mismanagement. In January 1990, the Department had to suspend the acquisition of a human resource management system called PRISM. The acquisition was to involve three separate but interdependent contracts for the supply of software products, but this had to be suspended when the combination of products could not be made operational. There is some terrific, effective, efficient bureaucratic bungling. The report goes on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: The acquisition was suspended after an endeavour spanning three and a half years, the expenditure of $475,000 in software licence fees, additional contractual obligations of an uncertain amount but possibly amounting to $140,000, and the costs of departmental staff who were engaged in the project.

The Auditor-General did not estimate the costs of departmental staff. So here we have at least $600,000 in wasted money because this Department could not proceed with a computer acquisition because it simply would not work. As the Auditor-General reports:
The acquisition was eventually frustrated through a technical failure.

It is not clear to the Auditor-General that the risks associated with using this system in the Department's technical environment were thoroughly appraised when the decision was taken to use the combination of these three separate but interdependent systems—PRISM, PICK and VM. The report goes on:

The tender evaluation report was deficient to the extent that it did not indicate that the implementation of PRISM would need to be carefully managed to minimise the risks inherent in using several technologies which were new to the Department.

Contributing technical risks were that the proposed combination was outside the Department's technical strategy; the combination was unproven; and, in any event, the Department had lost most of its technical staff because of the move from Melbourne.

PARA.TAB: On top of this there was a whole range of different people on the purchasing side, along with a whole range of different people on the suppliers side. The Auditor-General's report states:

SPEECH.PARA: In the circumstances the risk of an unsatisfactory outcome was increased by the difficulty of achieving co-ordinated action by all the parties.

Amongst the suppliers there was no prime contractor to accept the overall responsibility for providing a fully operable combination of products which satisfied DEET's requirements. But it gets even worse. A failure to finalise the contract with Panache, one of the companies involved, before proceeding to accept services from that contractor left the particular obligations of each party uncertain, especially in the event that one or other of the contractors failed to perform its contractual obligation. So here we have disaster on top of disaster. There was not a proper contract that was properly signed.

PARA.TAB: Although the Department was aware, according to the Auditor-General, of the need to draft contracts in such a way as to deal with non-performance or delayed performance, delay in concluding the contracts with the several parties created a situation in which the Commonwealth's interests were not protected. The report also states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the incompleteness of certain aspects of the contract can create uncertainty about the rights and obligations of the parties.

The Audit Office noted that the Joint Committee of Public Accounts had already criticised this kind of behaviour where there had been the proceeding with complex computer acquisitions before the completion of formal contracts. That had been criticised on the Jobseeker acquisition. The report further states:

The ANAO concluded that the selection of PRISM would have been justified had the technical risks which flowed from the use of new technologies been recognised and managed appropriately. The ANAO formed the view that the risks may have been managed more successfully if the transfer of Systems Division functions from Melbourne, and the urgency with which the Management Division pursued implementation of PRISM, had not combined to diminish the involvement of the Systems Division in the later stages of the acquisition of implementation.
The Auditor-General now recommends that various action be taken so that this sort of thing does not happen again.

PARA.TAB: The report notes that the Department of Administrative Services has advised that the failure of the Department of Employment, Education and Training to achieve successful operations of the PRISM package was not unique. It goes on to say that the introduction of such packages into the Public Service had produced other similar results. It gets worse and worse. The Audit Office now says that, where a contract is of such value or complexity that the requisitioning agency prepares written specifications and requires interested suppliers to present comprehensive written tenders or expressions of interest, a complete written agreement should be concluded before the acquisition proceeds. Is it not incredible that the Auditor-General has to say that one has to sign a contract before paying for or having the goods delivered and that it is a good idea to sign a contract first? One would think that the Auditor-General would not have to tell any government that is the basic way to do business. But this Government and this Department have to be told by the Auditor-General that they had better do that sort of thing, which is a basic requirement of people conducting normal business activity.

So all in all, it is a pretty depressing report from the Auditor-General. It is a pretty depressing comment on the competence of the management of the Minister in this Department and, I might say, a pretty damaging comment about the ability of this Government's Ministers to know what is going on in their own departments. That lack of ability may explain why this Government is making such a mess of the whole economy.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beahan Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities on use indemnity provisions in the corporations law and Australian Securities Commission law.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Securities Commission took over the role of Australia's corporate regulator in January of this year from the NCSC. The ASC was designed to be a more effective regulator. It is better funded, is designed to be more responsive to the needs of the business community, is designed to be more directly accountable to this Parliament—hence the setting up of the Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities from which, of course, this is the first report—and is designed to have a more uniform approach to corporate law with Australia-wide powers. To give effect to these expectations, the ASC was given, in the words of the former Attorney-General, Lionel Bowen, `strengthened inspection and investigation powers compared with those of the NCSC'. These included the power to hold hearings and to gather information on the conduct of companies and securities transactions.

PARA.TAB: In granting these powers the legislation prevents the answers to questions at a hearing, the fact of the production of a document, or `any information, document or other thing' gathered as a result of those answers—that is, material derived from those answers—being admissible in any subsequent prosecution of the person being questioned. This derivative use immunity, as it is referred to, represents an extension of the protection offered to witnesses before ASC inquiries when one compares this with similar provisions in the old Companies Code.

The Australian Securities Commission and the Director of Public Prosecutions in a joint submission to the inquiry argued that this derivative use immunity effectively renders its investigative powers worthless where criminal prosecutions are contemplated. One of the witnesses described the ASC's investigating powers under the current law as `a poisoned chalice—since you get the investigative power and if you use it you kill off your ability to bring a criminal action in some cases'. The problem was anticipated in evidence before the Joint Select Committee on Corporations Legislation by the NCSC. The NCSC said at that time that section 68(3)—which is one of the sections that we are addressing in this report—`will make the compulsive powers of the ASC virtually useless'.

As a result of their experience of working with the new law over the past year, the ASC and the Director of Public Prosecutions have recommended that corporations law and the ASC law be amended to remove the derivative use immunity and the use immunity relating to the production of a document. This is essentially a return to the status quo ante. It would, in effect, restore the level of protection provided by the old Companies Code. There is nothing unique about that. The tax Act at section 264 and the Trade Practices Act at section 155(7) removed the right to silence and in return provided limited indemnity but not derivative use immunity. If this change being proposed by the DPP and the ASC and supported by the Committee were adopted, answers to questions would be inadmissible where the witness claimed the privilege against self-incrimination before answering. However, derivative information gathered as a result of those answers would be admissible in a criminal prosecution of the person giving the answers, as would any documents provided by that person.

The Committee had to strike a balance between two competing public interests. On the one hand, there is the need to have a properly regulated corporate sector in which both investors and the community can have confidence and, on the other, the preservation of the established common law right against self-incrimination. It is the view of the majority of the Committee that that balance should be struck in favour of effective enforcement of the law and, thus, we have recommended in favour of the ASC-DPP proposals. Our reasons for reaching this conclusion relate principally to the nature of corporate crime and the special difficulties it poses for law enforcement. But they relate, secondly, to what we see as the importance of successful criminal prosecutions, for the standing of the ASC and for the consequent standing of the business community resulting from these prosecutions.

Corporations are legally privileged entities created by statute. They benefit from limited liability and the right to raise funds from the public. That privileged position carries with it obligations which may involve curtailing some of the rights of those who benefit from it. Mr Justice Rodgers, the Chief Justice of the Commercial Division of the Supreme Court of New South Wales, recently argued that the obligation extends to explaining:

SPEECH.PARA: what happened, why it happened, what was done by the executives in carrying on the business, even if the disclosures mean that civil or criminal liability may be proved against the person. . . Anyone who chooses to undertake the privileges of such office should be ready to explain the circumstances surrounding the discharge of statutory and fiduciary duties.

Similar sentiments were expressed by the judge in the recent Guinness prosecution in the UK, which conviction was upheld on appeal. I will not quote the judgment in full because it is very lengthy, but I draw the attention of honourable senators to submission No. 9 to the inquiry by Mr Santow, which quotes parts of the judgment. It is a very compelling argument in explanation of why the law was changed in the UK in the way we are suggesting it should be changed in Australia. That same witness to the Committee, an experienced lawyer in private practice in Australia, described the unique features of corporate crime in the following way:
Corporate crime is unlike conventional crime in at least three respects:

(a)the immediate victim, the company, is an inanimate legal fiction often controlled by the perpetrator at the time, unlike the human victim of theft. There is therefore typically no human victim with direct familiarity with the circumstances—so that the prosecution is forced to rely on the perpetrator for evidence, and

(b) for this reason and because of the complexity of the facts, documentary evidence is essential. But it is only useful if it can be identified and explained by the perpetrator and by other enquiries yielding other evidence not precluded by derivative use immunity,
(c)unlike ordinary theft, the accused has generally exploited the privilege of carrying on business with limited liability using the public's money, either as a shareholder or creditor.

The Committee is sensitive to the need to preserve traditional rights and responsibilities. However, it is also aware that society has evolved in directions undreamt of when many of these traditional rights were established. The law is not static and immutable, as some would seem to claim that it is. It is dynamic. It must evolve and develop with changing circumstances or become impotent. This is something that is recognised both in the USA and in the UK where they deal with the matter in different ways, some of which we agree with and others with which, as I will show later, we do not.

PARA.TAB: Our second reason for recommending in favour of the ASC-DPP position is the perceived importance to the standing of the ASC and, as a consequence, of the business community of successful criminal prosecutions. There is little doubt that the public perception of the ASC as an effective corporate regulator will be greatly enhanced if successful prosecutions can be mounted against some of the more notable thieves of the 1980s.

There is a high public expectation of this. That is not to say that the main thrust of the ASC should not be civil. Nor is it to say that that is in fact the case. The internal briefings of the ASC make it very clear that its main thrust is civil, to try to protect the invested funds or the creditors' funds as a first move, but that if matters arising out of those investigations show that there has been criminal negligence criminal action should follow. It is not a primary action but a secondary or consequent one. But it is very important in terms of the standing of the ASC and the business community.

If one asks the average person in the street whether the much hallowed and, I must say, often overstated right against self-incrimination should be allowed to frustrate prosecutions against the crooks of the 1980s, the answer—whether one is in Pitt Street, Bourke Street or Hay Street in Perth—would be a very decisive no.

There is a great deal of anger about the perception that these people are thumbing their noses at governments, at the courts and at the community; that they are living the same luxurious lifestyles that they were used to through their heydays in the 1980s, despite being bankrupt or technically bankrupt; or that they are escaping scrutiny altogether in secluded villas in Spain. There is a great deal of anger but, importantly, there is also, as a consequence, a lack of confidence in a system which allows this to happen.

The problem is not unique to Australia. A reading of the Roskill committee report in the UK shows how closely the UK has been mirroring the sorts of concerns that we have had and what it has done about it. The report states in its introduction:

SPEECH.PARA: The public no longer believes that the legal system in England and Wales is capable of bringing the perpetrators of serious frauds expeditiously and effectively to book. The overwhelming weight of the evidence laid before us suggests that the public is right. In relation to such crimes, and to the skilful and determined criminals who commit them, the present legal system is archaic, cumbersome and unreliable. At every stage, during investigation, preparation, committal, pre-trial review and trial, the present arrangements offer an open invitation to blatant delay and abuse. While petty frauds, clumsily committed, are likely to be detected and punished, it is all too likely that the largest and most cleverly executed crimes escape unpunished. The Government has encouraged and continues to encourage ordinary families to invest their savings in the equity markets, particularly in the equities of formerly state-owned enterprises. If the Government cherishes the vision of an `equity-owning democracy', then it also faces an inescapable duty to ensure that financial markets are honestly managed, and that transgressors in these markets are swiftly and effectively discovered, convicted and punished. Self-regulatory mechanisms designed to encourage honest practices are now coming into force. Where those mechanisms are abused, the law must deliver retribution, swift and sure.
It follows that fundamental change is required in certain areas of the law.
That change has occurred in England and it has allowed prosecutions which have been thwarted here by the impediments to which this Committee report refers.

PARA.TAB: It is also neither sensible nor realistic, as claimed in the minority report, to expect that derivative use immunity should have been tested before the courts before any change is recommended. For a start, a test case before the High Court is likely to take anything between three and five years—with my bet being closer to the five years than the three.

The effect of such a delay would be that the major players in the scams, the frauds and the thefts of the 1980s would get away scot-free. This would leave people wondering whether the ASC is capable of regulating the corporate sector. It does not matter how good the work it has done elsewhere, if it is not seen to have prosecuted some of these perceived criminals who are so prominently thumbing their noses at the courts, it will be judged harshly by the public. The law in these circumstances would be regarded correctly as an ass.

In the USA, where the right to silence is enshrined in the Constitution, the law has developed some interesting mechanisms to get around the problems posed in prosecuting corporate criminals. Racketeering legislation—the so-called RICO Act—involves the seizure of the total assets of the accused to compel plea bargaining. This was how the junk bond dealer, Michael Milliken, and others were convicted in recent cases.

It is the view of the majority of the Committee that properly regulated hearings in which evidence is gathered represents a far lesser threat to individual rights and liberties than the threat provided by such backdoor methods of prosecution. It needs to be borne in mind that ASC hearings are not, despite the views of some witnesses and some members of the Committee, star chamber investigations. Hearings under corporations law are conducted before courts at the request of the ASC and witnesses are protected by the procedures of the court. Hearings conducted by the ASC itself are also subject to strict controls. Participants may be legally represented. They are entitled to a fair warning of the hearing and of the matter under investigation, and there is a set of procedures produced by the ASC covering all of this.

A witness who is not satisfied that the ASC is conducting the hearing in accordance with its statutory responsibilities—or, for that matter, normally accepted practices—may refuse to cooperate. In the recent Titan Hills case, for example, representatives of a company under investigation were of the view that the notice requesting their attendance was inadequate and they simply refused to attend. The ASC then had to seek a court order compelling their attendance and the court sided with Titan Hills.

It should also be recognised that these examinations are not trials at which a person is being compelled to confess to some crime. They are information gathering exercises which may yield evidence admissible in court. The evidence is then open to challenge in the normal processes of the judicial system.

The Committee recognises the importance of these fundamental rights and does not believe they should be removed lightly. It does believe, however, that on balance there is a good case for returning to the protections afforded under the old Companies Code. In this regard, the argument put by some that perhaps the problem might be solved by the removal of the use immunity as it applies to documents is a nonsense, since the documents themselves are often useless unless their significance can be verified by verbal or other evidence which would still be subject to derivative use immunity.

In recommending the changes, the Committee will continue to monitor the ASC's use of its investigatory powers. It has also recommended that the proposed amendments include a sunset clause that will require positive action to confirm the amendments in the next Parliament.

The effect of leaving legislation as it is, as some would have it, and of effectively relegating the ASC to civil redress cannot be accepted. As I have already indicated, it would mean that Parliament is washing its hands of the problem of community expectations with regard to the effectiveness of the ASC. It would mean that it is prepared to take a risk that the standing of the ASC and, as a consequence, of the business community, would be severely damaged. It would mean that, unlike the UK, the Australian Parliament refuses to recognise that there are fundamental differences between conventional crime and corporate crime. It would mean that the Parliament refuses to recognise that the law is a dynamic and changing thing and that it must evolve and develop if it is to remain viable and to win community respect.

The Committee believes the checks and balances it has introduced will more than adequately protect people's rights and liberties in the light of the minor changes proposed. The Committee is in fact suggesting the very moderate step of returning to the situation which existed under the former Companies Code. In that context, I find it hard to understand why a minority report should have been necessary, although I guess I will very shortly find out why from Senator Cooney. I commend the report to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The challenge has been thrown out. We have been asked, `Why did the minority disagree?'. In answer, I say that, in my view, the right to silence, like a lot of other great principles of our law, is worth preserving. There is always a terrible temptation for government to rush in when it sees that there is a vice to be cured. Sometimes it does so in a way that puts at risk some of the great principles by which we live in a free and democratic society.

PARA.TAB: I give as an illustration—and I say this in a non-partisan way—what happened recently in Queensland where, because of a jury result in that State, there was a cry from government that the system should be at least examined, perhaps set aside and perhaps new rules brought in. That might seem all right to some people in respect of a particular case. But, overall, one has cause for concern once the principles upon which this society of ours depends start to be eroded. An erosion of a particular principle can then be used as a precedent for further erosions.

It is significant that the precedents Senator Beahan quoted in support of a change to the common law respecting the right to silence were pieces of legislation passed through this Parliament. It concerns me that we as a parliament pass legislation to modify the traditional principles we live by and then use that legislation as a precedent for a further erosion of liberties. Five years down the track someone may come along and say, `We want to take away a process considered up to now to be proper for fair investigation'. If there is an objection to that, he or she will say, `Look, why do you object? A similar thing was done five years ago'. So, there is a precedent established by what is now being done under protest.

Senator Beahan is right—a balance must be struck between the public interest in protecting individual rights and the public interest in seeing that the good of the community is promoted. The majority of the members of the Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities have said that it is for the good of the community that people—not only in the corporate field but, I should imagine, generally—should act ethically and morally, and with skill and diligence. However, it is also good for the community that its members should be able to go about their business freely without being harassed by the state, without being unduly suppressed by government and without being watched by a regime that is a shadow—no matter how pale it may be—of that described so well by George Orwell in his book 1984. I do not suggest for one minute that that is what is happening here. But I do say that one of the central features of the work of Orwell was that people could be questioned under duress—although I am not suggesting that that is the same sort of duress that is suggested in the present circumstances.

It is in the interests of our great traditions that I opted in this case to adhere to the right to silence. I come back to this point because I think it is interesting: the only precedent that can be quoted for a breach of the right to silence is the precedent that this Parliament itself has set in respect of the cooperative scheme with the States.

If corporate crime is so bad in the sense that it brings about bad results for the economy, that somehow it diminishes the corporate sector and that somehow companies are now faced with ruin or at least with a diminution of fortune, people in this chamber have been very quiet about it. We on this side tend to blame the Opposition for our economic problems; the Opposition is constantly on the attack, saying that it is the Government's fault. I rely on such people as Senator Baume to correct me but even in its new document I do not think the coalition has alleged that corporate crime has brought about our present economic difficulties.

It is stated in the report that the Director of Public Prosecutions and the Australian Securities Commissioner find that they have difficulty in proceeding against wrongdoers. Of course they would say that. We would all like to see our jobs made easier. But where is the compelling evidence that we can look to and say, `Here is a course of conduct; here is a series of illustrations of where the present law has not produced a proper result'? If we are going to make a dramatic change in the law—and that is what we are doing here—should we not be blessed with some sort of compelling evidence to show that the perpetrators of corporate crime have so shaken the economy as to make it necessary to surrender traditional rights?

There is a lot of evidence to the contrary that has to be taken into account. In that context, I would like to quote from an article by Mr John Coldrey, as he then was, Mr Justice Coldrey of the Supreme Court of Victoria, as he is now. When he was Director of Public Prosecutions in Melbourne, he had this to say about the right to silence:

SPEECH.PARA: Broadly speaking, this right has been recognised by the common law since the end of the 17th Century. For the past 300 years it has formed an integral part of the English criminal justice system and those that are based upon it. For much of those 300 years the concept has been criticised, yet it has survived and still has widespread support today. It is not unreasonable therefore to cast upon those who seek its abolition (or at least its curtailment) the onus of justifying the necessity for change.

I am not too sure that one can justify throwing aside 300 years of tradition by saying that people in the streets are very unhappy about how corporate criminals go about their business and that the people are baying for blood. If we are going to satisfy everybody's lust for blood, where will we be?

PARA.TAB: There has been an increase in the sorts of powers we give to investigative bodies such as the Independent Commission Against Corruption in New South Wales and the National Crime Authority. We load investigative authorities with more and more powers to tap telephones, for example. Where does it stop? It creates a quite unsavoury mood and, as I said before, recent events in Queensland are an illustration of that.

The other thing that has to be remembered is that people say, `Corporate crime is very bad; therefore we will change the law in respect of it. It is a crime that is different from other sorts of crime; therefore we will deal differently with it'. But if we are talking about how people in the street react to crime, what about a ghastly murder or an act of incest or a dreadful rape or a kidnapping or an awful burglary? Why are those crimes of such a nature that they do not attract a change in the law, yet corporate crime in some way does? It is sought to distinguish that sort of crime by saying that it is more important to preserve the economic integrity of the community and to look after our international trade than it is to preserve the lives and reputations and bodily integrity of our citizens. That seems to me to be what is being said here.

That proposition might cause some concern; but what causes even more concern is the fact that there is no compelling evidence that the proposition is correct. The National Crime Authority, the Director of Public Prosecutions and the Australian Securities Commission seem to be able, on the basis of the logic in this report, to come before a parliamentary committee and say, `We want more powers'; and we say, `Yes, very good; you can have the powers'. Let us hope that they do not come asking for too many more powers because we might become so supine that we will be willing to abolish not only the right to silence but also all those other protections that keep our society decent, free and fair, as it is today.

The right to silence can be easily set aside. Perhaps Senator Beahan might have given the example of what has happened in some trials in Northern Ireland, where a person's silence has been taken to be an admission of guilt. I happen to know that that sort of thing causes judges considerable concern. It was related to me that one judge in particular came to a conclusion of guilt on the basis that a person had stood mute, and that concerned him considerably. So it is not only the public generally but also the people who have to administer the law who are concerned by these sorts of erosions.

Time is on the wing. I have put forward my proposition and I have criticised the majority for not adhering to our great principles as strongly as it might have done. In answer to the demands of the people in the street who, quite properly, want to see criminals gaoled and who do not like people who are in Spain and criminals elsewhere getting away with their misdeeds, apparently we are going to change ancient principles. Before we label people criminals, it would be good if we were to go through the proper process to prove them to be so. When propositions are made on the basis that people are criminals before the process is over and done with, it becomes a matter for concern. It is a little like the Alice in Wonderland trial, where the verdict comes first and the trial afterwards.

Having said that, I add that this Committee is quite an outstanding one. I congratulate Senator Beahan, not on the result of the inquiry but on the way in which he has chaired the Committee. He has chaired it very well; it is a good Committee. I mention also Senator Lewis, who has been an able Deputy Chairman. The other members in this chamber are me, Senator Ian Campbell and Senator Sid Spindler. In the other House, the members are the Hon. Laurie Brereton and Mr Frank Ford, who is quite a genius because he agreed with me on this matter, as did Senator Campbell. That shows that there are people with great intellectual ability on this Committee. Other members are Mr Duncan Kerr, the Hon. John Moore and the Hon. Gary Punch.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are there any with brevity?

—The other thing that worries me a little is that one comes into this chamber now and then and an economist who sits down there gets up week after week and talks nothing but economics, as if it is the be all and end all, the light on the hill. He goes on and on. As soon as one gets up and starts talking about civil liberties and the great traditions of English law that protect this community, one gets this sort of thing. It happened on the Committee.
—Cold-hearted computers.

—It is a time of computers; it worries me. It also goes to show how effective the speech has been. It has not been effective at all. Concepts of decency, concepts of liberty, concepts of fairness, concepts of trying to protect people from the outrageous conduct of the state bring this sort of thing—`Will you sit down and shut up'. As Senator McMullan invited me to do that, I had better sit down and let him get on with his economic theories. Apparently, that is what is going to save us, that is what makes us human beings and that is what preserves us as real, decent people. Perhaps heaven is the only place where we can get away from economists.
—You can be assured there won't be any up there.
—That is the reason I am going there.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
