DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Parliamentary Delegation to Ireland and the European Institutions

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I table the report of the parliamentary delegation to Ireland and the European institutions. It is with great pleasure that I bring to the Senate this report of the delegation. We had hoped to table it on Thursday last, but the great amount of business that was before the Senate meant that it was deferred until today.

PARA.TAB: I recognise the presence in the gallery tonight of the Ambassador for Ireland, Mr Martin Burke, and the Charge d'Affaires for the European Communities, Mr Roderick Skinner. Right from the beginning, when the delegation from this Parliament was first nominated, they have taken a special interest in ensuring that we were well informed and that we had a good pathway to achieve our purposes in our visit to the European institutions and particularly to Ireland.

I note that this report is unanimous. It represents the work of five members of the House of Representatives and three senators—Senator Harradine, Senator McKiernan and me. We found the delegation to be most productive and useful. Having been in this chamber for more than 13 years, I have been happy to be on many parliamentary delegations. This is the one that I have valued the most in that we achieved a very real increase in our personal knowledge of the parliamentary and government institutions in Europe. It was a perfect delight not only to do that in Ireland but also to enjoy the people and to build on the enormous warmth and common feeling, common knowledge and common heritage that we in Australia have with the people of Ireland.

This report is in five parts. The first part deals with our visit to Ireland. We were the guests of the Parliament in Dublin for eight days. We were received by parliamentarians in various parts of the countryside, as well as in the capital city. We were received by the government, a number of commercial and industrial bodies and the university. The second part of the report concerns the European Parliament; that is, the 12 nations represented in the Parliament in Strasbourg. The third part of the report deals with our visit to the Council of Europe, also in Strasbourg, which comprises 24 nations.

Our fourth activity was to attend the Strasbourg Conference on Democracy where some 70 countries were represented. Hundreds of parliamentarians from around the world focused on democracy and how to promote it in the world; especially on our mind was eastern Europe and the recent changes there. We also looked at the Caribbean, Central America, Africa and Asia.

The fifth part of our report deals with our visit to Brussels where we went, as it were, to the government of Europe. We met with the European Commission and Council of Ministers and a number of other organisations. We had a full day with the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation. At this particular time NATO is redefining and giving a more current focus to its purposes and rationale now that we have seen the end of the Cold War. We had a number of other visits in Brussels of significance to us, such as to the Belgian Parliament. We also went to Ypres where at the Menin Gate we laid a wreath on behalf of Australians in memory of the 10,000 Australians who died during the First World War in that battlefield.

I refer briefly to some of the conclusions that are set out in the report following the delegation's visit to these five areas of Europe. First, I note that, in my mind, there were really two purposes for the delegation. We refer to these at the beginning of our conclusions. These two purposes were to familiarise ourselves with the European parliamentary and government institutions so that as Australian parliamentarians we could add more detail and more directness to our previous knowledge. For us, this was an invaluable gain. Fifteen per cent of Australia's exports go to Europe and we want to see that proportion increase. Europe is still the largest source of foreign investment in Australia. Of course, we have a huge cultural and linguistic heritage in common with Europe that leads us to have ready access to each other and to build.

The second overriding purpose was for us, as Australian parliamentarians, to reinforce Australian views about our national interest in Europe. That focuses almost entirely—our resources were limited, given the time that we were there—on one issue; that is, to achieve our purposes in GATT and in the Uruguay Round; to see a freer world trading community, in particular where Europe and the United States both agree to lower their high tariff barriers to many of our products, particularly agricultural products. In focusing upon Europe, every day of our visit we made it very clear, particularly in debates in the chamber in Strasbourg, in our meeting with the Council of Ministers in Brussels and in other ways, that we want to see the end of the common agricultural policy.

When I say that, I am very aware that the policy was the foundation of the European Community; it led to its formation. One of the transitional commitments of the European nations was to have a common agricultural policy that would hold Europe together. That purpose has been achieved, and at last we are starting to see the Europeans themselves wanting to move on to enable, for their own advantage, the CAP to be replaced by a freer trade system. We are all holding our breath to see the outcome of the Uruguay Round, but I would like to think that our parliamentary delegation in Europe played its part in reinforcing what the Government, the Opposition and all of the industrial groups in Australia have been putting to the Europeans and to the Americans over many years now.

I believe that we need to continue this pressure until we achieve our goal. Our first conclusion, set out on the introductory page v, is that we must maintain dialogue, we must be persuasive by showing the genuineness of our arguments. Without going over that here, I believe that there will be lower prices and lower taxes for Europeans as they move away from the common agricultural policy towards a freer trade situation. We need to reinforce that by every means possible, not only diplomatic, not only in terms of industrial meetings, but also by parliamentarians meeting with European parliamentarians and by our seeing European parliamentary delegations coming to Australia.

It is with this in mind that the delegation recommends that the annual visits by Australian delegations be maintained and that, similarly, the frequency of delegations from the European Parliament also be maintained. We believe it is also important that persons such as the Agricultural Commissioner, Mr McSharry, be invited as official guests of the Australian Government to this country on a fact-finding basis to reinforce our arguments as to why the common agricultural policy needs to be abandoned in Europe.

Towards that end, let me say that I bring to the Senate's attention, if it is not already in the minds of senators present, a pamphlet entitled Are You Paying Too Much? which was released by the Australian Government while we were in Europe, and we saw something of its immediate impact. On behalf of the Opposition, I join the Government in supporting this document. The arguments it sets out fairly and squarely reveal factually to Europeans that they will pay lower prices and lower taxes if they allow freer trade such that our agricultural products can be sent to the European market. I do not have time to refer to the information in this pamphlet, so I ask leave of the Senate to table this document.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I refer to just one fact: in Europe it is still cheaper to buy two sides of lamb from Australia, even if flown to Europe on a first-class Qantas seat, than it is to buy the local, hugely subsidised product.
—It will be better too.

—It would also be better. We have to make that point to the Europeans. I am not calling for too rapid change or change that lacks compassion; there must be transitional arrangements. Fortunately, in Ireland for example, we saw some transitions. The service industry is growing in Dublin; accounting mechanisms are being very profitably based there; a tourist development is reviving an old mid-nineteenth century canal. In Europe, countries are finding the things that they are good at and doing them at international prices. No longer are we seeing Europeans squandering their own resources and the taxpayers' money by continuing with an outdated and counterproductive common agricultural policy. I recommend the bringing of displays of Australian produce to the market places of Europe—we refer to that in our recommendation—and the publishing of booklets such as the one that I have tabled.

PARA.TAB: I conclude my remarks by referring to just three other matters briefly. With regard to Ireland, I could speak at length. I speak warmly about Ireland as a person who, although having a name common in Ireland, is of Cornish descent; my great grandfather came from Cornwall. Whilst there is this common Celtic link, I do not have the same direct Irish ancestry as, say, Senator McKiernan or Senator Harradine, who I hope will be speaking in just a few moments. Yet I went to Ireland with the feeling of all Australians that the Irish have had an enormous part in the building of Australia and have brought so much that is positive, including humour, humanity and a sense of fairness that I really warm to. I can become very emotional, particularly when some of those themes are included in an Irish song and there is a bit of Murphy's about.

I want to refer to one particular serious and topical matter, and that is the International Fund for Ireland. One of the tasks we set ourselves was to gain some first-hand knowledge of this fund and how it operates. The United Kingdom and the United States, with Ireland, have been big contributors to the fund. Up to this point, Australia has not contributed. The delegation has unanimously concluded that it is a sound project that we ought to contribute towards. I just read the report's conclusion:

SPEECH.PARA: The delegation therefore recommends that the government commences negotiations with the UK and Irish governments with a view to making a contribution to the International Fund for Ireland.

I finally refer to the Strasbourg Conference on Democracy and to the scrutiny of multilateral organisations. With regard to democracy, I remain, as an Australian parliamentarian, excited about democracy. I believe that it is the determination of free peoples that leads to the best government and the most prosperity for those peoples. Indeed, it leads to the best peace in the world. A former member of the House of Representatives, Dr Klugman, once put forward the thesis that no democracies had gone to war. I support democracy for all sorts of positive reasons, such as those to which I have referred.

PARA.TAB: The Conference on Democracy that was initiated by the Council of Europe in Strasbourg has had several meetings now. There is a call for a meeting to be held in Asia and for us to focus upon what we can contribute to enhancing democracy in the countries of Asia. It was a request put to us in the delegation that Australia consider hosting such a conference. We have recommended that:

SPEECH.PARA: . . .subject to the satisfactory resolution of funding arrangements, the Presiding Officers give consideration to hosting the first Asian/Pacific Regional Colloquy Conference on Democracy to be held in October 1992.

The last point to which I refer is the parliamentary scrutiny of multilateral aid organisations. We took part in a debate on the floor of the chamber in Strasbourg along with all the Europeans, the 24 nations, in an examination of the OECD annual report. The Secretary General, Mr Claude Paye, was present and gave a speech. We asked questions of him. It was a very mild and introductory form of a Senate Estimates committee, but it was one where many nations' parliamentarians were examining on an annual basis an important report of an important body—the OECD. I believe that we ought to see more of that and that we ought to see that applied to the World Bank, to the International Monetary Fund and to the principal programs of the United Nations, such as UNDP. I believe that there are ways to do this. I set out this matter in more detail in a paper I gave 10 days ago here in Canberra to the annual forum of AIDAB. I ask leave to table that paper.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I wish to thank our hosts who looked after us in Ireland and Europe. I thank the staff who assisted us as a delegation, both before we left and while we were travelling for four weeks in Europe. I also thank my colleagues. The leader of the delegation, Ron Edwards, did a superb job—as did each member of the delegation. I believe that all eight of us contributed significantly to the success of the delegation. It was a pleasure to travel with all of them.

PARA.TAB: Finally, I give notice that in the coming week I will refer to the opportunity I had on my way to join the delegation to visit Turkey where I was able to follow up a number of matters with the government there and to visit Gallipoli. I also had the opportunity on my return trip to Australia to make a personal visit to the United Kingdom, to spend four days in Moscow—with a similar agenda to that of the Foreign Minister during his visit last week—and then to visit Mongolia and Beijing. These visits, which were valuable to me personally, were made possible by being a member of the delegation to Europe. I thank all those people associated with the delegation's work. I thoroughly commend our report to the Senate and to the nation.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Prior to this debate, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) reminded me of the need for brevity in view of the amount of legislation that is before the Senate. I omitted to tell him that Senator Teague, Senator Harradine and I actually kissed the Blarney stone. I think Senator McMullan, with his name and heritage, would understand what I am saying. Perhaps there is fear in his heart as he continues to look at the clock during the course of my contribution to the debate this evening.

PARA.TAB: I was privileged to be a member of the Australian parliamentary delegation to Ireland and the European institutions in September of this year. My first duty, like that of my colleague Senator Teague, who has just spoken, is to thank those who participated in that delegation. For the sake of brevity, I will not name each and every one of them, but I thank them all the same.
I also thank the Parliament for giving me the opportunity to participate in this delegation. I thank my Caucus colleagues who had the good sense to elect me as a Government member on the delegation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Much deserved.

—It was certainly much fought for in the lobbying processes leading to the ballots for the positions. Without the Parliament's approval and without my Caucus colleagues' approval, I would not have been able to revisit the land of my birth.

PARA.TAB: I claim the privilege of being the only Irish born member currently serving in this Parliament. Certainly, I am not the first who has ever served in it. It is with a great deal of pride that I continue to claim that privilege. Although a colleague in the other place has an accent that is quite similar to mine in Australian terms, it is distinctly different in Irish terms. I refer to my colleague Ted Grace, whose mother had the unfortunate experience of giving birth to him while she was briefly in the country of Wales. Nonetheless, I think Ted, for the purposes of the debate here tonight, is as Irish as I am. I have made a point of making these comments at the start of my speech. I want to go on to make some mention of the Irish contribution to this great and wonderful country—this land of Australia.

Looking back over the four weeks the delegation was in Ireland and in Europe, it is very difficult to select highlights. Certainly, there was lots and lots of hard work, with some days stretching for as long as perhaps some sittings of the Senate—starting early in the morning and concluding rather late at night. However, I assure honourable senators that we did not touch the Murphy's until after the bells had rung. We certainly had some opportunities to join with our parliamentary colleagues from other parts of the world and to share experiences on a whole range of issues.

Highlights that spring to mind include the visit to the magnificent parliamentary chamber of the European Parliament where we participated to some degree in some very crucial and important debates of the times and, unfortunately, some debates about issues that continue to this very day. I am talking about the great difficulties in Yugoslavia, Croatia and Slovenia. That visit was certainly a highlight.

We visited the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation headquarters, where we had some very useful and intense discussions with senior officers of that organisation. NATO played a crucial role in the Gulf conflict in which Australia was involved earlier this year. I make the point in passing that it seemed easier to get into the NATO premises, high security as they may be, than sometimes it seems to be to get into this place. That is perhaps a credit to the Australian Parliament.

A very moving experience for me was our visit to war graves in Flanders. With the memories of the Gulf war very fresh in our minds, having participated in the debates which I mentioned earlier, it was really a sad reflection on humankind when one looked around at the headstones, all similar and all identifying young men and women cut down in the prime of life while fighting in a war. It certainly brought home the message that peace ought to be predominant in all our minds.

Indeed, it was a very moving experience to identify the graves of people from one's home State—as indeed did every member of the delegation. We also visited the Menin Gate memorial, which is literally covered with the names of young Australians who gave their lives, in what some of us now believe was a needless conflict that should not have happened. On one of our leisure days we visited a former concentration camp which has been preserved to remind each and every one of us of man's inhumanity to man.

As Senator Teague said, we participated in a conference on democracy. Some 400 politicians from 70 nations talked about that most cherished possession, parliamentary democracy—something that we do indeed cherish in Australia.

In regard to the major highlights, perhaps we could talk about our discussions with senior politicians and dignitaries in the different nations. But coming down more to earth, from my own personal point of view one of the most moving experiences was visiting a farm in Ireland. We met an Irish family, the Ryan family, at Rathcannon in County Tipperary. We were not only given a real life experience of what agriculture is like—Ireland is indeed an agricultural country—but also shown what life is like for a typical Irish family. The whole of the delegation is grateful for the hospitality that was given to us by the Ryan family on that morning when we visited them in Tipperary.

Senator Harradine may want to say something more about Tipperary because he was supporting that county in the all-Ireland hurling final which took place on the first day of the delegation's visit. He bought a hat in the Tipperary colours before the game and he supported what turned out to be the winning side. I will not steal his thunder but will let him beat his own drum.

Unfortunately, I was unable to be part of the delegation's visit to that magnificent Irish occasion, the all-Ireland hurling final. My son, in his wisdom, decided to get married to his wonderful wife, Sandy, the day before the delegation left, so I had to delay my departure for one day. It just shows the choices that politicians sometimes have to make. In the interests of family life, I believe that I made the right decision, although when I woke up on the morning after the wedding I was not quite so sure.

The second farm that we visited was in Belgium. Again the family on the farm bestowed real and meaningful hospitality upon us. They made us feel welcome on a European autumn morning. We had to rise very early in the morning, and I put on record my thanks to the delegation secretary for getting me out of bed because I had had a late night the night before. He made sure that I joined the delegation.

The delegation on its last day in Europe visited the farm of Mr Van Acker. We participated to some degree in his farming duties and we experienced what life is really like for a European farmer. Life on a farm in Europe is not just a comfortable cushion, despite all the subsidies that are given. There will be real difficulties in Europe—and this applies to Ireland as well as to each of the European agricultural countries—as Europe moves away from its common agricultural policy, which indeed it must do. This must happen if it wishes to preserve its own economy. As we in Australia pressure Europe because of the damage that has been done to Australian agriculture, I feel that it is important for us to appreciate why Europeans have got into their present position through their use of subsidies. My remarks apply equally to Mr Van Acker's farm in Belgium and to Mr Ryan's farm in Ireland. The members of the delegation learned some salutary lessons.

The delegation had a number of aims; we did not just go over there to see the sights of Europe. One of our aims—and our aims are all enumerated in our report—was to assess the implications of the single market concept both for the European Community internally and externally, and also for Australia. The other aim was to promote Australia's trade interests.

I wish to commend the delegation leader—and indeed this arose from strong recommendations made by previous delegations which we took up by way of goodwill—for the idea of passing out gifts to our hosts who entertained us. We thought that we would reward them with a uniquely Australian gift. One of the most popularly received gifts that we had the fortune to pass out was Australian wine. Every time it was passed out—and the delegation got none of it!—comment was made that the wine was of top quality and was produced without subsidy.

Having regard to the time and the comments that were made earlier, I return to the subject of Ireland in my concluding remarks. We were fortunate to meet the new President of Ireland, Mrs Mary Robinson. She received us with great dignity at Aras an Uachtarain, the Irish President's home. There is a picture of the delegation together with the President of Ireland on page 12 of the report. I draw the attention of honourable senators to the second window from the left in the photograph, where a ghost is illuminated. It is a light that burns continuously and is something that the President has innovated since taking office. The light is in memory of all the migrants who have left Ireland for one reason or another. The Australian delegation contained two migrants from Ireland.

We had the fortunate experience of meeting with the Prime Minister of Ireland, Mr Charles Haughey. In my case it was a further meeting with the Prime Minister, as I have been a member of every Australian parliamentary delegation that has ever been to Ireland. Mr Haughey is known as the great survivor of world politics. There were some tensions in Ireland while we were there, which I shall not develop any further here in this chamber.

One name that springs up a couple of times in our report is that of a very distinguished Australian, Sir Ninian Stephen. Sir Ninian, as honourable senators will know, was nominated earlier in the year to chair some crucial talks aimed at resolving the horrible conflict that besets the beautiful green land of Ireland. Unfortunately, despite the appointment of Sir Ninian to chair and keep the talks together, they have not actually happened. But wherever we went in Ireland wishes were expressed that it was hoped the talks would get under way. People were grateful for Australia's cooperation in encouraging Sir Ninian to undertake this enormous task.

Senator Teague mentioned our recommendation in regard to the International Fund for Ireland. I went to Ireland as a member of a delegation from Australia and would make the point that one-third of Australia's population can trace their roots back to Ireland either directly or indirectly.

TALK.START.PARA: —The cream!

—Indeed, the cream. I thank Senator Collins for that interjection. Ireland is a tiny country measuring 300 miles long by 150 miles wide. We note on page 15 of the report that a number of countries such as those in the European Community, the United States, Canada and New Zealand have made not insignificant contributions towards that fund. We received a detailed briefing early in the delegation visit when we first arrived. We were told of the aims of the fund—namely, to promote economic and social advance and to encourage contact, dialogue and reconciliation between nationalists and unionists throughout Ireland. My earlier comments referring to Sir Ninian Stephen will bring home the importance of those remarks.

PARA.TAB: The delegation was taken on a tour of sections of Ireland and saw in real life how the moneys from this fund are being put to very good use by improving the social conditions of the people who live in the vicinity and providing employment for individuals. We in Australia are shocked to have 10 per cent unemployment. None of us on any side of this chamber are happy with that figure. In Ireland, the norm is 17 per cent, and in many areas the figure is much higher. This fund has directly contributed to the creation of some 10,000 to 15,000 jobs in border areas, bringing together people from diverse cultural backgrounds with the common aim of improving their immediate surroundings.

I was embarrassed that Australia's name is not included on that list of donors. However, I must say that I did not take the leading role in lobbying for the inclusion of the unanimous recommendation of the delegation that Australia do make a contribution to the fund. Whilst the Australian Government does not make a contribution to the fund, that is not to say that some Australian money does not go to Ireland. In this country there is an organisation called the Australian Ireland Fund through which, by means of a series of fundraising events—with which all politicians are familiar—money is raised and sent over to Ireland to assist in promoting the unification of that country. I mention that only in passing, not in any way to slight it but to make the point that members of the Australian community have already accepted their responsibility and are exercising that responsibility by putting their hands in their pockets and drawing out their wallets and, in turn, funds.

I hope that recommendation 231 on page 18 of the report will be examined very carefully by the Government and that Australia will, in a very short time, take a firm decision to make a contribution to this most worthy cause. Like my colleagues in the other place who spoke to this report two weeks ago, I will not care to nominate a figure, but I do think that it should at least be approximately that given by other nations. Those amounts are enumerated on page 15.

I am aware that I have let my tongue carry me away; I have spoken for longer than I initially intended. It was for me a very great experience to once again visit the land of my birth and to visit, without my prior knowledge, the town in which I was born, brought up and sometimes went to school. There are some remarks on page 71 and photographs on pages 72 and 73 of the report which are evidence of my return to my roots. Finally, I apologise for perhaps giving the Blarney stone such a big smack. Brevity should have ruled the day rather than that which you have just experienced.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: It is my intention to stick to a five-minute speech in a very Irish way. Ireland truly is a country of great beauty and its people are highly intelligent with a very rich spiritual heritage. As you, Mr Acting Deputy President, Senator McKiernan and other members of the delegation know, their welcome was most generous to the point of being overwhelming. The Irish are quick-witted people and are very colourful.

PARA.TAB: The country, unlike the people, is incredibly green. I had heard about it from my ancestors, but I had to see it to believe it. I can now understand how the Gleesons and the Ryans, my ancestors on my mother's side, felt about leaving that incredibly green country to go to outback northern South Australia. Anyone who has gone to outback South Australia will know how dry and brown that is. I can feel what it meant to them over the years to sing those songs about the Emerald Isle.

It was fitting that our first official engagement was to attend, at the invitation of the GAA, the all-Ireland hurling championship finals between two magnificent hurling counties—Tipperary and Kilkenny. There was a magnificent atmosphere. It is more to the Irish than just a sport. It has deep meanings for many Irish, going back decades. As I understand it, the game was forbidden at some stage.

Being an incredibly green and beautiful country, Ireland is a desirable place to visit from the tourist point of view. The work that is being done, with the help of the International Fund for Ireland, to open the canals that were built a century ago and extend them, and thus the waterways, by some incredible distance—by maybe 200 kilometres—to small tourist craft is an ideal way of attracting tourists from both America and Europe, and indeed from Australia. I would like to return to Ireland at some stage and take that journey when the scheme is completed.

I believe it is important that that work be done on the north-south border because it enables cooperation between the peoples of the area. I believe that there have been too many simplistic suggestions that the conflict in Northern Ireland is basically a fight over religion. It is often forgotten that a major part of the conflict was, and unfortunately still is, the problem of job discrimination. Efforts are being made to overcome that, and this is one such effort. I believe that any Anglo-Irish agreement should be supported, given the problems that the Irish have suffered over many years.

Therefore I agree with my colleagues that the recommendation we have made should be taken up immediately by the Government and a commitment made to that international fund. I am very pleased to see that members of the Opposition on the delegation—including you, Mr Acting Deputy President, as deputy leader of that delegation—are very strongly in support of that fund. That appears to me to be a good commitment for the future.

On the issue of tourism, I will digress slightly and say that Ireland surely has a very good tourist Minister in Denis Lyons. He got up at about 4 a.m. Ireland time and flew in to Ireland from Austria. He put on a reception for us in Cork. He entertained us; he was the floor show. He sang and told jokes while we quaffed our Murphy's. He got the people to sing songs. His wife was a marvellous person. He wore the badge; he was a total abstainer. Those who know the history of the badge know the importance of the self-denial commitment of the wearers of the badge in response to what was and still is a problem in many parts of the world. Denis Lyons was a magnificent host, as indeed were all our hosts. It is probably a bit invidious to single out any one of them, but as we were talking about tourism I thought I might say that as it came to my mind.

It was good that we were able first to visit farms in Ireland. One of the major missions, if not the major mission, of the delegation was to point out the problems experienced by Australia and its farming communities, and indeed the problems experienced by the taxpayers of the European Community, because of the common agricultural policy. By and large, the farms in Ireland were small family farms that were intensively cared for. The question arises that, if the CAP is abolished, where do the families on those farms go? Do they go into the cities, where there is no work available? If they leave those farming areas, what happens to the countryside? Those farmers are truly the manicurists of the environment, the beautiful environment that is Ireland.

I think, as I believe many members of the delegation do, that Mr McSharry, who is the European Commissioner for Agriculture, has ideas that need to be fleshed out and supported. As I understand it, he suggests that it is more important to provide income support for family farmers than to subsidise production, which chiefly benefits the very large producers on the Continent. These are the areas that need to be explored so that we can come to common ground. We all have a very hard row to hoe but, sure as eggs, if the taxpayers of Europe do not wake up very soon to what the CAP is costing them, the whole show is likely to collapse. The burden will become too heavy.

I turn now to Europe. In Strasbourg we were able to question members of the European Parliament not only about the common agricultural policy but also about a number of other issues. On behalf of the hundreds of thousands of Australians of Croatian and Slovenian descent, we asked members of the European Parliament why they appeared so powerless to engender a peaceful solution to the problem. Here we are in Strasbourg, allegedly in the civilised twentieth century, when a few miles down the road absolute barbarism is occurring. The responses we received were inept, as has been the action since—threatened boycotts, threats to cut off supplies to the Yugoslav Army. Has that materialised? What is the civilised world doing to stop this barbarism?

In Brussels and Strasbourg I had discussions with members of the European Parliament and with a number of bureaucrats on issues of fundamental importance to the future of humanity. I refer to human embryo experimentation and to euthanasia. Unfortunately, an ugly development is occurring in some parts of Europe which has an all too familiar ring, recalling events of years gone by in pre-war Nazi Germany and during the war.

Those words `Lebensunwertes Leben', life unworthy of life, are echoing in the current euthanasia debate and in the push for research-driven human embryo experimentation. I believe that members of the European Parliament must take note of this and realise that they must ensure that the bureaucrats in Brussels adhere to the fundamental principles upon which European civilisation was based.

I think that, politically, there are problems in a united Europe and one of those problems is, in fact, how the European Parliament will exercise its audit and control function over the bureaucracy in Brussels. What is to be the principle of subsidiary function and how will that properly operate in a range of areas? I would like to develop those arguments a little further, but I will not.

I will conclude by expressing my thanks to my fellow delegates on the visit and to the Irish Ambassador to Australia and to his staff who are in the gallery and who were very helpful prior to our departure. I also thank our Secretary; the officers of the Parliamentary Relations Office; Ambassador Terry McCarthy, who is a very worthy ambassador for Australia in Ireland, and Mrs McCarthy. I do not want to offend anybody, but I am going to say that, from my information and from what people said to me when I was in Ireland, they felt that former Ambassador Brian Burke did a magnificent job for Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —This was the message I got, too.

—That is true. I think that Ambassador McCarthy, with his professionalism, will build upon that. The link between Australia and Ireland will only improve. I thank officers from the Irish Parliament who were so good to us during our stay there and, indeed, the members of the Irish Parliament for their generosity and their welcome. I appreciated the opportunity of being part of the delegation and I look forward to many of its recommendations being implemented as early as possible.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
