So I say to Senator Spindler: if the State or Territory has not seen fit to bind itself, why should the legislation be made applicable to the Commonwealth?

TALK.START.PARA: —But you can override that by Commonwealth legislation.

—I do not see why we should do that every time a piece of legislation comes to our notice. That is one of the difficulties that the honourable senator found in the last way we tackled this—that one has to tackle each piece of legislation that the State or Territory might enact which one thinks might apply in a way which imposes liabilities on the Commonwealth. This would be an endless process. We would have to set up a continual monitoring section in the Attorney-General's Department to look at every piece of legislation passed by every State and Territory legislature.
—But you would have to concede that the circumstances would be very rare in any event. So you are not starting from a mass of instances where the State legislation would bind the Commonwealth.

—I am not sure of the exact scope of it. Certainly, in prudence and as a matter of caution, one would have to at least scan all of the legislation. The difficulty then is, of course, to look at the delegated legislation made under, and by reason of, the principal legislation passed by the States or Territories. It could be a very exhausting process to come to a conclusion which the honourable senator has come to—perhaps correctly and intuitively—that, in the end, nothing much would apply.

PARA.TAB: Then there is another provision which says that even if a State or Territory does subject itself, the Commonwealth ought to be able to opt out. Once again, this goes more along the lines of what was suggested as a better solution to the problem when we discussed this matter a year ago. We believe that if the law which, upon examination, does appear to confer a right of action against the Commonwealth for a breach of statutory duty, is applicable to the State or Territory—and, therefore, one might say that my previous argument ought to be accepted by the Commonwealth—we would normally accept it. But if we prescribed that law—and by prescribing it, I mean by dealing with it by way of a regulation which would be disallowable in this chamber—I believe that we would be properly exercising our responsibility even, let alone our right, as a Commonwealth to say that a State law should not bind us simply by will of the State parliament. It is an extraordinary proposition that it should be the case that we should be bound.

I want to emphasise that it would be only a reserve power; the normal situation would be to accept. There is force in what the Commonwealth judiciary—the High Court—has said. According to Senator Hill, in this day and age the idea that the Crown should be somehow aloof from the laws which normally bind citizens is a bit of an anachronistic concept.

Nevertheless, holding in reserve the capacity of the Commonwealth, subject to disallowance by this chamber, to say that a State law otherwise applicable to both the State and the Commonwealth should not apply to it seems to be a proper exercise of the sovereign rights of the Commonwealth. As to the second leg of this, the States made a very strong request that the results and the implications for them of the Evans Deakin decision be dealt with. We have also tried to do that in this legislation.

Senator Hill indicated that the Opposition wishes to move an amendment to the Law Officers Act 1964. No doubt we will have a considerable debate on this during the committee stage. I must say as a matter of principle—I imagine that the Australian Democrats, being a party of principle in relation to parliamentary process, would agree—that to enact this particular clause so that it becomes part of the Law Officers Act would be to retrospectively alter the statutory conditions under which the Office of the Solicitor-General was conferred on a particular person. To look at it another way, it would retrospectively alter the conditions under which that particular statutory condition operates, under which that office has been held, and with an expectation that section 9 of the Law Officers Act would be applied in accordance with its terms.

There has been a proper expectation over the last six months that section 9 would apply in a particular way, if it were to be applied at all. If it was sought, the Attorney-General should exercise his discretion or give his consent in a particular situation. To retrospectively alter the way in which the occupant of that office reasonably expected that power to be exercised seems to me to be a very brave infraction on the rights of that officeholder and a very legitimate expectation under the statute as drafted.

TALK.START.PARA: —If you extend the special privileges you ought to be prepared to tell the Australian taxpayers the basis for what you are doing.

—Perhaps that is a matter for the committee stage. I believe that the Opposition, in broad terms, is attempting to change the ordinary way in which the Minister is held responsible—through Question Time and censure motions in the House of Representatives. So far as the Opposition is concerned, that has not proved adequate in extracting what it thinks to be the reasons put forward by the Solicitor-General in his application to the Attorney-General.

PARA.TAB: I believe that in trying to graft the process of the AD(JR) Act into this situation the Opposition has potentially created a grave invasion of the privacy of the holder of the office. That would not be permitted under the AD(JR) Act. I will explain this further in the committee stage. In other words, if the Opposition amendment gets up, the Parliament becomes the aggrieved party, if you like, which seeks the reasons for a particular decision. Under the AD(JR) Act, an aggrieved person cannot be given reasons where the giving of those reasons would impinge on the personal affairs of a third party. The Parliament becomes the aggrieved party, the party whose decision the Opposition is challenging is the Attorney-General and the third party is the Solicitor-General. As I said, given the structure of the AD(JR) Act, we would not be permitted to give reasons which went into the personal affairs of the Solicitor-General.

Basically, what has happened is that Mr Peacock, having made an application under the AD(JR) Act for reasons and knowing that the Act would not be applicable because he is not an aggrieved person in terms of that particular statute, attempted to do by way of legislation what he could not do by way of request, by way of letter of the Attorney-General. I think it is a totally inappropriate procedure to try to graft onto this particular matter.

I do not deny that there is a proper place for scrutiny and questioning of any Minister in the discharge of his decision making. But I believe that there are other parliamentary processes—and they have been exercised in the other place in particular—to bring home to the Minister notions of ministerial responsibility to the Parliament in the exercise of this particular power. I do not believe that the grafting of the AD(JR) Act onto the Law Officers Act is the way to approach this matter.

I thank the chamber for the indications of support for much of the Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill. I hope that I have been able to indicate to the chamber why the request of the Family Court of Australia for an amendment in terms of the judge becoming aware of the fact, not the terms, of an offer should be accepted. I believe that the amendments to the Judiciary Act, flowing from the Evans Deakin decision, also ought to be accepted by the chamber as an expression of the proper sovereignty of the Commonwealth in these matters. I commend the second reading to the chamber.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I suggest that we take the Bill as a whole and take Opposition amendments No. 1 and No. 4 together and then Opposition amendments No. 3 and No. 5 together. The two proposed Australian Democrat amendments are the same as Opposition amendments No. 3 and No. 5. That would leave us with Opposition amendment No. 2.

PARA.TAB: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Clause 3, page 2, at end of clause, add the following subclause:

PARA.TAB: "(3) The amendment of the Law Officers Act 1964 made by this Act applies in relation to a consent given under section 9 of that Act within 6 months before the commencement of this Act as if the consent were given at that commencement.".

SPEECH.PARA: 4.Schedule, page 5, Part 1, after proposed amendments to the Judiciary Act 1903, insert the following heading and amendment:

PARA.TAB: Add at the end:

'(2) Where the Attorney-General gives consent under subsection (1), the Attorney-General must lay before each House of the Parliament, within 5 sitting days of that House after the consent is given, a statement in writing setting out the findings on material questions of fact relating to the granting of the consent, referring to the evidence or other material on which those findings were based and giving the reasons for the consent.'.".

SPEECH.PARA: These amendments relate to the final subject discussed by the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate); that is, the proposed amendments to the Law Officers Act 1964. Two questions are involved. The first question is the substantive change to the law that we propose; the second question is whether it should be dated to commence six months before the commencement of this Act.

PARA.TAB: I will deal with the first question. I do not know that the Minister argued against that. We are proposing that a new provision be added to provide:

SPEECH.PARA: Where the Attorney-General gives consent under sub-section (1), the Attorney-General must lay before each House of the Parliament, within 5 sitting days of that House after the consent is given, a statement in writing setting out the findings on material questions of fact relating to the granting of the consent, referring to the evidence or other material on which those findings were based and giving the reasons for the consent.

In other words, we regard the giving of this consent to enable a law officer to take paid employment outside the Commonwealth whilst at the same time continuing on full payment of the Commonwealth as a very unusual circumstance. In such an unusual circumstance, the taxpayer is entitled to know the reasons why. This amendment would mean that in the future an Attorney-General who decided to give that consent would know that he would have to be accountable to the people for the reasons for making that decision. We put it, therefore, as a wholly sensible reform and a discipline upon Attorneys of the future in giving consent under the existing section 9.

PARA.TAB: The second and more controversial question is whether it should be dated to commence six months before the commencement of this Act. On that issue, I say that we have put it in these terms because of the intransigence of the Minister, his refusal to account to the Parliament reasons for taking this highly unusual step and for allowing Commonwealth servants—I use that in a general term—to continue to receive Commonwealth remuneration while carrying on another business endeavour. In those circumstances of his refusal to give the people adequate reasons for this unusual course of action, we feel that we are forced to do so. We do not embark upon any retrospective change to law without careful consideration.

In particular, I would like to draw it to the Minister's attention that this is not retrospective in the sense that it seeks to take away benefits or impose obligations on private citizens retrospectively. There is no benefit taken. This particular law officer does not lose the benefit that the Minister has given him under section 9 in granting his consent; nor is any further obligation imposed upon him. Rather, it is an obligation on the Minister of the Crown to account to the Parliament for the reasons that he took this highly unusual course of action. It does not, as I said, remove any benefit. In fact, I argue that it confers a benefit on the taxpayers who are, in our opinion, entitled to an explanation from a Minister in relation to the administration of a statutory office and the expenditure of public moneys.

Therefore, I stay with the amendments that I have moved, notwithstanding the argument that the Minister put because, as I said, I do not think it is retrospective in the normal sense. We do not wish to intrude unduly upon the personal affairs of this particular officer or any other officers. If the Minister had perhaps accounted in one of a number of ways that I can imagine for his conduct in this instance, he may well have avoided the need for such retrospectivity. There may well be ways in which he can meet the obligation that we seek to apply without unduly intruding upon the personal affairs of the law officer concerned. That is not our wish; we do not seek that. What we do wish is that Ministers be properly accountable to the Parliament for expenditure of public moneys, particularly in most unusual circumstances. We regard this as a most unusual circumstance.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats support the amendments. We believe that in substance they are extremely reasonable ones to ensure that the Parliament receives the information which provides the reasons for the action of the Minister concerned in a case where he takes this action. We also agree that there is no element of retrospectivity—as this term is understood in the normal sense—involved in ensuring that it comes into operation six months earlier. It is not an attempt in any way to invalidate the consent which has been given by the Minister. It is simply to ensure that the reasons for that consent are provided to Parliament.

PARA.TAB: The matter of privacy of the individual concerned was of some concern. I have been assured that the privacy legislation covers the provisions of the Law Officers Act 1964. I note the general provisions in the Privacy Act where principle 8, for instance, ensures that the person who divulges that information is obliged to check the accuracy of the information; that the personal information disclosed is used only where it is relevant; that there are certain limits on the use of personal information; and, in particular, that the individual concerned must have consented to the use of personal information for that other purpose. On this basis, the Australian Democrats support the amendments.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the difficulties of dealing with these amendments is that they came to us rather late. I have to think about Senator Spindler's last point over the next couple of minutes as I speak on matters with which I am slightly more confident. But I do believe that this is a very ill-conceived attempt to write into a statute a means of overcoming an impasse which developed in another place, because the normal ways of holding a Minister accountable to the House of Representatives for the exercise of a particular discretion or decision-making power on his part proved—in the Opposition's view, and perhaps in Senator Spindler's view—to be less than satisfactory in getting the sorts of answers that the Opposition wanted. It is going be a very full statute book if we start to make amendments to Acts to overcome the failure of the ordinary parliamentary processes of Question Time, motions of no confidence and censure notions to elicit information from Ministers. It seems to me to be an extraordinary proposition that we should start amending the Law Officers Act because Question Time in the House of Representatives proved somewhat futile from the Opposition's point of view.

PARA.TAB: But the real point I wish to make is that in relation to the substantive matter—and I hope Senator Spindler may still have some room for reconsideration—the fact is that the model which is being adopted and the very language of the amendment put forward by the Opposition is an exact replica of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act provision. What that does is enable an aggrieved person to seek reasons for a decision. What this amendment is virtually doing is saying that the Parliament in this case—certainly the Opposition and perhaps the Democrats—becomes the aggrieved person seeking from the Attorney-General not only the reasons for his decision but also the material facts upon which the decision was made, et cetera.

Under the previous understanding of the Parliament as expressed in that particular Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act, if an aggrieved person seeks reasons and those reasons, if given, would impinge on the personal affairs or business affairs of a person other than the aggrieved person, other than the person making the request, then they cannot be disclosed. This Parliament has already said that in those situations that sort of information cannot be disclosed. So there is very clearly an intention in the Parliament in the structure of the Act, which is the model for this provision, that personal affairs or business affairs of a third party ought not to be disclosed. Quite clearly, these may have been the sorts of matters which led the Attorney-General to give his consent or would lead an Attorney-General to give his consent in a particular instance on an application by the Solicitor-General of the day to take advantage of the permission available under section 9 of the Law Officers Act.

I find it quite incredible that the personal business affairs of a Solicitor-General could be paraded in a formal way by way of a tabling document before the Parliament. I believe not only that this could do great damage to any Solicitor-General in office from time to time but also—I ask Senator Spindler to take this into account—that many potential applicants for that office may be precluded from coming forward if they think that, on a particular matter, a very personal reason which they may give to the Attorney-General and which is sufficient and adequate to enable him to exercise power under section 9 might be tabled in the Parliament. I think this is a great disservice to the office of the Solicitor-General. I would certainly suggest that the Committee reject it on that basis alone.

Even if, despite my eloquence, Senator Spindler were minded to accept for the future the proposition put by the Opposition, that is, Opposition amendment No. 4, I maintain very strongly that to accept Opposition amendment No. 1 would be to inject a very real element of retrospectivity. There is a contract of employment—let us put it that way—between the Commonwealth and the person who occupies the office of Solicitor-General. The terms of that employment are those negotiated in part between the Attorney-General and the Solicitor-General; for example, as to an equality of situation between the Solicitor-General and a Federal Court judge as to certain leave entitlements and so on. But there is also a statutory element imported into that employment relationship.

One of the key areas of that statutory employment relationship is, of course, section 9. Any past Solicitor-General, in accepting an offer of that particular high office, would make himself well acquainted with the Law Officers Act and would make himself well acquainted with section 9. There is no way—I will be blunt—that the present occupant of the office of Solicitor-General could have anticipated as part of his employment relationship that any reason he put forward to the Attorney-General to try to encourage the Attorney-General to exercise his discretion and to consent to his engaging in the practice of a barrister or solicitor, to engage in paid employment, would be required by Parliament to be laid before it.

TALK.START.PARA: —He couldn't have stopped the Attorney-General from answering questions in the other place.

—I am saying that that is a completely different matter. I do not believe that the Minister, in responding to a parliamentary question, would choose to divulge certain matters because he would be very conscious of the matters I have brought to the Senate's attention in regard to the analogy with the AD(JR) Act. The fact is that the Opposition by this amendment is formally attempting to change a statutory term of employment of the Solicitor-General. I believe that that is a retrospective act which changes very much his entitlements to be employed according to the terms he has negotiated with the Attorney-General and which are supplemented by or based on the sure foundation, he would have thought, of the Law Officers Act.

PARA.TAB: I would make a very real plea to Senator Spindler that he not undo the proper and legitimate expectations under the current employment arrangement of an incumbent in that office—whatever he does as to the future. If the honourable senator is moved to do something for the future, so be it. That is all I have to say to the Committee on this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to respond briefly to one or two points made by the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate). I emphasise that I derive great comfort from the provisions of the Privacy Act and that, in that case, I believe that the private concerns of the individual concerned, whoever he or she may be from time to time, would be properly protected.

PARA.TAB: On the other point the Minister made—that the terms of employment are being changed—I would be very surprised indeed, even though I am not privy to the views of the current incumbent, if he did not anticipate that, if that eventuality ever occurred, the reasons for the Minister's decision might be made public, either, as Senator Hill has suggested, in response to a parliamentary question or in some other way. Section 9 certainly does not provide currently for that information to be divulged, but neither does it prohibit such information being provided. I would have thought that the holder of a public office, if he seeks the consent of the Minister for a procedure that is somewhat unusual and that is an exception, must surely expect that the reasons for the Minister's decision might have to be made public. I regret that on this occasion the Minister's eloquence did not sway me.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have had some opportunity to think about the Privacy Act matter that Senator Spindler has raised. It seems to me that, if it is the case that Ministers are bound by the Privacy Act in their capacity as Ministers, that means that they are bound by information privacy principle No. 11. That would prevent the disclosure of information about the personal affairs of the Solicitor-General. So certainly he should derive great comfort from the Privacy Act.

PARA.TAB: However, if this amendment became law that would override the Privacy Act. It would be a clear, express intention by the Parliament to create a new situation in respect of this particular matter—an exception that has thereby been authorised by law. So whilst the Privacy Act in principle may be a comfort to the honourable senator, and undoubtedly a comfort to the Solicitor-General to this point, if the amendment were to be passed into law the comfort of the Privacy Act would be stripped away from the Solicitor-General. Whereas at the moment his consent would be required, under IPP 11 for the disclosure of this personal information, it would not be, obviously, under this particular amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not our desire to get into the personal affairs of this particular Solicitor-General or any other law officer. The amendment is put in such terms that I would have thought that any Attorney-General with any wit and wanting to do what we think is proper in the interests of the Australian public would be able to put a fair and reasonable explanation to the Australian people as to why he has given this highly unusual approval without unduly interfering in the personal affairs of that officer.

PARA.TAB: I do not know, but I put to the Minister the hypothetical situation that the Solicitor-General may well have gone to the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) and argued that his salary was unreasonably low. We know that there has been a public debate about whether the salary of the Solicitor-General and the Director of Public Prosecutions is reasonable or unreasonable vis-a-vis the salary of High Court judges. It may be that the Solicitor-General was particularly persuasive in putting to the Attorney that it was unreasonable that he be expected to exist on the allowance the Commonwealth was providing him and therefore that this special privilege should be given to him in these circumstances to go out and hold down another job. That might be the reason.

If that is the reason, the Australian public has every reason to know. Members of the public may well have a view as to whether the Solicitor-General is being properly paid or otherwise, and through their elected representatives they may wish to take action in that regard. Many other possibilities might have been put to the Attorney-General—I do not know—but I stress that we do not want unduly to interfere with the personal privacy of this man. We are only interested in the proper accounting by the Attorney-General of taxpayers' money.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry that this discussion is going on somewhat. I am not saying, even with the amendment that I am about to propose, that, having heard Senator Hill, the Government would accept an amended version of Opposition amendment 4. I think that part of the problem comes from lifting the provision holus-bolus out of the AD(JR) Act as a model to try to achieve what Senator Hill says he wants to achieve, which is a requirement for the Attorney to table his reasons. It could be by way of a written expression of those reasons which does not unduly impinge on the privacy of the individual concerned. I think it is very difficult for that to be done where one requires a statement in writing:

SPEECH.PARA: setting out the findings on material questions of fact relating to the granting of the consent, referring to the evidence or other material on which those findings were based and giving the reasons for the consent.

It may be that what Senator Hill says is his aim would be sufficiently achieved if the words, `setting out the findings on material questions of fact relating to the granting of the consent, referring to the evidence or other material on which those findings were based and' were omitted. The amendment Senator Hill is putting would then read:

Where the Attorney-General gives consent under subsection (1), the Attorney-General must lay before each House of the Parliament, within 5 sitting days of that House after the consent is given, a statement in writing giving the reasons for the consent.

It may be that that would be sufficient for Senator Hill's purpose and would give the Attorney, if the matter were to be accepted by the Government in another place, and I cannot give any undertaking and I will not vote for it here—

TALK.START.PARA: —It might be better that that question be addressed in the other place. I know that Senator Spindler is always reasonable in negotiation, and we will be reasonable in negotiation.
—I am not saying that it is a matter for negotiation.
—You are floating the idea now.

—No; I am taking up Senator Hill's explanation of how he thinks this clause could operate in a way that is not unduly intrusive. I am asking Senator Hill to consider that because he asks for a setting out of the findings on material questions of fact and referring to the evidence or other material on which those findings were based, that invariably will lead to a degree of intrusion because he is seeking very elaborate background information.

PARA.TAB: If Senator Hill were simply to ask for a statement in writing giving the reasons for the consent, he would sufficiently achieve his objective and certainly make it closer to a situation which a government might very reluctantly accept. I do not foreshadow any acceptance by the Government but, taking Senator Hill at his word, I would suggest that Senator Spindler might find the amendment easier in conscience to accept if it were put forward in the way I suggest.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let us hold the question over for a minute or two. I will move to the next amendment which concerns the Family Law Act. The Minister will be pleased to hear that we found his argument to be more persuasive. I say that in the terms that the Minister put to us—that is, judges have been concerned about highly unusual cases where the fact of the offer of compromise has come to them at the final stage of a case and it has been the fact of the offer of compromise, not the detail of the offer of compromise. Even then the judge would weigh up in his own mind whether, in the interests of natural justice, he should proceed with the matter.

PARA.TAB: All this amendment does, as the Minister indicates, is give the judge that option in these highly unusual circumstances, which the judge may not have at this time. As the Minister has put his understanding of the intention of this piece of legislation in those terms, we are persuaded to accept his argument.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I need to clarify something because I would not want the Committee to accept the very kind offer of Senator Hill if it were based on a slight misunderstanding. I maintain that this amendment has been sought by the judges of the Family Court of Australia. I can provide privately to Senator Hill an indication of that.

PARA.TAB: My understanding is that if the amendment were accepted, in that rare instance where a judge becomes aware simply of the fact of an offer having been made—not the terms of the offer or anything else that might be prejudicial to the parties or any particular party, but in a simple unadorned situation where he or she becomes aware of the fact of an offer having been made—in the terms of the Bill, the judge is not disqualified from sitting in the proceedings. That is a clear statement: he is not disqualified. It does not confer an option or a discretion on him. It simply says that he is not disqualified. I believe that that is a very bald statement of the situation in that very simple unadorned circumstance where quite unexpectedly—as I have indicated, the court rules mean that these matters should be kept quite separate from the court file—he becomes aware of the fact. In that situation he is not disqualified. I hope that clarifies the matter a little.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats accept the Minister's assurances on that point and will not be supporting the Opposition's amendment.
—It is my understanding that the amendment has not been moved at this stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will not press that amendment. I seek leave to move amendments 3 and 5 together.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 3.Schedule, page 5, Part 1, proposed amendments to section 64 of the Judiciary Act 1903, omit the amendments.
5.Schedule, page 6, Part 2, proposed amendment to section 64 of the Judiciary Act 1903, omit the amendment.

Amendments 3 and 5 concern section 64 of the Judiciary Act. I will be brief because the arguments were canvassed during the second reading stage. Our objections are basically that the amendments confer on the Commonwealth an immunity from section 64, which is broader than that proposed for the States, and that the Commonwealth will be able to exempt itself by way of regulation from any prescribed law of the State or Territory. In light of the comments from the High Court—it feels that section 64 is able to be interpreted in a workable way—I quote one part of the Evans Deakin judgment of the High Court:

. . . in every suit to which the Commonwealth is a party, section 64 requires the rights of the parties to be ascertained, as nearly as possible, by the same rules of law, substantive and procedural, statutory and otherwise, as would apply if the Commonwealth were a subject instead of being the Crown . . . that result seems entirely just.

In most circumstances we think it is entirely just. There may be the occasional difficulty and, if that does occur, it is capable of being overcome by legislation. We would much prefer it to be overcome by legislation rather than by regulation.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will be supporting the Opposition amendments Nos 3 and 5 for the reasons stated previously.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —It seems to me that we have reached a very unfortunate stage in the Committee's consideration of this matter, because there has been an abdication by those honourable senators who have spoken of their right to determine the laws which will bind the Commonwealth and subject it to liability.
—We did that when section 64 was passed.

—A very good point. Section 64, as interpreted by the High Court very recently, has created this situation. What Senator Hill is now saying is that because several justices, exercising the judicial power of the Commonwealth, have interpreted a simple Act of our Parliament in a way which creates this most unfortunate situation, we should not overturn it.
—You think it is most unfortunate. We do not think it is.

—Senator Hill does not think it most unfortunate that a State parliament, meeting in the Legislative Assembly and the Legislative Council of Victoria, for example, passes a law which does not even purport to bind the State but deals with the residents in the State and binds the Commonwealth. I think that is pretty extraordinary.
—If they seek to do that, you can take action.

—We would have to come in here every time and pass an Act of Parliament. What is more, questions of retrospectivity might even arise. But of course you do not feel so strongly about retrospectivity in this Committee as I have hitherto heard you speak. Did you address the Scrutiny of Bills Committee conference yesterday? Not on the subject of retrospectivity, I take it, or anything like that?
—Justice.

—I can read the writing on the wall as far as this is concerned. I think it is very unfortunate, and I may also say that the State governments have sought the amendments which have been suggested as new subsection 64(3), to prevent section 64 from conferring rights against a State and Federal jurisdiction on the basis of the law where the Commonwealth or the State that does not otherwise apply to the State, et cetera.

PARA.TAB: The States have expressly asked for this amendment to be made. I believe they are quite right in thinking that there is a parallel between the case I have put, so far as the Commonwealth is concerned, and their claim that Commonwealth law should not determine when State statutes will bind a State in proceedings brought by or against the State in Federal jurisdiction. This should be determined by State law. I think that is a very sound principle.

So it appears that the chamber has become subservient to the non-elected judges of the High Court of Australia in this matter, and that is rather unfortunate. It has to be emphasised that section 64 of the Judiciary Act is a simple Act of the Parliament; it is not a constitutional provision or something which is absolutely binding on us as interpreted by the High Court of Australia, as it would be if it were a constitutional provision. I believe that to give it the exalted status which the Opposition and the Democrats wish to give it so that it becomes immutable, as interpreted by the High Court, is almost to allow the Opposition and the Democrats to substitute themselves for the people in referendum, if I may be so bold as to make even that claim at this late stage of the evening.

As I say, the Opposition and the Democrats are thinking not in terms suitable to parliamentarians but in terms suitable to those who say that they have an absolute right either to interpret the Constitution, which should bind this Parliament, whatever we may think in subsequent sittings of the Parliament, or, as I say, virtually by way of analogy with a referendum, to determine how the Constitution will be formed by virtually elevating section 64 into the Constitution. For all those reasons I urge the committee to reject Opposition amendments Nos 3 and 5 which are in the exact terms of the Democrats' amendments.
Amendments agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will return to amendments Nos 1 and 4.

—I have a proposal which might help the Minister. The Minister suggests that, if these amendments are to go forward, they should go forward to the other place simply providing that the statement should set out the reasons for the consent. We believe that that is probably inadequate in as basic terms as that because, to put it at its worst, the Minister could simply say that his reasons for consent were that the Solicitor-General asked for it. We think that there must be some factual base upon which he reached that decision that he put before the Parliament, although, as I said, we do not want to unreasonably intrude into personal affairs.

PARA.TAB: An alternative set of words which might be slightly better would be a statement in writing setting out the reasons for the consent, including material questions of fact leading to the granting of consent.

TALK.START.PARA: —That would not substantially change it.
—If the Minister does not think that substantially changes it, I will leave it as it is and as I have moved it. I am only trying to be helpful.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That amendments (Senator Hill's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Amendments agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with amendments; report adopted.
Bill (on motion by Senator Tate) read a third time.
Debate resumed from 13 November, on motion by Senator Cook:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I say at the outset, in handling the Public Service Amendment Bill on behalf of the Opposition, that it is a great humiliation for what is now a very short shelf life government to be introducing this Bill at this time. It should have been introduced a long time ago because it is now the height of embarrassment for this Government to admit that it has allowed public servants, if made redundant, to have the capacity to double dip the system by taking a redundancy package and then returning to the public sector, taking former entitlements with them. Either way, life has looked pretty sweet for these individuals, all at the overburdened taxpayers' expense.

PARA.TAB: This Bill proposes a range of amendments to Part V of the Public Service Act 1922 to prevent officers employed by statutory authorities from accepting redundancy benefits and then returning to the Public Service. This will bring them into line with other public servants who have only a single option—either a redundancy package or the capacity to rejoin the Service in another job with their entitlements intact. The fact that many thousands of individuals have been legally able to take both steps has been a preposterous and absurd situation.

There are currently some 90 statutory authorities, including the Civil Aviation Authority, Telecom, Austrade and the Health Insurance Commission, which are responsible for some 50,000 public servants, who may be placed in just such a position where they may be able to make the most of their redundancy. Staff employed by these statutory authorities are usually covered by redundancy provisions, including severance pay. Under existing mobility provisions, many officers and ex-officers of the Australian Public Service may also have the right to return to the Public Service if they are retrenched from a statutory authority. There is potential here for public servants to have two bites of the pie, that is, to take their redundancy provisions and also, at some future time, to rejoin the Public Service with their rights intact. This is nothing short of piracy on the public purse.

The Public Service is not some kind of television quiz show where the winner takes all at the sponsor's expense. We should never forget that the Australian taxpayer sponsors the Public Service. It is completely unacceptable to the Liberal and National parties that this situation was ever allowed to develop. It is shameful that this decaying Government has tolerated the state of affairs which has flourished so far. Why should those people with mobility rights benefit from the redundancy arrangements of an agency and then return to the public sector where they may either get another job with the Commonwealth or, if there is no work available, have access to further redundancy arrangements? I know personally of a number of examples where this situation has in fact occurred.

Why should redundancy arrangements available to former public servants in government business enterprises and other such authorities be any more generous than for other staff in these agencies? It is no wonder this country has fallen on hard times. It is no wonder the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) attempts to muzzle Dr Hewson, as he did in the other place today, to prevent him bringing the coalition's economic reform package to the ears of all Australians. The Prime Minister knows he is sunk.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Crowley)—I wonder whether honourable senators could lower their tones a little and allow Senator Chapman his hearing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you for your assistance, Madam Acting Deputy President. Just as this Prime Minister has allowed the rorts on the ports and the union featherbedding to go on unabated, so he has allowed this Public Service double dipping to flourish. Now he is wondering why everything is collapsing around him.

PARA.TAB: This Bill is a belated and feeble attempt by the Government to apply some kind of brake to the Public Service. Preventing the duplication of redundancy benefits removes the potential for significant and unjustifiable additional costs associated with the restructuring of government business enterprises and authorities. That this Government has not jumped in sooner to stop this daylight robbery from the public purse is further confirmation that it no longer has its finger on the pulse.

The Minister claims that the objective of establishing non-Budget agencies such as government business enterprises or authorities is to provide such agencies with financial independence, which includes the opportunity to obtain benefits and savings arising from that independence. What this really means is the establishment of yet more empires, where much overlapping and decision making will abound and become entrenched, just as they have in the past. For example, in the past year the Federal Public Service took on an extra 4,000 employees, while 222,000 Australians lost their jobs through retrenchment or redundancy and for other economic reasons. With unemployment breaking the 10 per cent barrier and business across the nation going to the wall, the Public Service keeps growing. These additional 4,000 employees represent a 2 1/2 per cent increase in the Public Service work force. This is happening under the noses of other workers who have been forced to undergo real hardship.

The Senior Executive Service has also undergone a facelift. It grew by 5 1/2 per cent, or about 90 jobs, all in the name of restructuring and efficiency. In the past 12 months the Department of Social Security has recorded the strongest growth. It seems there are quite a few thousand employees who have a strong hold on the unemployment industry, but these people are not recipients of the dole or welfare cheques.

The Keating-Caucus inspired recession has seen the earlier trend of successful public sector staff being lured to the private sector almost cease as the squeeze hits business hard. It is obvious that many public servants, as a result, see that they have a job for life if they stay with the Public Service. It could be argued that it is the sign of a deranged mind to believe that one has a guaranteed job for life.

Other Public Service costs have also increased. There has been a 100 per cent increase in the cost of staff air travel in the Attorney-General's Department alone—from $1.78m in 1988-89 to $3.72m in 1989-90. Whatever the Department puts forward as reasons for this huge leap will pale into insignificance for unemployed people and those who have been retrenched during this recession. The Public Service cannot continue to tolerate escalating costs in this way. These departments are funded by the public, and the public deserves an efficient use of resources being demonstrated. Nearly $4m worth of taxpayers' money being spent on air fares demonstrates nothing of the sort; it demonstrates nothing but insupportable excess.

The Australian Bureau of Statistics has also failed to keep expenses to an acceptable level. Last year the Bureau spent about $1.5m on 67 outside consultancies. Compare that with the year before, when it spent just $679,200 on 53 consultancies. This represents a massive jump of about 121 per cent in a 12-month period. How can this Government claim to be on top of the job and have a special relationship with the Australian taxpayer if that is how it spends our money? Of the 67 consultancies engaged by the Bureau, only three were publicly advertised. This represents only 4 per cent. A further abuse of this claimed special relationship on the part of the Government is evidenced again by the Bureau's 3.8 per cent increase in staff levels. How can this Government assure taxpayers that they are getting a good deal?

The Government's attitude to its own personal staff makes it less than convincing that it means business with this Bill. Dr John Edwards, a one-time consultant to prime ministerial hopeful Paul Keating, was paid out almost $80,000 after only four months work—surely an act of scandalous self-serving on the part of this Government. Any right thinking Australian would be seriously offended that this Government pays its own political employees such largess when 10 per cent of Australians cannot even find work.

The Australian National Audit Office, as recently as today, has released information that highlights deficiencies in the management of information technology within the Department of Employment, Education and Training. Among other things it found that the operation of key information technology services in the Department had been jeopardised by the transfer of computer operations from Melbourne to Canberra, when 95 per cent of Melbourne-based technical staff left the Department. It further found that parliamentary oversight of the Department's management of information technology had been hindered by an excessive delay in responding to the recommendations of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, and that a substantial waste of public money had resulted from an unsuccessful attempt to acquire a human resource management system.

The next Liberal-National Party government, which is not very far away, will provide a dramatic and beneficial alternative to this self-serving maladministration. Our proposals for government involve a less costly but more effective public sector; one which is less intrusive but which enforces clear general laws, fairly and equally applied; and a role for government which will provide a framework of policy and law within which people can plan with confidence. The current size of government imposes an onerous burden on and costly intervention in the lives of individuals, families and businesses. The size and costs of government are excessive, and under a Liberal-National Party government will be reduced.

As we have seen in many areas of the Hawke Labor Administration, there is still a requirement to target programs more effectively and reduce or abolish programs that are no longer cost effective or appropriate. Over many years, governments have increasingly and inappropriately involved themselves in the provision of goods and services that are more efficiently provided by the private sector. Public sector activities are often shielded from competition, whereas individual firms in a competitive private sector have no option but to minimise their costs and maximise efficiency if they are to prosper. This means that they must be innovative and responsive to changing demands.

The users of many services currently supplied by government would benefit considerably if these services were delivered by the private sector. The contracting out of such services will provide a better definition and more direct targeting of the services provided. It will also enable the level of and the need for community service obligations to be accurately assessed and to be more cost efficient. For example, research indicates that at least 20 per cent can be saved in the cost of delivering services if they are contracted out.

Government should set the framework for action but not determine the content of action, which should as far as possible be left to individuals. The failure of government to provide such a satisfactory framework has been a central cause of Australia's recent spectacular decline. The most effective way for governments to meet that challenge in the 1990s is to create a predictable and orderly environment which will best enable individuals, families and businesses to achieve their values and plan for the future with certainty and confidence.

A government which tries to correct every social ill invariably creates more problems than it solves. The Hawke Government's ad hoc deal-driven policy interventions have meant that in many areas of national life no-one really knows what he can and cannot do. Labor has extended government by deal to the operation of many of our national institutions: it compromised the independence of the Reserve Bank of Australia when it engineered a change in bank rules to keep housing interest rates down in 1989; it has bullied, denigrated and ignored the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, whenever its decisions have diverged from the government line; and it ignored a High Court ruling on MP's postage which it found inconvenient.

Under this Hawke Labor Government, public administration has become increasingly out of touch with the needs and aspirations of the people it is supposed to serve. Politicians and officials have become too cocooned in Canberra and the Public Service has become increasingly in need of infusions of outside talent. The role of government under Labor expresses the traditional collectivist belief that Big Brother knows best. Whether the decision involves the ACTU, the Green movement or Labor's own factions, the views of the leaders are those which count and not those of the rank and file.

Labor's compulsory training levies, compulsory superannuation, compulsory arbitration, compulsory accords and a refusal to act against compulsory trade unionism exemplify a philosophy of government which continually resorts to coercion and compulsion in order to achieve its aims; yet every compulsion undermines motivation and distorts decisions. All compulsions strike at the roots of growth and prosperity, and no democratic government should lightly resort to coercion.

The Liberal and National parties believe that compulsion is justified only to ensure an equitable sharing of contributions to community well-being or to protect those members of the community who cannot look after themselves. But compulsion is always very costly. It should always be a last rather than a first resort and should never become a means of simply achieving political objectives.

The main task of government is to provide a framework of law within which people can plan their own lives in freedom and with confidence, and the framework which this country desperately requires is one which promotes prosperity and full employment. The primary role of government must be strategic and not focused on the distribution of benefits and privileges to its friends. Public policy may distinguish between activities which are equally legal. For example, it may seek to discourage smoking or encourage saving. But we should minimise distortions to maximise efficiency.

A Liberal-National Party government public sector will promote freedom of contract, exposure of monopolies to competition, fair dealing and open and competitive markets as well as the acceptance of liability by market participants and promotion of the public good by cultivating individual excellence. By exposing the public sector to these forces, the performance of government and its contribution to national well-being will be enhanced.

The Australian Public Service is capable of being a more vital, progressive, effective and efficient force in the development of our nation. Too many of the dedicated and professional men and women in the service of Australia have become hamstrung by the controls and regulations which have multiplied under this Government. The present Government has failed to encourage the Public Service to achieve its full potential.

A coalition government will be committed to the introduction of a new management philosophy which will enable the development of a highly respected, dynamic, enterprising Public Service capable of responding to the needs of our community. The next coalition Government—which, as I said, is now not very far away—will therefore introduce a range of reforms aimed at overcoming the present inefficiencies in government, including a new management philosophy in the Public Service and ensuring that the public sector in general meets the contemporary needs of Australia.

Among those reforms will be those which will provide more opportunities and incentives for achieving excellence and efficient and effective management and to make the public and private sectors more competitive. The reforms will also support the principle of a non-political career Public Service in which promotions and appointments are based on merit. Our reforms will also provide public servants as far as possible with similar terms and conditions of employment to those available in the private sector. Therefore, a coalition administration of the public sector will ensure that the sorts of rorts which have become endemic under this failed Hawke Labor Government and which this legislation belatedly seeks to remove will be decidedly a thing of the past.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—The Public Service Amendment Bill 1991 is a Bill which amends the officers mobility provisions contained in part 4 of the Public Service Act. The purpose of this Bill was described in my second reading speech: it is to remove the opportunity of double-dipping where officers of the Australian Public Service are working on secondment in agencies of the Government or in government business enterprises and where redundancies in those enterprises occur. The officers, therefore, by virtue of the carriage of this Bill, if made law, will be prevented from exercising a double dip in redundancy benefits at both the agency or the government business enterprise and, later, upon return to the Australian Public Service.

PARA.TAB: The best summary of the purpose of the Bill is found in the seventh paragraph of my second reading speech. I welcome the Opposition's support of this legislation. I note that the speech in reply to the second reading speech, which was just delivered by Senator Chapman, has not really confined itself to the limits of the legislation before the chamber. Certainly, Senator Chapman made a few remarks about that. Those remarks were unfavourable to the Government; that is what one would expect of an Opposition and I am not surprised by any of that. Nonetheless, the Opposition is supporting this legislation and the Government welcomes that.

I think the remainder of the remarks made by the Opposition are best characterised as an ideological rave. Buoyed up by the enthusiasm of the `Frightpack' that was released by Dr Hewson last week, we had the ebullient enthusiasm of the Opposition demonstrated today in a more unruly Question Time than normal as it pressed the so-called merits of its case. That is the role of an Opposition and one acknowledges it. Thank God; it is about time. Question Time in this place was a bit more exciting today than it has normally been over the last few months. Some of us on the front bench have almost dozed off, given the somnolent nature of the Opposition's attack on us over the past few months. We welcome a chance to sharpen our act and we thank the Opposition for performing a bit better today.

But I do not propose to embark on a comprehensive reply to this ideological wandering by Senator Chapman, other than to say these things, quickly and in summary. The most far reaching reform of the Australian Public Service is the reform that has been enacted under this Government. That is acknowledged; the authorities on the subject of public sector reform acknowledge that. It has been a reform through which we have devolved more responsibilities to the departments to have greater control and say over the management of the affairs within their portfolios. We have introduced program budgeting and we have insisted upon the establishment of performance indicators so that efficiency and productivity can be measured against objective criteria.

The Australian Public Service is now regarded by other public services in the world as being among the world's best, in terms of its efficiency and productivity. We have provided a degree of commercialisation of sections of the Public Service and we have, where appropriate, invited outside contracting of some of the things performed within the Public Service. But we have not made a fetish of those things. We have done them in recognition of the fact that the process is not an end in itself. Commercialisation is not some token god which is an end in itself; its purpose is to make the service more efficient and to deliver a better quality service.

The issue of quality may be separate from that of price. The cost of delivering a public service is one thing; the quality of it is quite another. It is more difficult to judge the second of those two criteria and it is more simplistic and easier to judge the first. But we have insisted on delivering both. I will make the other observation that is invited by the comments which have been made here this evening, that neither I nor the Government believes one can run the health or welfare services of Australia by contracting them into private hands. There is a clear role for the public sector. They are two areas in which that role is very clear, and that is in great contradistinction to the Opposition's policy.

There are many things one could go to in this debate but, as I have said, they are not related to the precise purposes of this legislation. I do not want anyone to think that my cutting short of my remarks is anything to do with a lack of argument. It certainly is not. But I do think this chamber should be as the Australian Public Service has increasingly been recognised as being, that is, a bit more efficient in the passage of Bills. Therefore, I will not debate any further. I commend the Opposition for its support and I commend the Bill to the chamber.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

DEBATE.TITLE: INTERNATIONAL MONETARY FUND (QUOTA INCREASE AND AGREEMENT AMENDMENTS) BILL 1991

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 6 November, on motion by Senator McMullan:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The International Monetary Fund (Quota Increase and Agreement Amendments) Bill 1991 implements Australia's part in giving effect to decisions taken at the ninth general review of IMF quotas. That review took place in 1990, and this is the enactment of Australia's involvement in that.

PARA.TAB: At that 1990 review Australia joined a consensus of member countries of the IMF to, firstly, increase quotas in order to enhance the capacity of the IMF to provide effective assistance and, secondly, to strengthen the measures available for use against member countries in arrears with their accrued obligations to the IMF. That essentially involves the suspension of voting and associated rights of the offending members.

The proposed increase in Australia's quota is from $2.8 billion to $4 billion, an increase of some 44 per cent. That contribution compares with the increase in members' quotas as a whole by 50 per cent, so our increase is somewhat less than the aggregate overall increase. The reason for the increase is to help augment the International Monetary Fund's financial resources. Those have been placed under considerable pressure by drawings required by member countries since the previous review of quotas that occurred seven years ago.

Augmenting the IMF in this way will allow it to continue to provide temporary balance of payments assistance to members experiencing weak external positions and, in so doing, will help to promote a more stable international monetary system. That, of course, has been one of the basic objectives of the International Monetary Fund since its establishment as one of the so-called Bretton Woods twins after the Second World War—the other twin, of course, being the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development which is now known as the World Bank. Australia has always been a strong supporter of those Bretton Woods twins, and I think we have always been a respected member of both institutions. So far as the International Monetary Fund is concerned, we have always been a contributor to the Fund and never, to my knowledge, have we drawn on its resources.

Of course, the way things are going in Australia at the moment, unless our external position improves substantially, it is conceivable that the day will come when we have to go cap in hand to the IMF for financial assistance. I hope we can avoid that. Unless we change direction in this country, the prospect of that cannot be dismissed.

For the immediate term, the increase in our quota does not represent a drain on our resources because it is essentially the substitution of one asset for another on the national balance sheet. The foreign currency and special drawing rights, or SDRs as they are commonly called, purchased from the Reserve Bank and deposited with the International Monetary Fund, count as part of our international reserve assets, as they did prior to the transaction. The advantage of the substitution of assets for Australia is that by depositing funds with the International Monetary Fund the asset is augmentable in the event of an exchange rate crisis.

Australia's large and persistent current account deficit is a matter of great concern to Australia and to the economy as a whole. It is something that the Government, with its present approach and its policy paralysis, is incapable of correcting. The Government caused the problems that we have, but it does not seem to be in a position to solve them. If the insidious current account deficit is being held down—it has fallen somewhat over the last year or so but is still extraordinarily and dangerously high by all past standards—it is occurring by strangulation rather than a healthy competitive economy. This continuing major deficit in our balance of payments has led to a vast build-up in our net foreign liabilities. That, of course, is to the detriment of future generations. Those liabilities are drawing on our resources of the future and, therefore, it is our children and grandchildren who will be left to fix the debt.

Over the last five to six years the current account deficit has hovered around 4 to 5 per cent of gross domestic product. In 1989-90, it was 6 per cent of GDP and that percentage was the highest in the developed world. As our current account deficit has increased, there has been more than a fivefold increase in our foreign liabilities, counting both debt and equity. At the last count, those foreign liabilities stood at no less than $176 billion. They increase by about $1 billion every month as the bad news on our external account front continues to roll in.

The cost of servicing our net foreign liabilities is now running at about $17 billion per year. That is in the order of 4 1/2 per cent of gross domestic product; it is about 25 per cent of our total export earnings. For every dollar in exports that we earn through wheat, wool or whatever other commodity or service we export, 25c in every dollar is going simply to meet our debt obligations. As such, it is a massive drain on the economy and a major reason for the erosion of living standards and the associated loss of jobs in this country.

To illustrate the impact of the high cost of servicingour foreign debt liabilities, just consider the boost which would occur to employment if there were a 4 1/2 per cent boost to our gross domestic product. They are the sorts of magnitudes that we are talking about. That is the perspective in which this debt obligation needs to be looked at.

The basic cause of this burgeoning current account deficit and the consequent build-up in foreign liabilities has been the persistent trend of too much domestic spending relative to our ability to produce. That is not to say that our demand is necessarily high by international standards. More to the point, it is that our productivity is depressingly low. We are inefficient in many things we do. To our regret, and to the real shame of this Government, most of the reasons for our inefficiencies are the result of Government inaction or, more to the point, the Government's fear to act lest it might have to face up to the electoral consequences of upsetting a few of its mates in influential and privileged positions.

The Industry Commission and the Business Council of Australia have, in recent research, indicated that with the proper structural reform of our economy, at least a 15 per cent increase in our gross domestic product could be achieved. In other words, our gross domestic product could be permanently increased by at least $60 billion if the necessary reform measures were taken. Those reforms lie right across the board of infrastructure industries in Australia—the areas of domestic water transport, bulk commodity handling, international shipping, rail transport, domestic aviation, international aviation, road transport, post and telecommunications, electricity supply, rural and manufacturing assistance, water services, contracting out, labour market reform, and capital productivity.

If the inefficiencies in those areas were tackled seriously, there would be a $60 billion boost to our gross domestic product, if one can believe the studies of the highly respected Industry Commission and also the studies commissioned by the Business Council of Australia.

The other side of the excess consumption relative to production coin is that there has been too little saving and, accordingly, too little investment. As inevitably follows, there has been an abysmal performance in the productivity stakes, as I mentioned earlier, and a consequent loss in international competitiveness. The domestic spending binge really stemmed from the expansionist policy of the Hawke Government when it first took office in 1983. `Expansionist' is, of course, often another word for `soft touch' or `do anything to stay in power even if it wrecks the country'. That was precisely the policy approach taken by this Government in its early years. We have been living with the disastrous consequences of that ever since.

The main factors that were pushing domestic demand in those early days were of course the Keating Budget deficits from 1983-84 through to 1985-86. It is often forgotten that the size of those deficits in those years and the rate of increase in government spending in real terms matched fairly well the enormous excesses in government spending that occurred during the three years of the Whitlam Labor Government, which excesses of course set in train many of the fundamental problems with which we have been grappling unsuccessfully ever since.

Those Keating Budget deficits produced a huge financing requirement, and that was rapidly translated into monetary expansion, higher inflation, current account deficits, and a rapid increase in the funds owed to foreign lenders and equity holders. When that damage had been done, the perpetrator himself, namely, the then Treasurer and now ex-Treasurer, Mr Keating, declared that Australia faced the prospect of becoming a banana republic. That was certainly the case, and it still remains the case. The thing that should never be forgotten is that the duo of policy developers and architects of that situation were the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, and the former Treasurer, Mr Keating.

By the second half of the 1980s the effects of the dramatic overheating of the economy had come home to roost. It was an overheating which was entirely due to irresponsible economic management and the irresistible temptation of the Government to fiddle with the economic levers for short term political gain. The artificially overheated economy saw a surge in private investment but, in response to the signals of the time, that investment went into property speculation and takeovers. Very little of it went into productive plant and equipment. The Government was entirely at fault because interest rates were maintained too low for too long on top of a surge in commodity prices.

As a result, the lending binge went on and the current account deficit blew out to 6 per cent of GDP in 1989. We were in a dreadful upward spiral that inevitably had to burst. This brought about the devastation of jobs, output and living standards that we have been witnessing in the last two years. During this time we have suffered the most severe recession in Australia in the last 60 years. None of those current problems should have been experienced. They were all due to the major policy miscalculations by Prime Minister Hawke and ex-Treasurer Keating that occurred in the middle and late 1980s.

Having caused the problem within appropriate fiscal and monetary policies and being incapable of making any worthwhile micro-economic reforms to reduce the cost of doing business in Australia, the Government then resorted to murderously high interest rates. Business rates were over 20 per cent for over a year in an attempt to kill demand.

In keeping with this fascination for deceiving the Australian people, the Government perpetrated the view—we will never forget this; it was put around publicly just before the last election by both the Prime Minister and ex-Treasurer Keating—that, firstly, there would be no recession and, secondly, even when that falsehood was revealed, there would in fact be a soft landing. The truth, of course, is that that policy created a vicious cycle and the most severe recession for 60 years.

Given the mess that Labor has made of the Australian economy, it was not inconceivable that the IMF may have been brought in by Australia's creditors to put the house in order. I am referring to the 1980s generally. In 1986, for example, there was a very rapid depreciation of the exchange rate. That was at the time of the banana republic statements by the ex-Treasurer. It was at a time when Australia faced a major external crisis—a crisis that essentially has continued ever since then.

The fact that the exchange rate was allowed to float was no doubt one of the reasons that the IMF was prepared to wait and see what happened rather than intervene in our internal situation. Subsequently, the fact that the Budget was brought into balance and then into surplus at the end of the decade was sufficient to maintain credibility with the international financial community, although we suffered and continue to suffer in terms of reduced international credit ratings.

The inherent problem remains: we are still a country at very high risk. The ratio of foreign liabilities to GDP is still rising. Overcoming that problem requires radical change. There is no way we are going to get out of our present problems by tinkering at the edges or by incremental change. Overcoming our problems requires radical change. The essence of the task is that in order to stabilise our foreign liabilities as a proportion of GDP we need to shift at least 4 per cent of economic activity into the tradables sector. That translates to a 25 per cent increase or thereabouts in net exports. That shift from the domestic to the external sector has never, in our postwar period, been achieved in any one year, let alone been sustained for a period of years, and it is that that is required simply to stabilise the existing level of debt.

So we have an enormous task ahead of us. Achieving that target will require a massive increase in productivity in order to become competitive on world markets. Only the types of measures that are contained in the coalition's set of proposals that were launched last week, the Fightback proposals—only measures of that order of magnitude and that order of change to our existing circumstances—will lead us towards the achievement of that goal. It is the only hope for Australia to make dramatic and radical change.

As I have said, it is no good tinkering at the edges. We have been doing that for decades and look where it has got us: it has got us on a downward slippery slope scale of international comparative living standards; it has produced massive unemployment and hardship in this nation. The sooner we realise the magnitude of the task ahead of us the better. The longer we delay making the changes of the type that have been outlined by the coalition in its dramatic proposals, released in recent days, the more intractable our problems will become and the less opportunity there will be to have the hope and the vision and the jobs that Australia and Australians so desperately crave.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know the hour is late but there are some important details I want to address in my response to the International Monetary Fund Bill. This is not a contentious Bill and it is supported by the Australian Democrats. The Bill proposes two amendments to the principal Act, that is, the International Monetary Agreement Act 1947. These are an increase in Australia's quota in the International Monetary Fund and an alteration to the rules of the IMF concerning the voting rights of member countries who are in arrears to the IMF.

PARA.TAB: The IMF was established to promote international monetary cooperation. It provides temporary financing to member countries experiencing balance of payments difficulties. It also seeks to promote orderly exchange arrangements, a multilateral payment system free from restrictions, and international monetary cooperation generally. Australia has been a member since 1947, with total current membership being 155 countries. The fund is controlled by a board of governors which comprises representatives of all member nations and the Treasurer (Mr Kerin) is Australia's representative. There is also an interim committee of the board of governors which comprises 22 members, either representing their own interests or those of a particular constituency. Membership of this interim committee arises if a country is entitled to an executive director's position on the executive board of the fund. Since 1948 Australia has represented our constituency of Pacific and Asian nations on the executive board and, hence, has been a member of the interim committee of governors.

Each member of the fund is assigned a quota, which determines its financial and organisational relations with the fund. Quotas determine members' subscriptions, their relative voting power, their access to fund financing, and their shares in allocations of special drawing rights, which I shall refer to as SDRs. The SDR is an international reserve asset created by the IMF. These are allocated to member countries, who can hold them as international reserves or use them in a variety of transactions with the IMF. The value of the SDR is calculated as a weighted basket of the five major currencies. The Commonwealth Government has transferred its SDRs to the Reserve Bank, less net charges of the IMF payable by the Commonwealth. As at 30 June this year, Australia had 131,738,522 SDRs, valued at over $226m.

The usual financial transactions which Australia undertakes are, firstly, the maintenance of value obligations to the fund. If the value of a member's currency varies against the SDR during the year, the member country must adjust the fund's holding of its currency. For the year ended 30 April 1990, Australia had to pay the IMF almost $140m as a maintenance of value payment. Secondly, participation in operational budgets is necessary to provide domestic currencies in exchange for other currencies to assist the fund needs of the fund. Operational budget transactions affect only the composition, not the level, of a country's international reserve assets.

Thirdly, there are three categories of transactions in special drawing rights. Firstly, designation plans identify those countries with sufficiently strong external positions that are called upon to provide foreign currencies in exchange for SDRs from countries with weak external positions. The IMF levies charges on the SDRs that have been allocated to member countries and pays interest on those SDRs that are held by each member. As Australia's actual SDR holdings are well below our maximum allocation, we must pay an annual amount to the fund. In 1989-90, this amounted to over 20 million SDRs. In addition, an annual assessment to cover the administration is payable. This was over 94,000 SDRs in 1989-90.

Finally, if the fund's holdings of a member's currency fall below a certain level, the fund pays remuneration to the member for the use of its currency. In 1989-90, Australia received remuneration of nearly six million SDRs. So the aggregate size of quotas and their distribution are key elements in the operation of the IMF. Consequently, the articles of agreement provide for a general review of quotas at intervals of not more than five years.

The Bill before the Senate tonight seeks to implement the general quotas that apply to member countries as agreed under the ninth general review of quotas. This review commenced in March 1987 and was completed in June 1990. The resolution adopted by the board of governors on that date provides for an aggregate quota increase of 50 per cent. This is the same increase as occurred in the seventh and eighth general reviews, which were completed in 1978 and 1983 respectively. This will augment the IMF's financial resources which, according to the speech by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan), have been `placed under considerable pressure by the drawings made by member countries since the last general review of quotas some seven years ago'.

Australia's allocation increase was proposed at 44 per cent. This Bill seeks to implement that proposal. This will leave Australia at the same relative ranking within the IMF—that is, a ranking of thirteenth.
