The increase will come into effect before 31 December this year if members accounting for at least 85 per cent of existing quotas consent to their respective increases before that date. They must also accept the other proposals in this Bill concerning member countries that are in arrears to the IMF, and I will deal with them later. The proposed increase in Australia's quota is from about $2.8 billion to about $4 billion. Clause 5 of the Bill authorises the Treasurer to consent to this increase on behalf of Australia.

The financing of this obligation is a complex one which will not affect the Budget deficit. It is characterised as a financing or below the line transaction in our complex system of public accounting. In any event Australia will not be sending a cheque for $1.2 billion to the IMF this year. The method of payment is provided for in the IMF articles of agreement and the ninth quota review resolution approved by the board of governors. Of the additional quota subscription, 75 per cent will be paid in Australian dollars and the remainder in SDRs and foreign currency.

Clause 6 allows the Australian dollar component—75 per cent of the increase in the quota—to be paid in the form of a non-negotiable and non-interest-bearing security. The issue of this security will not affect the Consolidated Revenue Fund. It is a promise to pay the IMF in Australian dollars if the Fund needs more Australian currency than it holds. The second reading speech states that the likelihood of the IMF actually calling in this security is remote.

Section 7 of the principal Act establishes the general use of and standing appropriation for securities issued under clause 6. The foreign currency and SDRs required will be purchased by the Commonwealth from the Reserve Bank of Australia. Clause 7 of this Bill authorises an appropriation for the purpose of purchasing of foreign currency and the SDRs will be purchased under the standing appropriation of sub-section 5A(6) of the principal Act.

The second matter covered by this Bill is a set of proposals to alter the IMF's articles of agreement. These are known as the third amendment and were adopted by the board of governors to strengthen the IMF's capacity to deal with members who are consistently in arrears to it. The term `third amendment' refers to the fact that this is the third time the IMF's articles of agreement will be changed.

The first amendment arose in July 1966 because Ministers from the G10 nations agreed to create additional reserve assets in the Fund at some time in the future. After the consideration of many options, the first agreement entered into force on 28 July 1969, establishing a new facility based on special drawing rights and making other changes to Fund rules and practices.

Following the years of paying special attention to the problems of the less developed member countries, including setting up the group of 24, which includes a geographically representative cross-section of less developed countries, the second amendment came into force in April 1978. The amendments related to the exchange arrangements, the reduced role of gold in the IMF and making the special drawing right the principal reserve asset of the Fund. At 30 April 1991, nine members had accumulated overdue obligations of more than $US5.7 billion.

The proposed third amendment changes to the IMF articles are as follows: firstly, the suspension of voting and associated rights of members in arrears would be a compulsory step interposed between a declaration of ineligibility and a compulsory withdrawal; secondly, a 70 per cent majority of the executive board would be required to impose or terminate such a suspension; thirdly, a suspended member would lose the right to vote in any organ of the Fund on most amendments to the articles and in elections of officials; fourthly, the governor or alternate governor of a suspended member would immediately cease to hold office; and, fifthly, the executive director representing a suspended member would lose office though, if also representing other non-suspended members, would be eligible for re-election by those other members.

To the extent that these measures will reduce the amount of arrears outstanding to the IMF, all other members, including Australia, will directly benefit by lower costs. It is also claimed that Australia and other members will benefit indirectly from a stronger IMF which can obtain more consistent adherence by members to their obligations. The IMF provides general financial assistance to states. Eligibility depends on national need, which is evidenced by poor current account performance.

In addition to this, a variety of international agencies provide specific project related aid to less developed nations. Australia is involved in many, but not all, of these international agencies. The most well known of these is the World Bank group. Another international development agency of which Australia is a member is the recently established European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, which will provide assistance to the former Eastern Bloc nations and the former USSR to convert their economic systems to market oriented ones. I wish them luck.

The Treasurer gives an annual report on Australia's participation in the World Bank's activities and the assessment of the efficiency and effectiveness of those activities pursuant to section 7 of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (General Capital Increase) Act 1989, as well as the annual report required by section 10 of the International Monetary Agreements Act 1947.

The last tabled report on Australia's participation in the World Bank relates to the year ended 30 June 1990. The report incorrectly states that Australia was not a signatory to the ICSID Convention as at 30 June. This report arose on the initiative of former Democrats Senator Macklin, who was concerned that the World Bank group's activities did not sufficiently take into account the problem of environmental degradation and the rights of indigenous groups affected by development activities and that the original report under the Monetary Agreements Act did not adequately report on these and other matters such as success in poverty alleviation and the efficiency of the group's activities.

It is important at this point to remember that the various arms of the World Bank group operate to provide finance or to provide guarantees to financiers on behalf of member countries on a project basis rather than the general assistance provided by the IMF. Thus the bank group operates at the micro level while the IMF operates more at the macro level.

The report shows that between 1965 and 1985 average per capita consumption in developing countries rose by over 70 per cent in real terms; average life expectancy increased from 51 to 62 years; and primary school enrolment rates increased from 73 to 84 per cent. Despite these achievements, over one billion people or one-third of the developing world still live in poverty in 1990 and the number is now on the increase again. More than half of these people—about 600 million —live in extreme poverty; that is, they struggle to meet the minimum needs of life. These people are concentrated in South and East Asia and sub-Saharan Africa, as are the bulk of the world's poor.

It is in this context that Australia's foreign aid performance must be judged. The Prime Minister has stated his goal—his cliched goal these days—of making Australia the clever country, but his Government's foreign aid record has certainly made Australia the mean or miserly country. The United Nations target for foreign aid for developed countries is 0.7 per cent of gross domestic product, although few nations achieve this. The Scandinavian nations and some oil rich Middle Eastern states are the exceptions.

Our recent performance in foreign aid is nothing short of a disgrace. The boom years of the deregulation decade of the 1980s saw a consumption binge by the rich and powerful and the coining of a new term—`conspicuous consumption'. During this period, fast money and the relative decline of the Anglo-Saxon world, especially in trading terms, saw Australia's foreign aid decline from the reasonable levels of the Fraser Government—about 0.51 per cent of GDP—to the pitiful level of 0.33 per cent in 1990. The estimated allocation this financial year is marginally better at 0.35 per cent of GDP. That is exactly half the level the United Nations recommends and only one-third of the level that the Australian Democrats would like to see as a long term goal. This has occurred at the time that we are supposed to be integrating into our region—the region that undoubtedly contains the majority of the poorest people in the world.

Our alternative Budget put forward proposals to raise our aid allocation by an additional $420m, which would raise our contribution to the still inadequate level of 0.45 per cent of GDP. Our proposals will emphasise locally initiated and controlled cooperative programs which contribute to the alleviation of poverty, ecological sustainability, the special needs of women, and indigenous people's rights. In addition, global environmental concerns would be addressed in the areas of population, family planning and rainforest protection.

As well as the legacy of colonisation and the historical exploitation of the developing world by the Western nations, the poorer countries now have the insurmountable obstacle of massive foreign debt. This Parliament recently considered this problem in the report entitled Third World Debt; An Australian View, which was delivered by the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade in November 1989. This report concluded that Third World debt problems have been severe and chronic since the beginning of the 1980s, particularly in Latin America and sub-Saharan Africa. There is no single cause of the problem. The crisis of the early and mid-1980s arose because the optimistic forecasts relating to servicing costs and commodity prices were not realised. As well, there was the combination of reckless lending by many Western institutions and reckless borrowing by many nations.

Until the 1970s, Western banks' involvement with the less developed countries was limited to short term trade financing, loans to countries in conjunction with IMF stabilisation programs and some project related loans. The less developed nations basically relied on finance from foreign governments and from the international development agencies. The total debt owed to private banks in 1971 was 7 per cent of the foreign debt of the less developed nations. The level since that time has increased to about 33 per cent.

The first oil price shock produced massive balance of payments imbalances between the OPEC nations, which enjoyed huge surpluses, and the rest of the world. There was a significant fear that the OPEC nations would not reinvest this money, thus creating a capital shortage in both the developed and less developed nations, which may even have led to a world depression.

Poland experienced a foreign debt crisis in 1981, and in August 1982 the Mexican finance Minister announced that his country could not meet its debt servicing payments. This was crucial because Mexico was an oil exporter and had been regarded as the best credit risk of the less developed nations. Loans to several other countries had to be rescheduled and there was genuine fear that a general debt moratorium could wipe out some of the largest Western financial institutions with a consequent collapse of the international monetary system. At this point the IMF intervened and imposed a series of economic policy conditions on Mexico and, later, Brazil. In return, rescheduling of obligations was negotiated. This was not a philanthropic exercise, but merely a realisation that payment could not be made when it became due but could possibly be accommodated at a future time.From 1982 to 1990 there has been a net transfer of $334 billion from the Third World to the first. Literally, the rich are getting richer and the poor are financing them.

Although the bank lent over $20 billion last year, the actual net disbursements plummeted from $11.6 billion to $7.8 billion. The new concern is that although loans are expected to increase next year to about $30 billion, a lot of this will go to eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union, and that the extreme poverty in Asia and Africa will not be alleviated.

The human and environmental cost of this result is enormous. Poor nations are forced to unsustainably exploit their natural resources, especially forest resources, to obtain funds to service their debt. This in turn increases supply, which depresses the prices obtained for the commodity. In addition, since almost any development project must be pursued to raise foreign exchange to pay the interest on their foreign debt, poorer nations have become pollution havens, accepting those projects which would not be allowed in the wealthier nations. So we see the intrinsic link between environmental degradation and poverty, with excessive foreign debt being the catalyst to both.

In 1984 the environment movement, through the then head of the World Wildlife Fund, Dr Thomas Lovejoy, proposed the idea of debt for nature swaps. This will allow conservation groups to purchase a debt from the financier and then swap it with the debtor nation to pay for environmental projects. In 1987 the first debt for nature swap went ahead in Bolivia. This was followed by swaps in Ecuador, Costa Rica, the Philippines, Madagascar, Zambia and the Dominican Republic. Although all of these have been worthwhile exercises, the scale is still small. Total swaps as at 1990 stood at only $26m.

Karl Ziegler, a merchant banker, has proposed a $50 billion swap deal between Brazilian debt and the Amazon rainforest. The Brazilian Government initially opposed what it saw as the economic and ecological imperialism of such a proposal. However, that has changed to a question of negotiating an appropriate arrangement. The Australian Democrats certainly support this kind of initiative.

The whole world needs these resources and the whole world should contribute to their maintenance if that is the only way that they can be preserved. Similar action is necessary in respect of Asian and African rainforests. The subject of foreign aid and the plight of the less developed nations are huge subjects. My colleague Senator Bourne will expand briefly upon these matters in her contribution.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.

TALK.START.PARA: —As my colleague Senator Kernot has already outlined, the Australian Democrats will be supporting the International Monetary Fund (Quota Increase and Agreement Amendments) Bill 1991. My purpose in speaking is to place on record some concerns about the conditions which the IMF attaches to its assistance and loans to developing countries. As the Senate is aware, one of the International Monetary Fund's prime objectives is to assist countries which run into difficulties over their external accounts. The IMF understandably perceives that it has a duty to see that a country, with an external deficit problem which is drawing on IMF reserves, is operating its economy in a way which meets with the approval of the organisation's board of directors.

PARA.TAB: In the past decade or so, this concept has blossomed into conditionality, which refers to the terms the fund attaches to the use of its financial resources. It is this concept of conditionality and the methods which the IMF uses to exercise its overseeing role which have worried a number of international aid groups in recent years. The IMF tells us that in exercising its overall supervisory role it is merely fulfilling financial commitments to its own members and this is as it should be. In most cases, this does not cause too many problems.

Access to IMF funds is based on formulas and a country which is borrowing need only be willing to cooperate with the IMF in working out solutions to its balance of payments problems. However, in certain instances where a country borrows a great deal of money, or up to 75 per cent of its own IMF quota, the IMF will place additional conditions on the loan. The disadvantage is in the conditions which are attached to that loan. Usually it will mean that the IMF will present a borrowing nation with a written program for correcting that country's balance of payments problems. Often these problems require major policy commitments on the part of the nation's government.

Over the last decade or so the criticism has been made that these conditions are based on a standardised framework that pays little attention to the specific circumstances of each individual country. This has clearly resulted in a number of problems for developing countries. In some cases, the loan arrangements have concentrated on balance of payments problems to the exclusion of any other factors peculiar to that nation's economic growth and development.

Most seriously, in the case of developing nations in particular, the strict conditions which the IMF places on its lending programs can lead to an overall reduction in the standard of living of the population. From Egypt and Jamaica in the late 1970s, to Venezuela and Trinidad in the late 1980s, and a host of other countries in between, the world has witnessed a strong reaction to the IMF and its financial programs. The price effects of devaluation, the reduction in subsidies and the increases in indirect taxes which follow the IMF recommendations to cut back a developing country's fiscal deficit often lead to high price increases in the basic consumer goods in that country.

This invariably penalises the more vulnerable and poorer members of society. Consequently, while loans in many instances may not be used for the direct benefit of the people, the burden of servicing these loans lies squarely on the shoulders of the poor.

Those of us who are concerned about these developments argue that the industrialised world, which is dominant in the IMF's decision making processes, should be less rigid and dogmatic in the assistance programs it forces on to the less developed nations. It is encouraging that in more recent years the IMF has been attaching greater importance to collaborating with member countries in looking at ways to improve the design of programs to protect the poorest segments of a developing country's population.

Despite this, the Australian Democrats along with a number of other community groups, particularly aid agencies, argue that much more could be done at the senior levels of the IMF to improve its policy and decision making processes. To this end, I will be moving an amendment to the second reading of this Bill requesting that the Federal Government take action to broaden the selection process for the positions which Australia holds at the IMF. One of the problems with the IMF has been that those serving on the board of governors in the position of executive director often come with a very specialised financial or economic view of how the world operates.

In the past, Australia's position at the IMF has usually been filled by someone from Treasury. As with the positions Australia holds on similar institutions, such as the International Development Fund, it is possible that an officer with foreign affairs, trade or aid experience will be able to provide some useful insights into how the IMF can improve the structuring of its financial assistance packages and, in doing so, limit the adverse impacts on the populations of those developing countries in need of the assistance. The Australian Democrats' second reading amendment also urges the Government to call on the International Monetary Fund to improve its decision making processes on loan assistance programs by carrying out an environment and poverty impact statement in conjunction with that package.

I note here that the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade in its report of November 1989 on Third World debt, which has just been mentioned by Senator Kernot, recommended a similar course of action. It recommended that the International Monetary Fund should be required to prepare social impact statements in respect of country adjustment programs that it initiates. On page 48 of that report, the Committee explains the reasons why such a proposal should receive Government support. On this basis, I look forward to the support of all sides in the Senate and now move:
At end of motion, add ", but the Senate:

(a)calls upon the Government to open nominations for the positions of Executive Director and Alternative Executive Director at the International Monetary Fund to competition on merit and for the selection process to be transparent, fair and independent; and

SPEECH.PARA: (b)calls upon the Government to urge the International Monetary Fund to produce an environment and poverty impact statement in conjunction with all structural adjustment financing packages.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to address briefly a particular issue which is relevant to the International Monetary Fund (Quota Increase and Agreement Amendments) Bill. The Bill increases Australia's contribution to the IMF by 44 per cent through the issue of a non-negotiable and non-interest bearing security. The IMF provides direct financial assistance as well as finance to specific projects mainly through the World Bank group. In this connection, I direct the attention of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) to the World Declaration on the Survival, Protection and Development of Children. Australia endorsed the World Declaration on the Survival, Protection and Development of Children at the World Summit for Children on 30 September 1990. Prime Minister Hawke signed the declaration on 13 May 1991. The declaration states in paragraph 19:

SPEECH.PARA: We ourselves hereby make a solemn commitment to give priority to the rights of children, to their survival and to their protection and development. This will ensure the well-being of all societies.
The plan of action for implementing the declaration states in part, in paragraph 34(iii):

Each country is urged to re-examine in the context of its particular national situation, its current budget, and in the case of donor countries, their development assistance budgets, to ensure that programs aimed at the achievement of goals for the survival, protection and development of children will have a priority when resources are allocated. Every effort should be made to ensure that such programs are protected in times of economic austerity and structural adjustment.
In a letter dated 24 June to a constituent concerned about this issue, Mr Stickney, the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development, Dr Neal Blewett, boasted:
Australia recently cosponsored a resolution at the United Nations General Assembly . . . which urges donor countries to assist developing countries to achieve the objectives of the Declaration.
He further said:

Could the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development advise the Senate whether Australia intends to discharge this responsibility through the project-specific financial assistance through the World Bank group? If this is not so—admittedly, it is somewhat unlikely—could he refer me to the specific allocation in the 1991-92 Budget for this purpose of implementing the declaration on the survival, protection and development of children?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the International Monetary Fund (Quota Increase and Agreement Amendments) Bill 1991. The second reading debate has provided an opportunity for honourable senators to range fairly widely, in terms of both domestic economic policy and their views about international equity matters and overseas aid. In a sense, quite a lot of the debate strayed a long way from the Bill and even the IMF; but, nevertheless, there were some worthwhile contributions. I thought Senator Short, from time to time, did give us a fairly articulate exposition of classical 1970s economics, which I suppose is appropriate for one of the people who have advocated a sort of `back to the future' economic policy. I am sure that the Australian public would be fascinated to hear him saying that interest rates were kept too low for too long.

PARA.TAB: Nevertheless, when we are talking about the International Monetary Fund we are talking about one of the major international financial institutions, of which Australia has been, and remains, a respected and effectively participating member. As a result of a long period of negotiation culminating in the meetings of the interim committee of the IMF in 1990, there were agreements about quota increases and amendments to the articles which have subsequently been reflected in this legislation. If the international pattern of developments continues, it is likely that both the increase in the quota and the amendments—because one is contingent upon the other—will come into effect by the end of the year.

I think that is the agreed background to both the second reading speech of the Minister for Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Treasurer (Mr Free), who introduced the Bill in the House of Representatives, and the contributions of honourable senators. The broad substance of the matters have been debated. I will merely respond to the amendment and I will respond very briefly to Senator Spindler's point, although I have to say I will not be able to contribute much by way of a speech during the second reading debate in answer to the questions he has raised.

The amendment moved by Senator Bourne on behalf of the Australian Democrats is really a matter that relates more particularly to issues that have been of concern with regard to the World Bank, rather than the IMF. That is not to say that it has no relevance to the IMF; I understand the concern that people have, and I will come back to that in a moment. Australia's relationship with the World Bank has been a major issue of debate internationally and in the aid movement in Australia, both in terms of this and the other international financial institutions—in particular, the Asian Development Bank and also the EBRD, to which Senator Kernot referred—as to how we choose our executive and/or alternative executive directors and as to their views about the environment and the poverty impact of the policies of those international financial institutions.

The Senate is probably aware of it, but I reiterate that this Government has, in the last few years, changed the way in which executive and/or alternative executive directors have been selected. I express it like that because in some institutions we do not have both positions. In the World Bank, for example, we do not have both an executive director and an alternative executive director, because we represent a broader grouping of nations. One of the positions is usually held by a representative of one of the other nations in our group.

We have opened up the positions of World Bank and ADB executive directors and alternates to open advertisement. The recent selection of Australia's executive director to the ADB went to a non-Treasury person. So that process is under way. I believe that is the appropriate process, and I welcome the change.

I am not keen to see the amendment carried at this stage. I think it is a matter we should debate in the Senate, and there will be the alternative forum for that when the World Bank and the IMF reports by the Treasurer (Mr Kerin) come down as required by legislation. Those reports will be tabled this session and there will then be the opportunity for honourable senators to express a view.

I have some sympathy with, and I know a number of honourable senators on both sides of the chamber support, the thrust of both points in the amendment. Certainly I have long advocated that with regard to the selection of our executive director of the World Bank, but the IMF is a very different institution from the World Bank. It has a much narrower focus. It is much more directly a financial institution rather than the World Bank, which is fundamentally a development institution. Very broadly, I guess it is described as an aid institution. The IMF is an institution for the management of the international monetary system. So the narrower, more financial economic focus of selection of representatives for Australia at the IMF is appropriate.

The other comment about the wording of this amendment is that Australia does not actually have executive directors and alternative executive directors of the IMF. There is a group of nations, of which we are a member, which has executive directors and alternative executive directors. We are not entirely at liberty to choose just anybody we like. We have to have somebody who is acceptable to the representatives of those countries. It is not an Australian executive director; it is a person chosen to represent the group.

Australia is the largest member and usually has the executive director, but not always. Australia will not always, or certainly very rarely, have both the executive and alternate. I think we need to consider how we go about it. It is not impossible. We have done

SPEECH.PARA: something similar in the World Bank. I do not want to exaggerate the difficulty or problem with that. It is a bit of a wording problem.

PARA.TAB: We do want to talk about the environment and poverty issues which are more important at the World Bank than at the IMF. However, once again, I do not say it is of no significance because the extended structural adjustment financing packages are important and can have important domestic economic consequences for the countries entering into those agreements. But it is different from the World Bank.

I think the more appropriate forum to debate these quite important points that Senator Bourne and Senator Kernot have raised will be in the debate on those two reports when they come down. I reiterate the assurance that they will be brought down this session. If it is so late that we cannot facilitate a debate immediately, we will make some arrangement to ensure there is the opportunity for debate on those reports as soon as possible thereafter. I have already been approached by some Government senators about that.

Senator Spindler, as I think he acknowledged, was a little bit off the point in his remarks on this Bill. He seized the opportunity, but I cannot give him any information. He may want to follow up with me subsequently and I will get such information as I can for him. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wanted to say a couple of words about the amendment moved by the Australian Democrats to the motion for the second reading of the Bill. The Opposition will not be supporting the amendment, but I have a lot of sympathy certainly for the first part of the amendment. The second part of the amendment causes me some difficulties. I will outline them briefly.

PARA.TAB: I welcome the statement by Senator McMullan. I think that this Parliament does not debate enough. In fact, it is not sufficiently aware of the very significant importance of the international financial institutions, such as the IMF, the World Bank, the ADB and the EBRD. The Opposition would very much welcome debate on those matters. The reports that Senator McMullan referred to may well provide the best venue for that. My views on the two parts of the amendment are similar to those of Senator McMullan. We could go along with paragraph (a). I think there is something in that, although I take the points that Senator McMullan raised.

Paragraph (b) is a more difficult one. As Senator McMullan said, the IMF is really quite a different institution from the World Bank and the other agencies which are essentially of a bank lending nature. Institutions such as the IMF are more hardnosed and designed to come in and help a sister country to correct its basic internal problems which lead to an external exchange rate and a currency crisis.

Whilst I agree that to have environmental impact statements and poverty impact statements in conjunction with certain financing packages may be desirable, the basic role of the IMF is to try to get an internal economic discipline into countries that, as a result of a lack of internal discipline, have got themselves into external difficulties. To have a requirement for the IMF to produce impact statements of this nature could potentially exacerbate the problems that the IMF is there to tackle. A few wrong signals may be given by the IMF if it were required to take account of those aspects.

There are different disciplines involved through different institutions. The disciplines required by the International Monetary Fund are different from those of lending institutions such as the World Bank. Therefore, to some extent, paragraph (b) is more appropriate to a World Bank type of institution than to the IMF. I indicate that whilst the Opposition will not be supporting the Australian Democrat amendment we believe that it provides a good reason for us to have a look at some of these matters as a Parliament and a Senate before too long. I welcome the opportunity to participate in that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief. A couple of people would know that I have a particular interest in the IMF. I do not think we need to be lectured by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) about the difference between the IMF and the World Bank.

PARA.TAB: I appreciate what he said; that is, this Parliament will be given an opportunity to address those issues that we want to raise on these international financial institutions. It is my long held belief that the Parliament has not had sufficient time devoted to do just that. I welcome his statement. That is all I want to say. The occasion to debate this matter will not arise before the end of this year, but I look forward to it next year.
Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 3 June 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) How much was spent on staff travel in 1988-89 and 1989-90 by each of the departments and agencies for which the Minister has portfolio responsibility.
(2) What is the breakdown of total spending in terms of:
(a) air transport costs; (b) sea transport costs; (c) land transport costs; and (d) travelling allowance.
(3) What proportion of staff travelling expenses relate to travel overseas.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister representing the Attorney-General has advised that this answer replaces the answer (Hansard 8 October 1991, page 1592) previously supplied to the honourable senator in respect of the Department:

PARA.TAB: There are errors in the figures previously provided for the Department as follows:

Expenditure on staff travel in 1988-89 was $6,673,538 and not $4,812,598 as previously advised. The original figure did not include a segment of staff travel incurred by the Department prior to the commissioning of the Department's Financial Management Information System (FISCLE) in mid 1988-89.
The correct breakdown of travel expenditure for the Department in 1988-89 is:
(a) Air Transport—$2,409,127
(b) Sea Transport—NIL
(c) Land Transport—$1,868,341
(d) Travelling Allowance—$2,396,070
The proportion attributable to travel overseas was 12.4 per cent.
The 1989-90 expenditure of $5,748,073 previously given is correct but the disposition across the individual categories was incorrect. The disposition of funds in 1989-90 was:
(a) Air Transport—$1,572,748
(b) Sea Transport—NIL
(c) Land Transport—$1,440,031
(d) Travelling Allowance—$2,735,294
The proportion attributable to travel overseas was 25.9 per cent.

The abovementioned figures suggest a decrease in expenditure on travel between 1988-89 and 1989-90 but in 1989-90 the funds for the Federal Court of Australia, the Family Court of Australia and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal were appropriated under their own separate appropriations.

If the expenditure for the abovementioned agencies is added to the Department's travel expenditure in 1989-90 (to maintain comparability between 1988-89 and 1989-90) the revised figure for 1989-90 would be $7,219,434, or an increase of 8.2 per cent over the 1988-89 expenditure.

The increase is explained by the significant increase in overseas travel by the Special Investigations Unit (re War Crimes) in 1989-90 ($1,144,422 over 1988-89 expenditure of $498,993), offset by the impact of the pilots dispute in early 1989-90.

TALK.START.PARA: asked all portfolio Ministers, upon notice, on 17 October 1991:

PARA.TAB: Following Mr Rod Cameron's statement at a hearing of the Senate Select Committee on Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures on Friday, 11 October 1991, that `the [ANOP] questionnaires [that have been done for the Government since 1983] and the print-outs are always available to the client', will the department/agency request ANOP to provide a copy of the exact questionnaire used and the computer print-out of the results for all surveys undertaken by ANOP for the department/ agency since 1983 and provide me with a copy of the questionnaire and the computer print-out.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer, on behalf of all portfolio Ministers, to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: Some departments and agencies may have only required the collation and conclusions of surveys. Therefore, whether departments or agencies choose to request ANOP to provide to them a copy of the exact questionnaire used and computer print-out of the results for all or any surveys undertaken by ANOP for them since 1983 is for those departments and agencies to decide, having regard to matters such as their present operational requirement for those items and any relevant contractual arrangements between them and ANOP.

In order to decide whether Senator Bishop should be provided access to the particular questionnaires and computer print-outs of the results it would be necessary to undertake a proper assessment of those documents. My Parliamentary Secretary is writing to ministers to ask them to arrange for their departments and agencies to undertake such an assessment of any major surveys ANOP has carried out for them, where this is possible without an unreasonable diversion of resources from higher priority tasks. Depending on the outcome of those assessments, departments and agencies will make appropriate arrangements for Senator Bishop to have access to those items.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 23 October 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) On what grounds was the decision taken to introduce a patient contribution of $2.60 per prescription item for STEC and PTEC holders from 1 January 1991; please supply figures plus explanatory methodology.
(2) How effective has the patient contribution introduced in the 1990 Budget, for DTEC and SPBC holders, been.
(3) Does the Government accept the general proposition that benefits provided to veterans are based on compensation rather than welfare.
(4) Could it be reasonably argued that the requirement for all disability pensioners to pay a contribution towards pharmaceuticals represents a watering down of this principle.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The $2.60 patient contribution is being introduced to the Repatriation Pharmaceutical Benefit Scheme (RPBS) as a part of the overall strategy to encourage a more thoughtful and responsible use of drugs. Introduction of the charge will align the RPBS with the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS) where a similar co-payment was introduced for pensioners from November 1990. Data available to date indicates that introduction of the pensioner charge has resulted in a significant fall in demand without adverse health outcomes.

Veterans are being fully compensated by means of a pharmaceutical allowance for the effect of the patient contribution and safety nets will apply. No veteran will be worse off and, depending on the amount of drugs they use, many will be better off.
It is expected that as a result of the patient contribution there will be a fall in demand of 15 per cent compared to base line estimates.

Net savings are estimated to be—$1.1m in 1991-92, $10.5m in 1992-93, $11.4m in 1993-94 and $12.2m in 1994-95. Gross savings were arrived at by applying the 15 per cent fall in demand to the base estimates and assuming that 10 per cent of RPBS scripts will reach the safety net in 1991-92 and 30 per cent will do so in future years. Offsetting the gross savings are additional costs to DVA and HIC, the cost of the pharmaceutical allowance and additional PBS costs (due to people reaching PBS safety nets faster because of RPBS drugs being counted towards them).

(2) Pharmaceuticals for DTEC and SPBC holders are provided under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme. It would be very difficult to separate them from other community pensioners who receive drugs under the PBS.
The following information for this question was provided by the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services.

As indicated by officers from the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services at Senate Estimates hearing, it is far too early to tell what the impact of pensioner co-payment will be on pharmaceutical usage patterns.
This is in part due to the fact that there was evidence of hoarding of Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme drugs by pensioners prior to the introduction of the co-payment.
There was evidence of a reduction of dispensing for pensioners in the early part of 1991. This was about 18 per cent in February-April 1991 compared to the same period in 1990.

However, this is not expected to be the long-term impact. As more pensioners become eligible for the safety net and as the effects of the stockpiling fade, the size of the reduction is expected to diminish.

It is indeed unfortunate that a definitive answer cannot be given. However, given the nature of the system, hoarding and safety net impact, it will be some time before a complete analysis can be undertaken.

However, there is nothing to lead the Government to believe at this stage that the long-term outcome will be any different to that originally predicted. (The total Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme budget for 1990-91 was, in fact, broadly in line with overall estimates.) So far the community has reacted as expected and the likely long-term effect was always predicted to be a reduction of around 15 per cent in the volume of prescriptions supplied to pensioners.
(3) Yes, the Government accepts the general proposition that those who served this nation in time of war receive compensation for their service through:
a comprehensive and proven pharmaceutical service;
quality hospital care, medical and related treatment, and counselling services; and
income support and compensation pensions and a range of associated benefits and allowances.
(4) The principle of compensation for war and service related injuries and diseases is not being undermined by the charging of a patient contribution:
veterans will be fully compensated for the patient contribution;
under the safety net arrangements no veteran will pay more for RPBS drugs in a calendar year than is received as the Pharmaceutical Allowance for that year;
advances for the pharmaceutical allowance will be available for chronically ill veterans to ensure that they are not out-of-pocket for drug costs in the short term;
the contribution has been introduced, in part, to encourage a more thoughtful and responsible use of drugs.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 23 October 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) What was the 1990-91 cost to produce and distribute the Defence Information Bulletin.
(2) What are the terms and the value of the printing contract with Pirie Printers for printing the Defence Information Bulletin.
(3) Could a copy of the Defence Information Bulletin be provided.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The cost of producing four (4) issues of the Defence Information Bulletin over the period 1990-91, was $17,700. The Defence Information Bulletin, a staff newsletter aimed principally at Defence civilian employees, is primarily distributed by departmental mailbag to various defence regional and outposted offices and the cost is absorbed within the overall bagged mail system.
(2) Pirie Printers is not, and never has been, contracted to produce the Defence Information Bulletin. The Defence Information Bulletin is currently produced by Paragon Printers of Canberra.

Under the terms of the contract with Paragon Printers, 6000 copies of a 12-16 page, two-colour A4 size newsletter including typesetting and galley proofs are printed quarterly on 110 gsm paper. The contract also specifies that the Defence Information Bulletin be completed by the printer within 10 working days of lodging camera ready copy. To date, Paragon Printers has produced one (1) issue only of the Defence Information Bulletin (Winter 1991), at a cost of $2,883.
The Defence Information Bulletin is produced by Defence Public Relations through the Australian Government Publishing Service (AGPS).
(3) Yes. I have arranged for a copy of the latest issue (Winter 1991) of the Defence Information Bulletin to be provided to the honourable senator.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 23 October 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) With reference to each and which National Media Liaison Service (NMLS) staff, past and present, how many have concurrently been an employee working the NMLS and an employee of another media organisation.
(2) Are positions in the NMLS advertised: (a) publicly; or (b) in the normal Australian Public Service manner; if not, why not; if so, by whom are the applicants interviewed.

(3) Given that some current employees of NMLS are ex-ministerial staff, why is it not considered a conflict of interest to have former political staff working in a so-called non-political government media information service.
(4) Why did the NMLS refuse to allow SBS television film the Service's office in Canberra, or the press boxes, when they were doing a public information feature on the NMLS in September 1989.

(5) Does the NMLS agree with journalist Peter Bowers, who was interviewed in the above mentioned SBS feature on the NMLS, that the NMLS do a very efficient job distributing Opposition statements to the press gallery sometimes within half an hour of the statements being made.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) No current NMLS staff have concurrently been employees of other media organisations. One former NMLS employee worked concurrently for Capital Television as a part-time newsreader/ announcer while employed by the NMLS.
(2) (a) Positions in the NMLS are advertised where it is deemed there is a need to do so.
(b) Where positions are advertised they are done so in the normal manner for Ministerial staff vacancies.
Interviews are the responsibility of the Director MMG/NMLS, who may delegate that responsibility to senior State representatives when the position to be filled is located outside Canberra.
(3) There is no conflict of interest as NMLS staff are Ministerial staff employed under the Members of Parliament (Staff) Act 1984.
(4) The NMLS felt there was no useful purpose in filming the Service's Office in Canberra.

NMLS staff did not refuse permission to film press gallery boxes and nor do they have jurisdiction to do so. Matters relating to filming within Parliament House are the jurisdiction of the Presiding Officers.
(5) No, that is not the function of the NMLS.
(6) The NMLS did not transcribe any interviews on the day in question and, thus, cannot provide any transcripts.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 29 October 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) Does the department compile statistics on the number and cause of death of returned service personnel.
(2) How many deaths of returned service personnel from Vietnam have occurred since the end of the war.
(3) How many of these deaths may be attributed to suicide.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Department compiles death statistics on the basis of notification of deaths by relatives, friends or others. These statistics are in respect of those veterans who were in receipt of a benefit from the Department or those veterans whose widows have made a claim for war widow's pension. It therefore does not have statistics of deaths of all returned service personnel.

(2) As at 30 June 1990 the total number of deaths of Vietnam veterans recorded by the Department was 1,404. This figure does not include deaths which occurred on service and does not represent the total number of deaths of Vietnam veterans.

(3) The Department has statistics of causes of post-service death of 1,083 Vietnam veterans. These have been classified using International Classification of Diseases (ICD) codes. One hundred and five deaths have been classified as deaths from `suicide and self-inflicted injury' (ICD codes E950-E959), with a further nine deaths classified as `undetermined whether accidentally or purposely inflicted' (ICD codes E980-E989).

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 6 November 1991:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the statement by Senator Richardson in relation to the proposed Tully Millstream Hydro-electricity scheme (Senate Hansard, 16 October 1991, W2183), what were the full details of options which the Commonwealth suggested to the Queensland Government as possible alternatives to the Tully Millstream Hydro-electricity scheme, prior to the Commonwealth making a final decision on the project.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: The Commonwealth Government departments represented on the Tully-Millstream Taskforce drew up a series of questions relating to the Taskforce Report, which were submitted to Queensland prior to the meeting of the Taskforce in July 1991. The questions addressed, in part, issues relating to alternatives to the Tully Millstream scheme. These issues were:
demand management options, particularly with respect to the efficiency of existing end use appliances, and savings in generating capacity from growth in solar hot water use;

a comparison of the Tully Millstream scheme with options relating to the use of gas turbines and other fossil fuel based schemes, with the comparison to bring together the options in a succinct form, showing clearly the underlying assumptions and methodologies used in framing each option;
inter-connection between the Queensland and New South Wales electricity grids;
options involving different configurations of infrastructure within the scheme itself; use of photo-voltaics; more co-generation of power;

ANSWER.PARA: greater efficiency of generating equipment; the reduction of the reserve plant margin.
